headline: Campeau Granted Assets Extension
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation said in Toronto that the Edward J. DeBartolo Company, a major American shopping-mall developer, has extended until Aug. 6 a stand-still agreement under which DeBartolo will not seize any Campeau assets without first providing nine days' notice. Campeau, a Canadian developer, owns the Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corporation, two American retail chains.

headline: Buenos Aires Journal;   Where Horatio Alger Heroes Want to Pack It Up
abstract: LEAD: For Yolanda and Alfredo Di Sanso, their 10 years as business owners have been a losing struggle against political instability, runaway inflation, recession and government economic policies that were protectionist one day and free-trade the next.

headline: Matsushita-Tandy Venture Reported
abstract: LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan and the Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth will produce personal computers at a Texas plant under a joint venture, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. The size of the planned investment was not known, the newspaper said.

headline: Britain's Deficit Eases
abstract: LEAD: The British Government on Monday announced a better-than-expected trade deficit for August. The deficit on the current account of the balance of payments, measuring merchandise trade and such invisible factors as banking, insurance and tourism, fell to $:1.13 billion (about $2.1 billion) in August from a revised $:1.68 billion in July.

headline: Bhutto to Face a Judge in Response to Charges of Corruption
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan's ousted Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, said today that she would appear before a tribunal that would decide her political future.

headline: Net Up at Chevron and Mobil as Texaco and Phillips Fall
abstract: LEAD: The Chevron Corporation, helped by steady gasoline prices and demand in the West, where half of its refined products are sold in the United States, continued to outperform most major oil companies in the second quarter, posting a strong profit gain of 60.4 percent.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   Bush, in Freezing Assets, Bars $30 Billion to Hussein
abstract: LEAD: In freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States, President Bush has fenced off an estimated $30 billion from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government analysts say.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Anti-Government Protesters Rally in a Bucharest Square
abstract: LEAD: Scores of anti-Government demonstrators rallied tonight in University Square in the capital's center, the site of a 53-day demonstration that was violently broken up by the police in mid-June.

headline: Long-Term Securities Rebound
abstract: LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly yesterday after the Government's successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds, the last of its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding sales this week.

headline: Heublein Jobs Heading West
abstract: LEAD: The San Francisco agency Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein has a number a new accounts on which to test its creative reputation. The agency has been awarded all but one of Heublein's alcoholic beverages, formerly advertised by Young & Rubicam.      The brands include Jose

headline: Patents;   Tougher Materials For Superconductors
abstract: LEAD: Government researchers this week patented a tough new class of superconducting plastic composite materials. They are designed to overcome the inherent brittleness of recently discovered high-temperature superconductors, which are like ceramics. In particular, the researchers hope the new composites will make it easier to shape superconductors into rails for powering magnetically levitated trains.

headline: The Failure of Traditional Law Schools
abstract: LEAD: The popular assumptions that legal education transfers specialized information about the practice of law and teaches law students how to do legal work are misconceived. Likewise, the imagined stereotype of the masterful law professor transferring nuggets of wisdom through an intellectually rigorous

headline: Qatar Offering Installations To Foreign Forces in the Gulf
abstract: LEAD: Qatar joined other Arab countries in the Persian Gulf today in agreeing to make military sites available to the growing international force intended to deter an Iraqi attack.

headline: Technology;   The Internationalization of the Cash Machine
abstract: LEAD: American Express traveler's checks? Just leave home without them. In a development that could render traveler's checks obsolete and spell doom for street-corner money changers, automated teller machines are rapidly going global. Already, for example, a tourist from Buffalo can walk up to at least a few automated tellers in Tokyo and withdraw cash, in yen, from his or her bank back home.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., appointed James D. Varrato senior vice president for distribution services, replacing Paul W. Reese Jr., who is leaving the company in September.

headline: Iraq Grants More Visas to U.S. Networks Than Newspapers
abstract: LEAD: With the Persian Gulf crisis entering its eighth week, most major American newspapers have been struggling unsuccessfully to obtain visas to provide daily news coverage from Iraq.

headline: Romania Frees Student Held in 53-Day Protest
abstract: LEAD: A student who led a 53-day anti-Government rally has been freed after six weeks' detention, and he denied charges today that he incited protesters to violence.

headline: Technology;   Heating, Cooking and Now - Driving
abstract: LEAD: As the nation's cities grapple with air pollution from automobile exhaust, natural gas - best known for heating homes and cooking dinners - is drawing increasing attention as a clean-burning alternative to gasoline and diesel fuel. The General Motors Corporation said last week it would sell a minimum of 1,000 pickup trucks powered by natural gas starting next year, and United Parcel

headline: Treasuries Fall in Slow Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose in sluggish trading yesterday, as credit market participants sold notes and bonds because of a jump in oil prices.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * A.B. Electrolux, a Swedish appliance maker, said it had won a contract, worth more than $100 million, to design and provide technology for a compressor factory in the Soviet Union.

headline: KEATING INDICTED IN SAVINGS FRAUD AND GOES TO JAIL
abstract: LEAD: Charles H. Keating Jr., who has been widely portrayed as a symbol of the misconduct and reckless investment style that devastated the savings and loan industry, was indicted on criminal fraud charges today and led to jail after he was unable to post the $5 million bail.

headline: Japanese Shrine Burns Down
abstract: LEAD: A fire today destroyed an important Shinto shrine guarding sacred rice being grown for the coronation of Emperor Akihito. The police said they suspected anti-monarchist militants, who have said that they plan to disrupt Akihito's November coronation. They say the imperial system is a remnant of prewar nationalism.

headline: Currency;   The Yen's Turn to Shine
abstract: LEAD: Finally, the yen. Long after the German mark and other European currencies strengthened against the dollar, the yen is making a move. On Friday, the dollar briefly fell below the 140 level against the yen and ended trading in New York at 140.05. This is the strongest the yen has been since October.

headline: A New Interest in Taxing Trades
abstract: LEAD: Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against.

headline: Yields Down Only a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to decline in the week ended yesterday. The declines, however, were not significant.

headline: Terrorist Threats to U.S. Rise After Countermove on Iraq
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today that threats of terrorist attacks against the United States had increased sharply since the United States took action against Iraq in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Art's Cozy Relationship With Business
abstract: LEAD: In a development that gives new meaning to the term ''corporate takeover,'' art museums are increasingly promoting the commercial interests of the companies giving them money - not just indirectly, by enhancing a sponsor's public image, but directly, by helping to hawk wares ranging from perfume to vodka to credit cards.

headline: Business and Health;   Method of Pricing Drug Is Assailed
abstract: LEAD: IN the latest battle over drug pricing tactics, state and Federal officials, doctors and advocates for patients say one company is opening the door to a novel and inflationary marketing method. The company, the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corporation, requires patients who purchase clozapine, a promising treatment for schizophrenia, to buy a Sandoz-licensed program of weekly blood tests.

headline: Weekends: A Time for Credit Cards
abstract: LEAD: AMERICAN EXPRESS is to begin its first national advertising campaign today for a special credit card program for members and merchants called ''Weekend Privileges.''

headline: I.M.F. Plan on Lending Is Challenged by Banks
abstract: LEAD: An organization representing the world's largest commercial banks openly challenged the International Monetary Fund today on one of the most sensitive points of its global debt strategy, the fund's willingness to lend money to countries behind in interest payments to commercial banks.

headline: Trade Deficit Increases Modestly
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit rose modestly in May, to $7.73 billion, fueled by the economy's heavy reliance on oil imports and foreign automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: Trump Keeps Shuttle; $10 Fare Rise Planned
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that the Trump Shuttle was no longer for sale. In a separate announcement, the airline said it would raise its fares by $10, effective Monday.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Litton Industries Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of liquid yield option notes due 2010. The sale is expected to bring the company about $265 million in proceeds.

headline: Pipe Bomb on Israeli Beach Kills Canadian and Hurts 19
abstract: LEAD: A pipe bomb exploded today on a crowded Tel Aviv beach, killing a 17-year-old Canadian tourist and wounding 19 people, officials said.

headline: Saudi Arabia, Fearing Terrorist Attacks, Tightens Internal Security
abstract: LEAD: Reacting to what appear to be direct threats from Iraq, Saudi officials are tightening internal security measures, saying they fear that Iraq and radical Palestinian groups may be planning terrorist attacks here.

headline: Labor Pact Is Ratified At U.P.S.
abstract: LEAD: A strike against the United Parcel Service of America Inc., the world's largest package shipper, was averted today when drivers and handlers rejected the recommendation of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' leadership and narrowly ratified a new three-year contract.

headline: Revco Plans to Sell Southwest Stores
abstract: LEAD: Revco D.S. Inc. will sell 146 retail stores in the Southwest to a Maryland company in a divestiture plan announced in January. The stores, in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and Colorado, are being sold to the RDS Acquisition Corporation, formed by a group of longtime retail drugstore executives, Revco said.

headline: Tin Group Nears End
abstract: LEAD: The International Tin Council, which never recovered from the 1985 collapse of its plans to support the price of tin, said last week that it would vote on July 31 to disband. The Tin Council, made up of 22 tin-consuming and producing countries, no longer has any reason to continue after it settled its debts in March from a long-running case that followed the collapse of its buffer stock operations.

headline: President's Post Filled At a Software Company
abstract: LEAD: John F. Burton, who joined the Legent Corporation last year when Legent bought out his software company, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer and a board member of the systems software company.

headline: Unusual Deal By America West Seen
abstract: LEAD: America West Airlines Inc. has arranged an unusual way to finance its $200 million purchase of the Pan Am Shuttle, people familiar with the negotiations said. Aircraft leasing companies and an engine manufacturer are said to be lending the airline the money in exchange for America West's agreement to purchase or lease more than 100 Airbus Industrie

headline: Inquiry on Grumman Ex-Chief
abstract: LEAD: John O'Brien, who resigned abruptly as chairman of the Grumman Corporation late Thursday, is the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation into possible illegal loans from a military subcontractor and lobbyist, Federal officials said yesterday.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Moscow Fears That Lack of Food May Provoke Crisis
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government has warned the nation that social tensions will probably increase because of worsening food problems and a limited supply of hard currency to purchase grain overseas.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Offering Billions to Arabs To Help Offset Gulf Crisis Losses
abstract: LEAD: Japan is offering what may amount to billions of dollars in financial aid as well as communications and transportation support to Middle East nations that would suffer by cutting off trade with Iraq and Kuwait, the Foreign Ministry has said.

headline: Move by FundAmerica
abstract: LEAD: FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it. The company, based in Irvine, Calif., is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit filed in San Francisco.

headline: NEW ALLEGATIONS IN JESUIT KILLINGS
abstract: LEAD: The army unit accused in the slayings in November of six priests searched several Jesuit-owned houses eight hours before the killings and warned residents of the neighborhood to prepare for fighting in the area later that night, a senior Salvadoran Jesuit official says.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Kohl Will Meet Gorbachev Today in Moscow on Unity
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will fly to Moscow late Saturday for some personal diplomacy with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hoping to convince the Soviet leader to drop his remaining objections to German unification within NATO, West German officials said today.

headline: Afghan on a Sudden Trip to Moscow
abstract: LEAD: As Afghan rebel leaders and Pakistani officials await the results of talks on Afghanistan between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, attention here and in Kabul is riveted on the sudden and mysterious trip to Moscow by the Afghan leader, Najibullah.

headline: Economic Scene;   The Oil Reserve: Big Is Beautiful
abstract: LEAD: HOW much energy insurance is really enough?

headline: Earnings Plunge at G.M., Ford
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company yesterday reported sharply lower second-quarter profits. Both auto makers cited difficult market conditions in North America, and both were hit by economic disruption in Brazil that virtually stopped vehicle production there.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   To Albanians, 'Ciao Italia!' Means Haven
abstract: LEAD: Tattered, penniless and weary, but jubilant just the same, thousands of Albanian refugees sailed today into Western Europe and, they were certain, to a better life.

headline: Hearst Reported to Seek Nabisco's 20% of ESPN
abstract: LEAD: The Hearst Corporation has been negotiating the possible acquisition of the 20 percent stake in ESPN now owned by RJR Nabisco, according to an executive of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., which owns the rest of the cable sports service.

headline: Building a More Fuel-Efficient Jet
abstract: LEAD: Concerned about sharply higher oil prices, aircraft manufacturers are taking a fresh look at technology that can help planes squeeze more miles out of a tank of jet fuel.

headline: Kohl Gets German Spotlight But Genscher Had the Vision
abstract: LEAD: The man of the hour of German unity may be Chancellor Helmut Kohl, but the man who first saw it coming is certainly Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.

headline: Semiconductor Panel Backs Added Sematech Financing
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors said today that the committee still supported an increase in financing for Sematech, the semiconductor industry consortium.

headline: Rio Journal;   Bodyguards? Don't Leave Home Without Them
abstract: LEAD: The criminals' nicknames seem to be borrowed from the comics: Big Olive, Petunia, Butter George, Sweet Talker, Baby Skull, Little Rat and The Professor.

headline: Armed Raids in Pakistan Kill 27 Mohajirs
abstract: LEAD: Masked gunmen killed 27 people and wounded 83 today in raids on members of Pakistan's powerful Mohajir national movement, hospital officials said.

headline: Boeing Holding Talks To Sell de Havilland
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that it was discussing the possible sale of its de Havilland commuter-aircraft division to Aeritalia of Italy and Aerospatiale of France. De Havilland, which Boeing purchased from the Canadian Government in 1986, builds airplanes with 36 to 56 seats and is based in Downsview,

headline: Gasoline Up As Supplies Stay Tight
abstract: LEAD: Wholesale gasoline prices jumped again yesterday, but crude oil prices rose more modestly. Demand for gasoline remains strong, because of shortages of refinery capacity, traders said.

headline: Paper in Dublin Will Automate
abstract: LEAD: Ingersoll Publications Ltd. announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with unions at The Irish Press in Dublin that will allow the paper to install computerized typesetting equipment by the end of the year and to take other cost-saving measures.

headline: Saatchi Set To Sell Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the London-based advertising conglomerate, said today that it had agreed to sell the Gartner Group, an American consulting firm, for $70 million.

headline: Memo to Banks: Deep-Six The Dividends
abstract: LEAD: ''Every banker knows that if he has to prove that he is worthy of credit, however good may be his arguments, in fact his credit is gone.''

headline: Matsushita In Talks With MCA
abstract: LEAD: Underscoring the intense interest of the Japanese in the United States entertainment industry, Matsushita, the giant Japanese electronics maker, confirmed yesterday that it was in talks with MCA Inc. to acquire the Los Angeles-based entertainment company.

headline: Zulu and Mandela Groups Begin Talks
abstract: LEAD: The African National Congress said tonight that it would invite Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the president of the Zulu-based political movement Inkatha, to a conference to work out a common strategy for stopping fighting between the two groups that has caused nearly 5,000 deaths in the last four years.

headline: Seaborne Guerrillas Shell the Residence Of Liberia's Leader
abstract: LEAD: A rebel gunboat attacked President Samuel K. Doe's seafront executive mansion before dawn today and troops inside the fortified command post fired back, witnesses said.

headline: Angola Rejects Rebel Relief-Aid Plan
abstract: LEAD: Saying it fears a trap laid by the United States, the Government of Angola has rejected a proposal by Jonas Savimbi, the American-backed rebel leader, for the creation of safe routes by which food and medicine can be supplied to famine-stricken areas under guerrilla control.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From 'Open Letter' To Bush by President of Iraq
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Saddam Hussein's ''open letter'' to President Bush today, as transmitted by the official Iraqi press agency and translated by Reuters:

headline: Soviets Open Prisons and Records To Inquiry on Wallenberg's Fate
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to open prisons and archives to an international commission investigating the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared into the Soviet prison system after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, members of the commission said today.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   TWO IRAQI TANKERS IGNORE PURSUERS
abstract: LEAD: American warships continued to shadow two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in waters near the Persian Gulf today as the ships, heading toward the Indian Ocean, showed no signs of reversing course, Pentagon officials said.

headline: Liberian Rebel Says He'll Arrest Foreigners to Stir World Attention
abstract: LEAD: A rebel leader, Prince Johnson, said today that he was ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia to provoke international intervention in the nation's war.

headline: Kuwaiti in U.S. Speaks Of an Exile Leadership
abstract: LEAD: The Kuwaiti government-in-exile is directing an underground armed resistance and a wide assortment of public services inside its country, from garbage removal to emergency medical care, senior Kuwaiti officials said today.

headline: Japan Sending Vehicles and Housing for Military Effort in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: Japanese officials, moving to counter criticism that the country has been slow to aid the military buildup in the Middle East, said today that hundreds of off-road vehicles, generators, housing units and other items would be shipped shortly for use by armed forces stationed in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Tax-Exempt Chrysler Trust Backed by Municipal Leases
abstract: LEAD: In an innovative financing, the Chrysler Financial Corporation offered $35 million worth of tax-exempt asset-backed securities late last week through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Farm Credit Bank's $275 Million Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Bank is offering $275 million in system bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Prices Up 9.8% in Britain
abstract: LEAD: Retail prices in Britain rose 9.8 percent in the 12 months that ended in July, the same rate as in June, the Government said Friday. Some economists had forecast that the rate might break through 10 percent because of higher wage settlements and consumer spending. Lower prices for seasonal foods in July left the figure unchanged from June.

headline: Economic Scene;   How Hussein Miscalculated
abstract: LEAD: The crisis in the Persian Gulf struck at a time when demand for oil was weakening and prices sagging. In fact, Saddam Hussein's decision to gobble up Kuwait was driven by his need to shore up Iraq's failing economy, undermined by the long war with Iran. So he has put his unemployed, million-man army back to work, both to grab his neighbor's oilfields and refineries and also to panic the world oil market into a steep run-up in price.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 29:       MONDAY       Armstrong World Inds.    Baxter Intl.    Csldtd Freightways    Duke Pwr. Co.    Foster Wheeler Corp.    Georgia Pac. Corp.    Kennametal Inc.    Philadelphia Subn. Corp.    U.S. Surgical Corp.    United Technologies Corp.

headline: Division Chief For Grand Met
abstract: LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s food sector has put Peter M. Thompson in charge of its division that oversees Pillsbury International, Haagen-Dazs and Grand Met Foodservice U.S.A.

headline: Waterford Strike
abstract: LEAD: Workers at Waterford Crystal glass works in Ireland ended a 14-week strike today after agreeing on cost-cutting proposals with management.The strike by 2,300 workers at Waterford's three plants began on April 5 over cost cuts, including the scrapping of bonuses for 500 glass cutters. Waterford said management and unions had agreed to refer issues on pay and conditions still in dispute to binding arbitration.

headline: Embalmed Body of Bulgarian Communist Is Taken From Mausoleum and Cremated
abstract: LEAD: The embalmed body of the man regarded as the founder of Communist Bulgaria, Georgi Dimitrov, was removed from a mausoleum in Sofia's main square on Wednesday and cremated, news reports in Sofia said today.

headline: Market Place;   2 Companies Gain In Mideast Woes
abstract: LEAD: IT is an old tradition on Wall Street that even an ill wind can whip up a nice profit for someone.

headline: U.S. Insists Individual Nations Can't Break Blockade of Iraq
abstract: LEAD: Individual nations do not have the right to break the international trade blockade of Iraq, senior United States officials said in New York today, explaining their argument with countries seeking to send food and medicine through the sanctions net imposed by the United Nations.

headline: Bhutto Must Now Confront Foes on Volatile Issue of Religion
abstract: LEAD: Faced with an undeclared ethnic war in her home province of Sind and a tense standoff with India over the disputed territory of Kashmir, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto heads next week into a confrontation with her political opponents on Pakistan's most volatile issue: religion.

headline: Treasury Bonds Post Solid Gains
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates fell and the price of Treasury securities rose yesterday, with the benchmark long bond jumping more than a point. The gains were fueled by a drop in oil prices and rising hopes among market participants that the Federal Reserve Board may move to ease short-term interest rates soon, perhaps by the end of the week.

headline: U.S. Blocks Columbia 'Junk' Sale
abstract: LEAD: Saying the Columbia Savings and Loan Association had failed to get the best value for its portfolio of high-yield ''junk bonds,'' Federal regulators today blocked a $3 billion proposed sale of the bonds to a Canadian investment company.

headline: UAL Unions Drop Pact With Coniston
abstract: LEAD: The union group that is bidding to buy the UAL Corporation said yesterday that it had ended an agreement with the company's biggest shareholder, Coniston Partners, enabling the group to explore ways to buy the company without having to make constant disclosures to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Castel Gandolfo Makes Ready for the Pope
abstract: LEAD: It tends to be quieter when the town's chief summer resident is away, and so there was not much to do in the main square this day other than sit at the cafe and shoo flies.

headline: Oil Aid Plans By the I.M.F.
abstract: LEAD: The head of the International Monetary Fund predicted today that his 152-nation organization would back United States-led efforts to provide financial assistance to countries hurt by the Persian Gulf turmoil.

headline: Bush Presents Plan to Help Andean Nations Grow Non-Coca Crops
abstract: LEAD: President Bush announced trade concessions, expanded agricultural development assistance and other measures to help Ecuador, Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, the main cocaine-producing countries of Latin America, to develop alternative exports.

headline: Oil-Price Climb Slows; New Stability Possible
abstract: LEAD: The rise in oil prices on world markets slowed yesterday. And prices could steady or even fall, analysts and traders said, if Saudi Arabia raised its production and other exporting nations followed suit.

headline: Midway Air Is Cutting Staff
abstract: LEAD: In another sign of hard times in the nation's airline industry, Midway Airlines Inc. said today that it was cutting its staff by 10 percent, putting about 500 people out of work.

headline: G.E. Announces Plans To Cut More Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company said today that it would cut more jobs because of a shrinking military budget.

headline: Fujitsu Introduces Two Supercomputers
abstract: LEAD: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's biggest computer maker, today introduced two powerful supercomputers and an operating system that can run all the company's computers.

headline: R.T.C. Stance On Assets
abstract: LEAD: The Government must strike a balance between its duty to clean up the savings and loan crisis and the need to protect the institutions' assets that have environmental value, Federal officials told a Congressional panel today.

headline: Your Money;   Overseas Stocks Require Caution
abstract: LEAD: Stock markets in both Europe and Japan have substantially outperformed American markets in recent years, leading some investment experts to recommend foreign holdings to put some pep into portfolios. Yet, the North American Securities Administrators Association, in a report issued last week, warned

headline: Syrian Chief Is Said to Urge Iran Not to Violate Embargo
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with his Iranian counterpart, President Hashemi Rafsanjani, and reportedly tried to persuade him not to send food and medicine to Iraq in violation of the United Nations embargo.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. and Israel Say They'll Seek 'Credible' Mideast Peace Process
abstract: LEAD: In the first high-level meeting between Israeli and American officials since the Persian Gulf crisis began, Israel and the United States agreed today to work to establish a ''credible'' Arab-Israeli peace process to demonstrate to the Arab world that there is an alternative to the violent approach advocated by President Saddam Hussein of

headline: AN ISRAELI OFFICER IS FATALLY BURNED
abstract: LEAD: Palestinian youths burned an Israeli army officer to death in his car in the Gaza Strip today, Palestinian witnesses and the army said.

headline: Venezuela in Shift on Citgo
abstract: LEAD: The Venezuelan state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., no longer plans to sell the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it purchased in February from the Southland Corporation, a senior Petroleos official said today.

headline: AIDS in Africa: A Killer Rages On
abstract: LEAD: The AIDS epidemic continues to course through Africa, outracing the prevention campaigns that have now been started by every government.

headline: New Airline In Korea Irks Flag Carrier
abstract: LEAD: A plan by a fledgling South Korean carrier, Asiana Airlines, to buy billions of dollars worth of Boeing jets to cash in on an expected Asian travel boom has irritated the long-established flag carrier, Korean Air Lines.

headline: Saudi Move For OPEC Meeting
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia, laying the basis for a sharp increase in its oil production without OPEC's approval, stressed to other members of the organization yesterday that it was seeking a meeting to discuss the issue and that opposition to such discussion was not reasonable.

headline: Company News;   MCI-Telecom Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $1.25 billion merger of the MCI Communications Corporation and Telecom USA Inc. MCI said the merger to be completed before the end of the month, pending state regulatory approvals. MCI plans to acquire all of Telecom's outstanding common shares for $42 each, or about $1.25 billion.

headline: I.B.M. to Offer New Computers
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce on Sept. 5 its plans for introducing mainframe computers twice as powerful as the current systems, a market research group said.

headline: Technology;   Rehabilitating the Image of the Two-Stroke Engine
abstract: LEAD: When the Berlin wall opened last fall, one recurring image of a society where technology had stood still for 40 years was the little East German Trabant automobile, with its noisy two-stroke engine spewing pollutants and fumes. Westerners are more accustomed to two-strokes in lawnmowers than in cars.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American International Group Inc., New York an insurance company, said it completed the acquisition of International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., a jet-aircraft leasing company. Each outstanding common share of International Lease was converted into the right to receive $32.50.

headline: Thorn EMI Buys Filmtrax
abstract: LEAD: The entertainment and electronics giant Thorn EMI P.L.C. said today that it was buying a British music publishing company with rights to such musical titles as ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Itsa Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny Yellow Polka Dot Bikini.''

headline: Wood Gundy Cuts Staff
abstract: LEAD: Wood Gundy Inc., a big Canadian brokerage, cut 21 workers today from its investment banking staff, reflecting a slump among investment firms in Canada. Both retail and corporate investors have turned away from stocks in favor of more conservative investments after the stock market crash in October 1987 and decline in October 1989, analysts said.

headline: The Fine Art of the Disney Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said today that a top Hollywood production team and a Japanese investment group had agreed to provide several hundred million dollars in financing for Disney films in coming years.

headline: Franklin and Seiko Distribution Deal
abstract: LEAD: Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. announced that it would sell electronic reference products in Japan under a distribution agreement with Seiko Instruments Inc. The publishing company, based in Mount Holly, will export electronic speaking dictionaries intended for students of English as a foreign language.

headline: Shares of Polly Peck Tumble in London
abstract: LEAD: The stock of Polly Peck International P.L.C. lost more than half its value on London's Stock Exchange today before the conglomerate asked the exchange to suspend trading.

headline: Need for Lower Rates Stressed by Analysts
abstract: LEAD: How soon will the Federal Reserve move to reduce interest rates and will the cuts be deep enough to ward off a recession that many economists believe is already gripping the nation?

headline: Excerpts From Iraqi Chief's Note and Iraqi Official's Remarks
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from an ''open letter'' from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to President Bush yesterday, as transmitted by the official Iraqi News Agency and translated from the Arabic by Reuters, and excerpts from a news conference yesterday by the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, in Amman, Jordan, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Asian Refugees in Airlift
abstract: LEAD: Seventy-two planes have been chartered to transport 19,000 Bangladeshi and Sri Lankan refugees from Iraq and Kuwait who are stranded in Jordan because of the Persian Gulf crisis. The airlift, which began on Monday, is focusing on refugees from third-world countries whose governments do not have the money to transport their citizens.

headline: Fire Kills 12 and Injures 25 in Lebanon as Fuel Truck Hits a Hotel
abstract: LEAD: A fuel truck hit a hotel in eastern Lebanon today and burst into flames, starting a fire that killed 12 people and badly burned 25 others, the police said.

headline: Company News;   Freeport-McMoran In Stock Swap Deal
abstract: LEAD: Freeport-McMoran Inc. agreed to acquire the publicly held shares of its Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas Company affiliate in a stock swap worth about $241 million. Holders of the stock will get about three shares of stock in the parent company for every 10 shares held, the company said. Freeport-McMoran valued the oil and gas unit at $10.50 a share.

headline: Magazine Revenues Up
abstract: LEAD: Magazine advertising revenues for the first half of 1990 rose a slim 1.6 percent, to $3.28 billion, compared with the period a year earlier, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Advertising pages fell 3.3 percent.

headline: Oyama Journal;   One Plum After Another; Still the People Leave
abstract: LEAD: Three decades ago, when the enemy in much of rural Japan was poverty combined with brutal working conditions, this riverside farming town became a symbol of self-improvement by encouraging the local farmers to break their dependence on rice and experiment with cash crops, principally plums and chestnuts.

headline: No Headline
abstract: LEAD:              Net Income   Percent       Apr.-June   Change       1990   From '89        American Cyanamid Co.   $ 111,400,000    +4.0        Cincinnati Milacron Inc.   3,100,000    -40.4        Coca-Cola Co.   409,900,000    +18.6        Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc.   55,300,000    +42.5        Adolph Coors Co.   25,100,000    +48.5        Federal Signal Corp.

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF    ARAB VOTE TO SEND TROOPS TO HELP SAUDIS; BOYCOTT OF IRAQI OIL IS REPORTED NEAR 100%;   Baghdad Isolated
abstract: LEAD: Arab countries moved tonight to confront Iraq's thrust into Kuwait by voting to send troops to Saudi Arabia, with only Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization openly backing the isolated Iraqis in the crucial decision.

headline: Medjugorje Journal;   Do 4 Behold the Virgin? Bishop Is Not a Believer
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican has warned that church-sponsored pilgrimages to this mountain village are banned, but that has not stopped Roman Catholic pilgrims from crowding into Medjugorje, where the Virgin Mary is said to have been appearing daily to four young people for the last decade.

headline: Paine Webber Lays Off 34 Employees
abstract: LEAD: Responding to the downturn on Wall Street, Paine Webber Inc. dismissed about 9 percent of its investment banking staff last week.

headline: In Romania, Ceausescu Is Gone but His Crippling Economic Legacy Endures
abstract: LEAD: The mammoth August 23 Conglomerate, which produces locomotive and industrial engines, was Nicolae Ceausescu's pet factory, and the factory clings to part of the executed dictator's grim legacy: a near-total obliviousness to market realities.

headline: Son of Former Military Ruler Goes Into Politics in Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: A son of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, convinced that the time is right to revive the name of Pakistan's late military ruler, has set aside a career in banking and plunged into politics in anticipation of elections on Oct. 24.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   THATCHER WARNS EUROPE OVER GULF
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that Europeans were in danger of losing the global military protection of the United States unless they took a broader view of their security interests than they have in the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: New Home Front Developing As Women Hear Call to Arms
abstract: LEAD: Since the Navy hospital ship Mercy set sail more than a month ago, Eric Laver has been both father and mother to his children, juggling the demands of work and family and sorting through conflicting feelings of anger and pride about a wife who volunteered for duty in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Offering by Sun May Be Halted
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it might not proceed with previously announced plans for a stock offering because the price of its stock had declined as a result of the selloff on the stock market amid the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Bill Dunlap, chief executive officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising, has been named chairman of the central region of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

headline: Renault Seeks All of Mack Trucks
abstract: LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc., an ailing company that still bears the most famous name in American truck making, announced yesterday that it had received a $100 million takeover bid from Renault, the French state-owned maker of autos and trucks.

headline: Oil Prices Decline Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices retreated slightly yesterday but remained above $30 a barrel in futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Gold Rises Above $400; 5-Month High
abstract: LEAD: Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday, fueled by the Middle East crisis. Gold jumped to more than $400 an ounce for the first time in five months.

headline: FAG Bearings to Acquire Barden Corp. for $131 Million
abstract: LEAD: The FAG Bearings Corporation, the United States-based subsidiary of a large West German bearings and industrial systems manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Barden Corporation for $66.50 a share, or $131.1 million.

headline: In Europe, Ambiance Costs $10
abstract: LEAD: It's one thing to hand over an unfamiliar bill or a few strange coins after a pleasant hour at a Paris sidewalk cafe. It's quite a different thing to find that you've just spent $10 for a Coke and sandwich and a touch of ambiance.

headline: A Top Position Is Filled By Alaska Airlines
abstract: LEAD: Alaska Airlines yesterday named Raymond J. Vecci, its chief operating officer, as its president and chief executive.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;   Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * A creative team from Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, won the grand prize in the Gannett outdoor group's ''Creative Challange.'' The company invited New York creative people to design billboards, and 120 groups from 8 agencies participated. For their winning entry, a billboard for Oil of Olay, an art director, Ralph Yznaga, and a copywriter, Alison Grant, will receive trips to London.

headline: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal
abstract: LEAD: Eager to give its corporate clients worldwide an opportunity to deal in futures and options, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation of Japan said today that it would form a venture with the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd., one of this country's leading traders of options and futures.

headline: Iran's Ailing Economy Is Reeling From Quake
abstract: LEAD: Just when Iran's sickly economy seemed incapable of sustaining another blow, it was dealt a tremendous one by the earthquake in June.

headline: In Poll, French Favor Gulf Role
abstract: LEAD: By a slight margin, the people of France want their armed forces to fight alongside the United States in the event of war involving Iraq, according to a poll made public on Friday. Of 800 people surveyed for Le Point magazine, 47 percent said they favored French participation in an international force and 43 percent were opposed.

headline: Company News;   Japonica Accepts Plan on Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: Japonica Partners agreed with creditors of Allegheny International Inc. to take control of the bankrupt appliance maker on Aug. 15. The partnership, based in New York and Rhode Island, has been pursuing Allegheny for about a year. Allegheny, which filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in February 1988, owns the Sunbeam Corporation, maker of Sunbeam and

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allen Group., Melville, L.I., an automotive products manufacturer, completed two separate acquisitions: the purchase of a 50 percent interest in a new-partnership joint venture with Metropolitan Air Research Testing Authority, Nashville, and the purchase of 80 percent of the stock outstanding of Grayson Electronics Co., Lynchburg, Va.

headline: Island Feud Slowing Japan-Soviet Thaw
abstract: LEAD: Japan and the Soviet Union, in their most intense round of diplomatic activity in recent years, tried and failed this week to narrow their differences on a 45-year territorial dispute that has stood in the way of improved relations.

headline: Puritan Oil Moves to Ayer
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday switched the advertising account for Puritan oil from Grey Advertising to Ayer. Grey remains the agency for the company's Crisco shortening and oil products.

headline: An Investment Adviser Becomes a Private Bank
abstract: LEAD: Morris W. Offit has a new bank named after him, the Offitbank.

headline: Pakistan Reports Clash With India in Kashmir
abstract: LEAD: Indian soldiers tried to capture a mountain outpost, starting a firefight with Pakistani soldiers along the cease-fire line dividing the disputed region of Kashmir, Pakistan said today.

headline: Arabs to Discuss the Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Arab diplomats here said a quorum had been reached today to call a disputed meeting of Arab League foreign ministers in Cairo on Wednesday to discuss the crisis in the Persian Gulf region.

headline: Tartikoff Show Goes On, But Its Script Is Changing
abstract: LEAD: JUST before Brandon Tartikoff faced the press for the last time as NBC's chief programming executive, he strapped on a mobile microphone and headset, a la Madonna, and sang a two-minute rap number with the network's newest star, Will Smith - also known as the Fresh Prince.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Putting Limits on Aid To Nations Hurt by Embargo
abstract: LEAD: Japanese officials attached new conditions today to the financial aid pledge Japan made last week to help Middle Eastern countries hurt by the trade embargo on Iraq.

headline: Offering by Massachusetts Has Maximum Yield of 8%
abstract: LEAD: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, whose fiscal stability is under siege from a weakening economy, various legal challenges and a tax-cut proposal to be voted on in November, came to market yesterday with a $1.3 billion offering of fixed- and variable-rate securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital

headline: Panel Hears How Federal Aid Profited a Savings Institution
abstract: LEAD: A Senate subcommittee was told today that a Texas savings and loan association made up of 15 failed institutions earned huge profits as a result of Government subsidies, but made only four new loans in 1989.

headline: A Bond Strategy for Foreigners
abstract: LEAD: With the economy slowing down, or possibly in a recession, and with a steadily weakening dollar, there is little to attract foreign investors to the American stock and bond markets From January through May, foreigners were net sellers of $6.7 billion in American stocks and $5.9 billion in Government securities, according to the most recent data from the Securities Industry Association.

headline: Patents;   No Drill, No Novocain In Laser Dental System
abstract: LEAD: American Dental Laser Inc. of Birmingham, Mich., obtained a patent this week on a laser system to remove tooth and gum decay without the need for drills, scrapers or even Novocain.

headline: Ex-Trump Official Hired by Resorts
abstract: LEAD: Jack O'Donnell, who recently quit as president of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, was named to run Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel.

headline: Markets Closed For Holiday
abstract: LEAD: The nation's stock, bond and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Labor Day holiday. Government offices and most banks will also be closed.

headline: G.N.P. Rate Up Just 1.2% In 2d Period
abstract: LEAD: In its latest figures on the health of the American economy, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the United States was much closer to a recession than Government statistics had recognized until now.

headline: BUSH TELLS IRAQIS LEADERS PUT THEM ON 'BRINK OF WAR'
abstract: LEAD: President Bush warned the Iraqi people today that their leaders had now brought them to ''the brink of war'' with the West and the Arab world.

headline: For Higher Gas Prices, Many Villains to Blame
abstract: LEAD: Paul Evantoff paid 5 cents a gallon more this morning to fill his gas tank at Fred's Chevron than it did last week, a development he attributed to the eagerness of the big oil companies to cash in on the turmoil in the Middle East. ''It's really greed with a capital 'G,' '' Mr. Evantoff said.

headline: Africa Study of AIDS Drug Finds Immune-Cell Rise
abstract: LEAD: A new study in Africa by the World Health Organization has shown that a drug chewed as a wafer boosted the number of immune cells in a small number of AIDS patients whose immune cells had been damaged by the AIDS virus, an official of the international agency said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Ends Soviet Curb
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to bolster United States-Soviet trade, President Bush today raised a longstanding ceiling on the number of Soviet business people permitted to live and work in the United States.

headline: Allied-Signal Product
abstract: LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency gave permission last week for Allied-Signal Inc. to begin marketing a substitute for chlorofluorocarbons, a chemicial that has been found to cause damage to the earth's ozone layer. The new substance, called HCFC 141b, can replace chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, in solvents and foam insulation, said William M.

headline: Sega Commercials Take On Nintendo
abstract: LEAD: Sega of America, a maker of video games, will begin a campaign next week that takes a hit at rival Nintendo of America.

headline: Tokyo Said to Tell China It Will Go Ahead on Loan
abstract: LEAD: A senior Japanese official has told Chinese leaders here that despite the tepid endorsement its diplomatic opening to China received from President Bush in Houston it intends to push ahead, a Japanese official who attended the meetings said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    The Houston Summit

headline: Chilean Communists in Turmoil About the Future
abstract: LEAD: The Chilean Communist Party, an entrenched part of the political scene since 1922 and traditionally one of the most loyal to Moscow, is going through internal turmoil with ousters, mass resignations and public name calling.

headline: Burma Seizes 6 Opponents, Including Election Leaders
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese military Government, which ignored May's election landslide for the opposition, announced today that it had arrested the acting opposition leader and five other major dissidents.

headline: Loan for Shanghai VW
abstract: LEAD: Hit hard by China's austerity measures, Shanghai Volkswagen has signed an agreement with the Chinese Bank of Industry and Commerce to borrow $27 million to complete its 1990 production plan, the Shanghai newspaper Liberation Daily reported on Thursday. Shanghai Volkswagen, a joint venture of the Shanghai Automobile and Tractor Industries Corporation and Volkswagen A.G.

headline: Macy's Gets A Good Price For 1% Stake
abstract: LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company, in a move dors about the retailer's financial strength, said yesterday that it had sold a 1 percent stake in the company for a price that values its equity at $1.5 billion - about four times what investors paid when the company was taken private four years ago.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   U.N. Said to Be Near Deal For Exit of 6,000 Albanians
abstract: LEAD: A United Nations plan calling for the mass evacuation of an estimated 6,000 Albanians who have taken refuge in foreign embassies is close to being approved by the authorities in Tirana, European diplomats said today.

headline: Judging Shearson's Chairman by His Book Covers
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Kuwait Stance on OPEC
abstract: LEAD: Kuwait's new oil minister, Rashid Salim al-Ameeri, ended talks today in Algiers with OPEC colleagues and said his nation was cutting excess output and could be flexible on its demands for a bigger quota.

headline: From State Pricing to Stoop Labor, Soviet System Dooms a Bumper Crop
abstract: LEAD: When the first reports from the Soviet grain belt reached Moscow early this summer, it seemed that fate had at last chosen to take pity on the famished economy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: 2 Nicaragua Currencies
abstract: LEAD: Two official currencies were in circulation today in Nicaragua, one on par with the United States dollar and the other devalued almost into oblivion. The central bank announced today that it had devalued the old cordoba 7.2 percent, to 690,000 to the dollar from 640,000. Black market dealers offered 740,000 old cordobas for $1.

headline: Export Restrictions Fail to Halt Spread Of Supercomputers
abstract: LEAD: The growing ease with which it is possible to design and build supercomputers is making it increasingly difficult for the United States and Japan to keep the powerful machines from proliferating. That raises the possibility that more nations may be able to use supercomputers to design advanced weapons systems.

headline: ISRAELIS WORRIED BY U.S. RESTRAINT
abstract: LEAD: As the Persian Gulf crisis drags on, Israelis are coming to the conclusion that the United States wants a political solution and is not looking for a military confrontation with Saddam Hussein. That has caused many Israeli politicians, academic experts and ordinary citizens to grow restive, nervous and in some cases angry.

headline: Bush to Revise Proposal to Sell Arms to Saudis
abstract: LEAD: Bowing to Congressional pressure, the White House today modified its plans to sell $21 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia and said it would present the package to Congress in stages, with the largest part deferred until next year.

headline: United Schedule At O'Hare Backed
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court cleared the way for United Airlines to revamp its schedule at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport after Oct. 1. The change, which was challenged by American Airlines, had been approved by the Federal Aviation Administration as a means of smoothing out evening arrivals and departures and easing congestion.

headline: SOME BOAT PEOPLE WILL BE RETURNED
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam, Britain and the United Nations refugee commission have reached an agreement on the repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from camps in Hong Kong.

headline: Eastern Planning Vacation Flights
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines said it would begin special vacation flights during the peak winter travel season to reward frequent business fliers. The airline said that in December it would start special ''Business Break'' flights from Atlanta to Hawaii, Mexico and the Caribbean to serve business fliers fulfilling free travel rewards during peak travel periods.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Close Lower
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices regained some lost ground in afternoon trading here today, after falling to a new trading low for 1990.

headline: Sunbelt-Case Plea Entered
abstract: LEAD: The former chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas pleaded not guilty today to bank-fraud charges stemming from his efforts to finance a $700 million real estate deal in California.

headline: Heinz Net Rises 13.1%
abstract: LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company's first-quarter earnings increased 13.1 percent because of higher food prices and favorable exchange rates for foreign currency, the food maker said today. Heinz posted earnings of $143.2 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter ended Aug. 1, up from $126.6 million, or 48 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1989.

headline: Rates Mixed At Citicorp Sale
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday were mixed, but the average rate on 91-day paper was the highest in more than a month.

headline: New England Bank Weighs Bond Swap
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation is considering an exchange of all or part of its $700 million in bonds, which could reduce the value of its present shareholders' interest in the company, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Mohawk Militants Out Of Canadian Building
abstract: LEAD: Canadian troops armed with bayonets today escorted Mohawk militants out of a building where they were encamped for nearly a month as part of a surrender plan to end a violent land dispute.

headline: Amid Sea of Difficulties, India's Prime Minister Welcomes a Small Victory
abstract: LEAD: As his Indian Air Force jet climbed into a hazy morning sky over the Bay of Bengal, Prime Minister V. P. Singh was relishing a moment of triumph.

headline: NICARAGUA USING A NEW CURRENCY
abstract: LEAD: In the bitterest days of the conflict between this country's former Sandinista leaders and American-backed rebels, all Nicaraguans shared one crucial piece of common ground: their reliance on the American dollar.

headline: Apple Plans System Delay
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would delay by as much as six months the release of its new Macintosh System 7.0 operating system software. This spring the Cupertino, Calif., computer maker told software developers that it expected to release the program by the end of the year.

headline: Resolution Trust Backed
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Resolution Trust Corporation can override Arkansas bank branching laws in approving the sale of a failed savings and loan association.      The 2 to 1 ruling by the

headline: Swissair and Aoki Cancel Hotel Sale
abstract: LEAD: Swissair, Switzerland's national airline, said the planned sale of its Swissotel hotel interests to the Aoki Corporation of Japan had been canceled. The airline cited the uncertainty in world financial markets and the recent strength of the Swiss franc for the joint decision. The sale price, which has not been disclosed, had been in Swiss francs.

headline: East German Pact For Otis Elevator
abstract: LEAD: The Otis Elevator Company has signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in an East German elevator maker. The East German company, Berliner Aufzugs-und Fahrtreppenbau, or B.A.F., is a subsidiary of a Government-owned conglomerate and employs 1,000 workers. The agreement is subject to approval by Government agencies in West Germany and East Germany.

headline: Pirelli Is Rejected
abstract: LEAD: Continental A.G. of West Germany said its supervisory board voted to reject a proposal from Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy to merge the two companies' tire operations under Pirelli's control. Instead, Continental will draft its own proposal to present to Pirelli, a Continental spokesman, Dieter von Herz, said.

headline: Seoul Is Firm on Rice
abstract: LEAD: South Korea will not budge from its refusal to open its market to foreign rice and will keep price controls on rice to protect its farmers, an Agriculture Ministry official said today. He said that Seoul was forced by political pressures to ask for special concessions to keep its rice market closed.

headline: Excerpts From President's News Conference on Meeting With Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today in Kennebunkport, Me.:       OPENING STATEMENT

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Private Lesson on Moscow Potholes
abstract: LEAD: The new governing powers of this abominably potholed city have rebuffed the state's sluggish road workers and hired an aggressive private contractor to repave Moscow's Ring Road as a kind of giant advertisement for can-do capitalism.

headline: Futures Bill Agreement Is Expected
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration is close to agreeing to compromise legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission far less than the broad new authority it had wanted to regulate stock index futures, Congressional aides said tonight.

headline: Across South Africa, Shattering Days of Violence
abstract: LEAD: As South Africa gropes toward negotiations between the white-dominated Government and the black majority, the nation is being torn by some of its worst violence in recent years.

headline: Romanian Leader Is Seeking Fall Visit With Bush
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Petre Roman wants very much to come to Washington this autumn and has let the Bush Administration know of this desire. But so far, the Romanian official has received no positive response.

headline: Company News;   Chrysler Prices To Rise 0.9%
abstract: LEAD: Facing slumping sales and tough competition, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it planned only minimal increases in its average 1991 car prices in an effort to regain market share.

headline: Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program
abstract: LEAD: Each year the United States sends so much grain to Egypt that the farmers feed loaves of bread to their cows.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From TV Interview With Iraqi Official
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview by Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq with Ted Koppel on the ABC News program ''Nightline'' Wednesday, as transcribed by Journal Graphics.

headline: U.S. and Japan Agree On Telecommunications
abstract: LEAD: Japan agreed today to open up its telecommunications market further to foreign companies, meeting an Aug. 1 deadline for possible American retaliation, United States officials said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    The Oil Jolt
