headline: A Casualty of Preparedness for War
abstract: LEAD: Pfc. Gustavo Torres of the 82d Airborne Division, second from left, was helped by comrades after being slightly wounded by a piece of shrapnel from an artillery shell in a live-fire exercise yesterday Saudi Arabia. (Associated Press)

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., to J. Walter Thompson, New York, for their new Medi-Flu flu reliever. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Eastern to Expand First Class Cabins
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, said it was doubling the size of its first class cabins and introducing new fares for business fliers. Eastern's court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., said in a statement that the new rates would be 15 percent and 35 percent lower than full coach rates on other airlines.

headline: Angola, in a Breakthrough, Yields on Relief Issue
abstract: LEAD: In what United States officials are describing as a breakthrough, the Angolan Government has agreed to allow ''the prompt and efficient delivery'' of food supplies to tens of thousands of Angolans who face starvation because of drought.

headline: A Dispute Over Radio Technology
abstract: LEAD: Setting the stage for a contentious regulatory battle over emerging radio technology, the National Association of Broadcasters has asked the Federal Communications Commission to dismiss the application of a company that wants to provide ''digital audio broadcasting,'' or D.A.B., by satellite.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices climbed sharply yesterday, following big jumps for both heating oil and gasoline.

headline: Blackstone Widens Link With Europe
abstract: LEAD: Reflecting Europe's increased importance in the mergers business, the Blackstone Group is forming an alliance with the investment banking unit of Banque Indosuez, a leading financial institution in France, the groups said yesterday.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: A chart last Sunday with the Mutual Funds column, about closed-end funds, misstated the closing price of General American Investors on Dec. 29, 1989. It was 18 1/8, not 8 1/8.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Omnicom Net Rises 16%
abstract: LEAD: The Omnicom Group said second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, to $17.4 million, or 67 cents a share, from $15.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues rose 24 percent, to $298.5 million, from $241.7 million in the 1989 period.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   12 Iraqi Soldiers Reported To Defect to Saudi Arabia
abstract: LEAD: At least 12 Iraqi soldiers defected to Saudi Arabia in tanks that they drove across the border from Kuwait, diplomats said today.

headline: FIGHTING BY NIGHT IS ARMY WAR PLAN
abstract: LEAD: The commander of the United States Army's mechanized forces here said today that if war broke out with Iraq, the United States would try to gain an advantage quickly by fighting at night.

headline: Orthodox in Israel Pressing for a Ban on Pork
abstract: LEAD: Orthodox politicians are trying to outlaw pork, the most unkosher of foods.

headline: I.C.I. Reports Drop in Profits
abstract: LEAD: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said today that its profit dropped 29.6 percent in the second quarter and announced that it was restructuring its fertilizer business.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet-Albanian Ties Restored
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union and Albania have agreed to normalize relations, which were severed in 1961 during Moscow's rift with Beijing, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. The Albanians sided with China in the ideological dispute. The agreement was reached during talks in Bulgaria in June and in Tirana Monday, Tass said.

headline: Suppliers In Loan to Northwest
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines has received a $500 million loan from two of its leading suppliers, Airbus Industrie and the General Electric Company, a spokeswoman for Airbus said yesterday. The loan was arranged by Airbus, the European aerospace consortium, after Northwest agreed to buy an additional 75 of the company's

headline: Baker Will Go to Syria For Help Against Iraqis
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he would go to Syria on Thursday to discuss with President Hafez al-Assad how their countries could cooperate on isolating President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and rolling back his invasion of Kuwait.

headline: Dow Up 8.42, to 2,930.94; Investors Cautious
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices continued to recover yesterday from Monday's huge selloff, but trading volume weakened and investors remained exceptionally cautious in an uncertain market.

headline: KING OF NEPAL GETS NEW CONSTITUTION
abstract: LEAD: King Birendra was officially presented today with the draft of a new national constitution that would preserve his status as chief of state but establish a multiparty democracy, separation of powers and human rights as fundamental elements of Nepal's political system.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Robert M. Austin 2d, an account supervisor, has been given the additional title of vice president at the Martin Agency, Richmond.

headline: No Soccer For NBC
abstract: LEAD: NBC said today that it would not bid for the United States television rights for the 1994 World Cup, the first world soccer championship to be played in the United States.

headline: Judge Picks Japan Routes
abstract: LEAD: An administrative law judge recommended today that five United States airlines be awarded direct routes to Japan from six American cities.

headline: Savings Deal Questioned By Senators
abstract: LEAD: After hearing James M. Fail acknowledge that he made incorrect disclosures to Federal regulators in 1988 when he purchased 15 insolvent savings and loans, members of a Senate panel said today that they were seriously troubled by the deal's inadequate disclosures and questionable finances.

headline: Dow Up 23.26 Points; Week's Rise Is 5.19
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday in the wake of unemployment data showing a weakening economy as investors concentrated on Middle East developments that could give the market a lift on Monday.

headline: Savings Unit Curbs Eased
abstract: LEAD: Savings and loan regulators today temporarily eased restrictions imposed on savings institution lending by last year's bailout bill.      As expected, the Office of

headline: U.S. Says Gulf Moves' Cost Will Far Exceed $25 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The worldwide burden-sharing program for the Persian Gulf operation will require tens of billions of dollars in financial aid to third-world countries, repayment for trade lost in the embargo against Iraq, donations of fuel to American military forces and other contributions, Administration officials said today.

headline: Rioting Follows Funeral of Israeli Teen-Agers
abstract: LEAD: Crowds of Jews attacked Arabs here today to avenge the slayings of two Israeli teen-agers who the authorities say are believed to have been killed by Palestinians.

headline: Campeau Granted Assets Extension
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation said in Toronto that the Edward J. DeBartolo Company, a major American shopping-mall developer, has extended until Aug. 6 a stand-still agreement under which DeBartolo will not seize any Campeau assets without first providing nine days' notice. Campeau, a Canadian developer, owns the Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corporation, two American retail chains.

headline: Buenos Aires Journal;   Where Horatio Alger Heroes Want to Pack It Up
abstract: LEAD: For Yolanda and Alfredo Di Sanso, their 10 years as business owners have been a losing struggle against political instability, runaway inflation, recession and government economic policies that were protectionist one day and free-trade the next.

headline: Matsushita-Tandy Venture Reported
abstract: LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan and the Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth will produce personal computers at a Texas plant under a joint venture, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. The size of the planned investment was not known, the newspaper said.

headline: Britain's Deficit Eases
abstract: LEAD: The British Government on Monday announced a better-than-expected trade deficit for August. The deficit on the current account of the balance of payments, measuring merchandise trade and such invisible factors as banking, insurance and tourism, fell to $:1.13 billion (about $2.1 billion) in August from a revised $:1.68 billion in July.

headline: Bhutto to Face a Judge in Response to Charges of Corruption
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan's ousted Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, said today that she would appear before a tribunal that would decide her political future.

headline: Net Up at Chevron and Mobil as Texaco and Phillips Fall
abstract: LEAD: The Chevron Corporation, helped by steady gasoline prices and demand in the West, where half of its refined products are sold in the United States, continued to outperform most major oil companies in the second quarter, posting a strong profit gain of 60.4 percent.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   Bush, in Freezing Assets, Bars $30 Billion to Hussein
abstract: LEAD: In freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States, President Bush has fenced off an estimated $30 billion from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government analysts say.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Anti-Government Protesters Rally in a Bucharest Square
abstract: LEAD: Scores of anti-Government demonstrators rallied tonight in University Square in the capital's center, the site of a 53-day demonstration that was violently broken up by the police in mid-June.

headline: Long-Term Securities Rebound
abstract: LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly yesterday after the Government's successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds, the last of its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding sales this week.

headline: Heublein Jobs Heading West
abstract: LEAD: The San Francisco agency Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein has a number a new accounts on which to test its creative reputation. The agency has been awarded all but one of Heublein's alcoholic beverages, formerly advertised by Young & Rubicam.      The brands include Jose

headline: Ethics Inquiry Is Sought On Metzenbaum and Staff
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee was asked today to open an inquiry into the conduct of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum and his staff on the Judiciary Committee in their investigation of specific savings and loan deals.

headline: Gandhi Leading in Indian Poll
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh trails former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi as the favorite for India's top post, according to an opinion poll published today. Mr. Singh, who ousted Mr. Gandhi in elections last year, was preferred by 36 percent of the respondents, compared with 44 percent who favored Mr.

headline: EUROPEAN NATIONS PROPOSE GULF AID
abstract: LEAD: The European Community announced today that it would not contribute directly to the cost of the American military presence in the gulf region and would instead give billions of dollars worth of emergency aid to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey and other countries hurt by the Iraqi crisis.

headline: The People Who Are Putting Taste Back on the Table
abstract: LEAD: THE Quaker Oats Company saw boundless potential in the $7 million a year rice-cake business when it bought a small producer in 1985. Supported by the Quaker name and advertising budget, rice-cake sales took off as health-conscious consumers sampled the filling, 35-calorie, fat-free snacks. But then consumers discovered another thing about rice cakes: their taste value was about on a par with styrofoam.

headline: Dow Climbs 32.67, Reversing a 4-Day Slide;   By ROBERT J. COLE
abstract: LEAD: After four down days that toppled the market 118 points, or close to 5 percent, stocks headed up yesterday as traders and investors opened the spigot. Program traders helped spark the rally, but many expect the rise to be short-lived.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From King Fahd's Speech to Saudis
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from a statement by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today, broadcast by Saudi television and translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation:

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       U.N. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW, WORKING GROUP ON       INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: With Care, U.S. Presses Kenyans To Open Their Political Process
abstract: LEAD: A senior American official, in Kenya to patch up ruffled relations, has urged the Government to open up the political process but has been careful not to insist on multiparty democracy as the only prescription.

headline: Saudis Make a Stand
abstract: LEAD: By allowing American troops to land on its territory and increasing its oil production, Saudi Arabia tonight proclaimed what it has been reluctant to say openly for decades: that its interests lie with the West.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Thunder on the Right: U.S. Role in Gulf Splits Longtime Conservative Allies
abstract: LEAD: Amid increasingly bitter invective, a small set of influential conservative newspaper columnists, editorial writers and television commentators has turned away from fighting liberalism and started battling one another over the United States' intervention in the Middle East.

headline: Unit of Nynex Denies Overpayments Charge
abstract: LEAD: Denying charges by New York Attorney General Robert Abrams and others, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday that its review of purchasing practices from 1984 to 1988 had found no evidence of financial improprieties.

headline: World Bank Stressing Environmental Issues
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank, long criticized by conservationists because of the ecological consequences of its programs, today described itself as an enthusiastic and effective convert to the environmental faith.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Those Often-Garbled Statements
abstract: LEAD: If you have a hard time deciphering your mutual fund's account statement, you're in good company. A panel of five industry experts, asked to evalulate 10 statements for this column, gave most of them poor marks.

headline: IRAQIS MASS ON SAUDI FRONTIER; ARABS AGREE TO MEET ON CRISIS; BUSH IS READY TO HELP IF ASKED
abstract: LEAD: Powerful Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia today, while the United States and its allies continued to search, without discernible success, for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait on Thursday.

headline: Henley in a Deal To Sell Itel Shares
abstract: LEAD: Henley Group Inc. said it had reached a pact for the Itel Corporation to buy for cash or be obligated to underwrite 18.7 million Itel shares now held by Henley in a series of deals with a total value of about $375 million. Itel will buy within 30 days about 4.68 million of the shares at $18 each and another 4.68 million shares before the end of 1990 at $19.50 a share.

headline: Junior Partner No More, Gorbachev Raises Role to Major Player in Crisis
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went into the Helsinki summit meeting a junior partner in an international alliance against Iraq, an alliance based on strength and unmistakably led by President Bush.

headline: AIDS Is Not the Only Political Disease
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Israeli Laborites Defer Action on Party Chief
abstract: LEAD: The Labor Party's leadership bureau refused to take any position today on Labor's bruising contest for party leadership and left the party leader, Shimon Peres, and his challenger, Yitzhak Rabin, to continue quarreling for three more weeks.

headline: Coke Income Rose 18.6% In 2d Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its second-quarter profits rose 18.6 percent. The company's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, said he expected continued strong earnings for the rest of 1990 and for 1991.

headline: Significant Losses Continue At S.& L.'s Not Held by U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Savings and loan institutions not under Government control continued to post significant losses in the second quarter of this year, although the declines were less than for the first three months of the year, regulators said today.

headline: Bush's Trade Offer Gets a Warm Latin Reception
abstract: LEAD: When President Bush made his offer to open a free-trade partnership with all of Latin America, President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay jumped to the telephone and said he would accept.

headline: City of Past and Future, Berlin Refashions Itself
abstract: LEAD: When the two German states are joined, probably only nine weeks from now, this sprawling city of over four million people will once again be the capital of a united Germany and more - a great metropolis of Europe and the world.

headline: Several Suspects Detained In Death of a Russian Priest
abstract: LEAD: Several people have been detained on suspicion of killing a prominent Russian Orthodox priest whose death provoked national outrage, the official press agency Tass reported today.

headline: Intergroup In Proxy Loss
abstract: LEAD: National Intergroup Inc. today lost a proxy battle with Centaur Partners L.P. as three Centaur candidates were apparently elected to National Intergroup's 12-member board.

headline: Wall Street;   How the Market Is Treating Energy Stocks
abstract: LEAD: A string of recent earnings disappointments in the energy sector just goes to show how forgiving investors have become in light of the gulf crisis and its positive implications for oil prices.

headline: Sikorsky Venture With Korean Air
abstract: LEAD: Sikorsky Aircraft and Korean Air said they would work together to make Black Hawk helicopters for the Korean Government. The number of helicopters to be produced and the value of the deal were not released.

headline: 9 Killed Near Johannesburg
abstract: LEAD: Nine people were killed and 35 wounded when squatters attacked a hostel for migrant workers in Thokoza township west of Johannesburg, the police said today. Witnesses said the attack on Monday was apparently to avenge the death of a squatter over the weekend. ''We ran helter-skelter and those in their rooms had to jump through windows,'' a hostel resident, Mpumuzi Tshabalala, told the South African Press Association.

headline: Mother Teresa Hopes Nuns In Order Will Go to Albania
abstract: LEAD: Mother Teresa said today that she hoped to send her order's nuns to care for the poor and destitute in Albania, Europe's last bastion of old-style Communism.

headline: Threats and Party Backlash for El Salvador Chief
abstract: LEAD: In the 15 months since his inauguration at the head of a rightist Government, President Alfredo Cristiani has moved moved toward the center of the Salvadoran political spectrum, provoking a backlash from the core of his party that threatens his administration, Western diplomats and Salvadoran politicians say.

headline: 'Micromachine' Project in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Japan plans a multimillion-dollar research project into ''micromachines'' that can travel through blood vessels or look for faults in tiny crevices in jet engines and nuclear power plants, officials said today.      The Ministry of International

headline: Bush Facing Scrutiny by Congress On His Policy in the Persian Gulf
abstract: LEAD: After 25 days of remarkably clear sailing, perhaps unparalleled in a foreign policy crisis in the last quarter-century, President Bush is about to face closer scrutiny from Congress for his policy in the Middle East.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Fed Setback In Bank Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal court in New Orleans denied a request yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board for a rehearing of a case testing the validity of the Fed's power to control the financial affairs of bank holding companies.

headline: Government in Beirut Imposes Siege on Aoun
abstract: LEAD: The pro-Syrian Government of President Elias Hrawi today imposed a siege around areas controlled by Gen. Michel Aoun to force the defiant general to relinquish power in Christian East Beirut.

headline: Caretaker Premier Pledges Investigation of Bhutto
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan's new caretaker Prime Minister, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who took office Monday after the abrupt dismissal of Benazir Bhutto's Government, pledged today to investigate and punish those responsible for what he called ''the worst corruption in Pakistan's history.''

headline: Racial Slur by Japanese Aide Rekindles Anger
abstract: LEAD: A new Japanese Cabinet minister has compared prostitutes in Japan to black Americans who move into white neighborhoods and ''ruin the atmosphere.''

headline: SANCTIONS STARTING TO PINCH IRAQ ECONOMY, U.S. AIDES SAY; U.N.'S DIPLOMACY WELCOMED
abstract: LEAD: Amid tentative new stirrings of diplomatic activity in the Middle East crisis, American officials said today that economic sanctions against Iraq, while already starting to have some effect, will probably not have a decisive impact for months.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    The Oil Jolt

headline: Detroit: America's Best Source of Oil
abstract: LEAD: At least one fact has become inescapably clear during the past two weeks. The world cannot afford a continuation of the steady increase in dependence on Persian Gulf oil. Means are available to reverse this trend. We can make our cars, buildings and industry far more fuel-efficient than they are today.

headline: Treasury Bonds Post More Gains
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates resumed their decline yesterday as prices of Treasury securities rallied on new evidence of a weakening economy.

headline: Is That a Dark Cloud or a Silver Lining for Aluminum?
abstract: LEAD: THE earnings released last week by aluminum producers were, in a word, grim. But the companies appeared unfazed and said profits would start climbing soon.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: McDonnell Stock Climbs on Rumors
abstract: LEAD: The stock of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation moved higher today amid rumors and speculation about the struggling military contractor's future. McDonnell Douglas's shares rose $1.25 each, to $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Boesky and Milken Granted Immunity by House Panel
abstract: LEAD: A House committee voted today to grant the ''junk bond'' financier Michael R. Milken and Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted stock speculator, immunity from additional prosecution in order to get them to testify before Congress.

headline: Iraq Shatters Some Myths About Oil
abstract: LEAD: ''We are frankly puzzled by claims that oil imports from OPEC countries constitute a threat . . . . References to OPEC as a ruthless cartel whose aim is to gain a stranglehold on economies of the West are completely false and misleading . . . . We must all endeavor to create a climate of mutual trust and respect .

headline: Official's Ouster Is Sought at Track
abstract: LEAD: R. D. Hubbard, the chairman of AFG Industries, called for the removal of Marjorie L. Everett as chairman and chief operating officer of the Hollywood Park race track. Mr. Hubbard, who controls 9.9 percent of Hollywood Park Realty Enterprises Inc. and the Hollywood Park Operating Company, the two companies that control the California race track, made the request in a letter dated last Friday to the board of Hollywood Park.

headline: De Klerk and Mandela Agree on Talks
abstract: LEAD: After a three-hour meeting today, President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela indicated that they had overcome a crisis between them and would resume negotiations on the country's future as planned next Monday.

headline: A Testament to Sexism at High-Tech Companies
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Fujitsu Weighs Stake In a Computer Maker
abstract: LEAD: Japan's leading computer company, Fujitsu Ltd., said today that it was considering whether to buy a stake in ICL P.L.C., Britain's sole maker of mainframe computers, in a move that could give the Japanese company a major European foothold.

headline: Amex Plans Expansion to Hawaii
abstract: LEAD: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with an outside group to plan the development of a securities trading operation in Hawaii. The move is intended to give the American Exchange extended hours of trading, as well as increase its reach into Japan and the Pacific

headline: Stotler Settles With S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: Stotler & Company, the bankrupt Chicago-based futures brokerage, today settled Federal charges that it had hidden its financial difficulties from the Securities and Exchange Commission for a seven-month period that culminated with the firm's collapse in late July.

headline: ADDITIONAL TROOPS PROMISED BY EGYPT
abstract: LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak promised Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that he would soon be sending more troops to bolster Saudi Arabia.

headline: Democrats Retreating On Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Democratic leaders pounded the Republicans over the savings and loan scandal today. But the attempt to compel the Attorney General to consider appointing an independent prosecutor in the case of Neil Bush appeared to founder as Republican leaders threatened to retaliate by seeking an outside prosecutor to look into the actions of former Democratic leaders.

headline: Market Place;   Gloomy Prospects Facing Retailers
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE a slight rise in the latest store sales figures, American consumers are likely to remain reluctant shoppers for the rest of this year, according to store executives and industry analysts. And that grim outlook means no end is in sight to the difficulties facing most American retailers and their suppliers.

headline: Social Democrats End A Division of 44 Years
abstract: LEAD: Forty-four years after Germany's Social Democrats were split by the forced merger of the East German part of the party with the Communists, a national congress of the party today declared the restoration of the movement's unity.

headline: Carter Urges Arab Mediator
abstract: LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that military action against Iraq by American forces may be inevitable, but should be undertaken only if no Arab mediator can be found. ''We need to let Saddam know, and let the Arab community know, that we are willing to have a respected mediator explore every possibility for a peaceful settlement,'' Mr.

headline: Envoys at U.N. Say Soviets Block Endorsement of Force Against Iraq
abstract: LEAD: Soviet objections have so far been the main cause of the United States' inability to win Security Council backing for the use of force to uphold the embargo of Iraq, diplomats here say.

headline: Trading Safety for Better Car Mileage
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Golden Nugget
abstract: LEAD: Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc., has lowered his stake in the Las Vegas, Nev., casino concern to 31.1 percent from 32 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Wynn gave no reason for the sale of the shares. Golden Nugget has 16.5 million shares outstanding. Between July 3 and July 11, Mr.

headline: Colombia Reports the Arrest Of Cocaine Cartel Assassin
abstract: LEAD: The Colombian security police said today that they had arrested the chief of assassins for the Medellin cocaine cartel.

headline: U.N. Plan on Cambodia Reported
abstract: LEAD: After eight months of negotiations, the five permanent members of the Security Council agreed today on a proposal for a comprehensive political settlement to end the Cambodian civil war, diplomats said.

headline: Serbia Suspends Government of Albanian Region
abstract: LEAD: The Parliament of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia today suspended the Assembly and the Executive Council of the Kosovo region, which has a 90 percent ethnic Albanian population and has been the scene of ethnic disorders.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * The Food and Drug Administration told toothpaste and mouthwash manufacturers that they must show that their ingredients are safe and effective if they want to claim on labels that their products prevent plaque. If safety cannot be substantiated with scientific data, makers will have to remove claims from the labels.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Hoya Museum Crystal to Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, San Francisco. The account had been with Cadwell Davis Partners, New York.

headline: Salomon Unit to Limit Commodities Trading
abstract: LEAD: The commodities unit of Salomon Inc. will stop its trading in coffee, sugar and rice as part of significant cutbacks in the division, an internal company memorandum told employees yesterday.

headline: U.N. Seeks Wider Embargo In Vote Assailing Iraqi Acts
abstract: LEAD: The Security Council unanimously condemned Baghdad early today for acts of violence against foreign embassies and their personnel in occupied Kuwait and promised new, unspecified steps to tighten the mandatory trade embargo against Iraq.

headline: U.S. Banks Cut Global Business As Rivals Grow
abstract: LEAD: Once the pacesetters for global expansion in the financial industry, American banks are retreating from foreign markets, losing business and stature to competitors from Europe and Japan.

headline: Japan Stocks Fall Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Tokyo stock prices tumbled more than 5 percent today on the widespread selling of long cash-index positions by futures arbitragers before regaining nearly a percentage point. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent, to close at 26,176.43.

headline: Proposal to Sell Shares in El Al
abstract: LEAD: Two United States investment banks have advised Israel to sell 51 percent of the state-owned national airline, El Al, the Transport Ministry said today.

headline: A British Official, Stirring Outcry, Says Germans Are Taking Over
abstract: LEAD: A senior British

headline: Bush Gives Approval To TV Aimed at Cuba
abstract: LEAD: President Bush said today the Voice of America television station aimed at Cuban viewers has passed a five-month preliminary test and will become a permanent operation.

headline: Venture Ties Acer And Smith Corona
abstract: LEAD: The Smith Corona Corporation and the Acer America Corporation formed a joint venture to develop and market personal computers for the consumer, home-office and small-business markets. The products will be sold under a new Smith Corona/Acer brand name and will operate using the MS-DOS software common to the International Business Machines

headline: Long-Term U.S. Bonds Tumble
abstract: LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday, sending interest rates up, after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The invasion raised the specter of a resurgence of oil-fueled inflation, which would undermine the values of bonds and other fixed-income securities.

headline: Bid for Allegheny Close to Approval
abstract: LEAD: A bankruptcy judge said today that he expected to sign an order clearing the way for Japonica Partners, an investment group, to take control of Allegheny International Inc., an appliance manufacturer. Judge Joseph Cosetti said he planned to sign the order by Friday.

headline: Foreign Securities Proposal
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved for public comment a new rule that would allow foreign banks and insurance companies to offer their stock and debt securities to American investors.

headline: Electrolux Plans To Lay Off 15,000
abstract: LEAD: Electrolux A.B., the Swedish appliance company, said it would cut 15,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, over the next two years to bolster falling profits. The company made the announcement as it reported that profits in the first half of the year fell to $175 million from $346 million in the 1989 period.

headline: Alaska Pipeline Reaches Accord
abstract: LEAD: The operator of the trans-Alaska pipeline, which carries a quarter of the nation's domestically produced oil, has reached an agreement with state officials on measures to cut air pollution, ending a threat that the pipeline would be shut down. the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the consortium of seven oil companies that operates the 800-mile pipeline, had threatened to cut off an important source of oil as a deadline approached for compliance with an Environmental Protection Agency order.

headline: Two Koreas Sign Pact For High-Level Visits
abstract: LEAD: North and South Korea signed an agreement today for an exchange of visits this year by their Prime Ministers.

headline: Conagra Finishes Deal for Beatrice
abstract: LEAD: Conagra Inc. became one of the world's largest food companies when it completed its $1.34 billion acquisition of the Beatrice Company. The deal, completed Tuesday, unites some of the country's best-known food brands: Beatrice makes Peter Pan peanut butter, Hunt's and Wesson condiments and oils, and Conagra makes Banquet, Armour and Chun King foods.

headline: Congress Is Close to Regulating Price of Basic Cable TV Service
abstract: LEAD: Pressed by widespread public anger over steep rate increases for cable television service, Congress is close to imposing modest controls over prices. But disputes over proposals aimed at fostering competition could derail the legislation and leave the industry a winner by default.

headline: Washington Calls on U.N. To Impose Boycott on Iraq
abstract: LEAD: The United States asked other members of the Security Council today to endorse its proposal for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq and occupied Kuwait until Baghdad agrees to withdraw its military forces from Kuwait.

headline: U.S. to Challenge P.&G.-Rorer Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said the Justice Department had decided to challenge their agreement to form a strategic alliance. The companies said they disagreed with the Government's stance and were considering their options.

headline: Surprise! VCR to Beat Was Born in the U.S.A.
abstract: LEAD: A tiny Arizona company has begun to market a new generation of videocassette recorder that could re-establish an American presence in consumer electronics, an industry dominated by Far East producers for the last 20 years.

headline: Wall Street Shrugs Off Tax Threat
abstract: LEAD: Are higher taxes just what the economy, and the stock market, need? Wall Street seems to think so.

headline: An Uneasy Alliance Is Born For Mitsubishi and Daimler
abstract: LEAD: Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz said today that they were exploring several joint ventures, including making cars in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, producing computer chips, jet airplanes, high-speed trains and refrigerators.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   U.S. ACTS TO RAISE MIDEAST STRENGTH
abstract: LEAD: The United States moved today to increase its naval forces in the Middle East for a possible blockade to enforce the United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq, and other Western officials indicated that they were prepared to join in such an action if it was necessary.

headline: RJR Move Helps Lift 'Junk Bonds'
abstract: LEAD: Word that the RJR Holdings Corporation has begun a $6.9 billion refinancing program for RJR Nabisco served as a long-awaited tonic to the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' yesterday, and prices of most issues posted strong gains in heavy trading.

headline: American Brands in Deal for Moen
abstract: LEAD: American Brands Inc., a consumer products company that has been adding to its non-tobacco businesses, said yesterday that it would buy the Moen Group Inc., a plumbing manufacturer, from Forstmann Little & Company for $975 million.

headline: Kuwaiti Bank Serves An Economy in Exile
abstract: LEAD: Five weeks after the Iraqis invaded Kuwait, the National Bank of Kuwait is up and running from its transplanted headquarters here, the only one of the occupied emirate's big banks that is back in business.

headline: FLOW OF TOURISTS SHIFTS IN HUNGARY
abstract: LEAD: It was a year ago that a tide of East Germans, many of them here on vacation, began moving through Hungary to the West, touching off the revolutions that swept Eastern Europe.

headline: RESTAURANTS: DALLAS;  Mealtime, Dealtime
abstract: LEAD: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs.

headline: 'Micro Bankers' Help The Poor Make Money
abstract: LEAD: Several nonprofit ''micro banks'' have flourished in North America, using an approach that most banks would consider absurd: they make small loans to potential business owners who live in poverty.

headline: Europeans Agree to Expel Baghdad Military Attaches
abstract: LEAD: Anxious to display a united stance on the Persian Gulf crisis, the 12-nation European Community agreed today to expel Iraq's military attaches from the region in retaliation for ''new and very serious illegal acts'' committed by Iraq in its raid on four Western embassies in Kuwait on Friday.

headline: Reader's Digest Fills New Post
abstract: LEAD: Reader's Digest yesterday named Richard D. Wright to the new position of associate publisher-sales development and said that it was eliminating about 25 jobs in its advertising sales organization.

headline: Patents;   Tire Pressure Gauge Is Mounted in Hubcap
abstract: LEAD: James Jard, a commercial real estate broker in Virginia Beach, Va., has patented a tire pressure gauge mounted into automobile hubcaps.

headline: NATO's Cousin Organization Will Meet on Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Amid criticism that they have not yet developed a coherent response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, key Western European governments are to meet here Tuesday under the auspices of a little-known defense organization that has long been overshadowed by NATO.

headline: Ending Feud, India's Leader Dismisses Powerful Deputy
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh dismissed his powerful deputy today for making unsubstantiated charges of corruption against other members of the Cabinet, Indian news agencies said.

headline: Mortgage Rates Down
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.19 percent this week, down from 10.24 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.29 percent, down from 8.30 percent last week.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   East German Coalition Finds Accord on Election Formula
abstract: LEAD: The East German Social Democrats decided today not to leave the coalition with Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and the Christian Democrats after an all-German parliamentary committee found a compromise for holding all-German elections on Dec. 2.

headline: Banks Challenging American Express
abstract: LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation and Barclays Bank P.L.C. said they would combine their traveler's check operations, mounting an increased challenge to the American Express Company, the industry leader. BankAmerica's traveler's check operation will become part of Interpayment Services Ltd., a company set up by the London-based Barclays last year.

headline: Dart Drug Stores Set to Liquidate
abstract: LEAD: Dart Drug Stores Inc., which operates Fantle's drugstores, announced it would liquidate because the company had been unable to develop a plan acceptable to creditors that would allow it to remain in business. The company said it would start a going-out-of-business sale as soon as it obtained bankruptcy court approval and completed inventories.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 4, 1990:       TUESDAY       Albertsons Inc.    Cincinnati Bell    Davis Wtr & Waste    Premier Indl Corp.       WEDNESDAY       Browning-Ferris Inds    First UN Real Estate    Handleman Co.    Helmerich & Payne    LG&E Energy Corp.    Louisville Gas & Elec.

headline: Where Price-Cutting Causes Pain
abstract: LEAD: The growling of lawn mowers, that ubiquitous sound of suburban summers, is music to the ears of executives at the Briggs & Stratton Corporation, the world's largest maker of lawn mower engines. Briggs engines made here have been the heart of American mowers for generations.

headline: Ozone Action by Japan
abstract: LEAD: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry said on Wednesday that it was increasing financial help to industries that must limit the use of substances that damage the earth's ozone layer. Ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons are to be phased out by the year 2000 and methyl chloroform by 2005 under an international agreement known as the Montreal Protocol.

headline: 3 in Baghdad Tightly Knit In Iron Rule
abstract: LEAD: The reins of power in Iraq are in the grip of three men in their mid-50's who in 22 years in office have turned their country into a force of formidable military might in the Middle East.

headline: Poland's Elections Threaten to Jeopardize Change
abstract: LEAD: Poland, tired but exhilarated after 14 months of a Solidarity Government, is bracing for a presidential election campaign that threatens to divide the nation and jeopardize economic and political change.

headline: MARKET WATCH
abstract: LEAD: When words don't persuade, a gun can help.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY
abstract: LEAD:   THE ECONOMY    More Pressure on Banks

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Insolvent Bank Bought Cheaply With Help of Former Bush Aide
abstract: LEAD: The Arizona businessman who secured $1.85 billion in Federal savings and loan subsidies with lobbying help from a former aide to President Bush was also able to buy an insolvent Oklahoma bank at a favorable price despite his failure to meet Federal standards for such purchases.

headline: Westair Merger
abstract: LEAD: Westair Holding Inc. said it would merge its two regional airline subsidiaries to cut costs. The company said that after merging its NPA Inc. and Westair Airlines subsidiaires, it would lay off up to 75 people from its administrative staff. NPA and Westair Airlines will function as two operating divisions of the same company.

headline: G.M. Sets Incentive Offer On Many of Its 1991 Models
abstract: LEAD: In a move that analysts said amounted to a concession that its new cars and trucks may be priced too high in a soft market, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was offering incentives on many of its 1991 models, including several that go on sale this month for the first time.

headline: S.A.S.-Lorenzo Sale Backed
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department said today that it would allow the Scandinavian Airlines System to buy out most of Frank Lorenzo's interest in Continental Airlines Holdings Inc.

headline: Hospitals Battling Specialists Over Revenues From Testing
abstract: LEAD: Squeezed by Government and employer efforts to reduce costs, many hospitals are battling with specialist physicians over the revenues generated by advanced testing equipment and life-support machines. Some of the fights over these lucrative procedures are ending up in court.

headline: Identity Crisis for 'Seven Sisters'
abstract: LEAD: In magazines as in life, being known as someone's sister can be a badge of pride - or a real drag.

headline: Europe's Jobless Rate
abstract: LEAD: Unemployment in the 12-nation European Community remained steady at 8.6 percent in July, the European statistical office said today. The rate has not changed since March. The statistics office said unemployment fell four-tenths of 1 percent in Spain and one-tenth of 1 percent in Portugal.

headline: Treasury Prices Continue to Fall
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities continued to drop and interest rates continued to climb yesterday, reversing their morning course, as an uncommonly volatile fixed-income market was buffeted by conflicting reports and rumors about the Mideast crisis.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   East German Unions Trying to Be Eastern Europe's Strongest
abstract: LEAD: After decades of docile behavior under the old Communist Government, East Germany's trade unions are flexing their muscles this week to make sure that workers' interests are not brushed aside as the nation rushes toward a free-market economy.

headline: All Transportation Is Subsidized
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Remarks on Economic Change
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarks at the Soviet Parliament today on the nation's economic crisis, as translated by The New York Times:

headline: Bond Quits Top Post
abstract: LEAD: The financier Alan Bond resigned today as chairman and director of Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., which has fallen victim to financial problems stemming from a heavy debt load.

headline: Oil Soars To $34.71 A Barrel
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil, gasoline and heating oil prices all leaped in late futures trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Earnings Forecast Is Revised at Saab
abstract: LEAD: The president of Saab Automobile A.B. said he was unsure if the Swedish auto maker would break even by the end of next year, contrary to an earlier statement. ''I regret that statement,'' David Herman said in an interview. ''I don't know if it will come true.'' Mr. Herman made the statement shortly after joining

headline: Iran, Holding Key, Hints at Hostage Release
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait may have indirectly improved the chances of freeing American hostages long held in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

headline: Bush's Gamble in Sending Troops: Stakes Are Certain, Outcome Murky
abstract: LEAD: By sending combat troops into Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved decisively today to defend fundamental American economic interests, but he also tied the United States and his own fortunes to a potentially explosive crisis with no clear outcome in sight.      The stakes behind the

headline: New Office for Warner
abstract: LEAD: Warner Brothers Inc. has agreed to move its film, television, comic book and licensing divisions from 75 Rockefeller Center to 140,000 square feet of office space at 1325 Avenue of the Americas. The new 35-story tower, which Warner will move into next spring, was developed by Edward J. Minskoff Equities Inc.

headline: No Payments to Douglas
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that the Air Force had suspended payments in July for the company's work on the C-17 transport plane, pending the completion of a review of the program's cost.

headline: Indecision and Mistakes Hamper Relief Efforts at Camps in Jordan
abstract: LEAD: When a giant Soviet AN-124 cargo jet landed here at midnight on Thursday, United Nations officials supervised the unloading of 50 tons of American-bought rice that had been flown from Bangladesh to help feed tens of thousands of Asian refugees from Kuwait in Jordan's desert transit camps.

headline: Time Warner Reports A Loss of $189 Million
abstract: LEAD: Time Warner Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $189 million for the second quarter. If Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. had been merged at this time last year, the company would have reported a comparable loss. The company's revenues for the quarter rose by 4.4 percent, to $2.58 billion, from $2.47 billion in the previous quarter.

headline: Eastern Can Trim Pilots' Pay
abstract: LEAD: In a ruling that gives Eastern Airlines some financial relief, a Federal Bankruptcy Court said yesterday that the beleaguered carrier could impose temporary wage and benefits cuts on pilots. At the same time, the airline reported a $35.6 million loss for the second quarter, an improvement from the period a year earlier.

headline: Soviet Oil Output Declines
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union's crude oil output, the largest in the world, fell sharply in the first eight months of the year and the decline is accelerating, the First Deputy Prime Minister, Lev Voronin, said today.

headline: Novelty in Leipzig: A Paper With No Party Line
abstract: LEAD: This is the time to be an entrepreneur in Eastern Europe, in newspaper publishing as in any other business. But at East Germany's largest independent weekly, youth and steady nerves are the most important assets.

headline: Saudis Widen Military Recruiting And Encourage Women to Work
abstract: LEAD: In a sweeping directive apparently intended to mobilize Saudi society for possible war with Iraq, King Fahd has ordered the expansion of the armed forces and has called for wider participation of women in the labor force.

headline: Canada Sets Oil Project
abstract: LEAD: Canada's largest offshore oil drilling project has been approved, and construction is expected to begin almost immediately, Energy Minister Jake Epp announced today.

headline: Panel Says Ex-Bush Aide Claimed Millions From a Savings Unit Deal
abstract: LEAD: A lobbyist who helped investors buy troubled savings institutions claimed to be entitled to a multimillion-dollar share in a deal providing $1.85 billion in Federal subsidies to one client, a Senate committee disclosed today.

headline: A.T.&T.'s New Card Stirs Strong Response
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that the pace at which it distributed its new A.T.&T. Universal card, a combination calling card and general purpose credit card, had accelerated sharply this summer.

headline: 31 Dead as Soweto Clashes Continue
abstract: LEAD: Fighting between rival black factions swirled through parts of Soweto for a second successive day today as the leaders of major black groups failed to agree on the date and location of a meeting to settle their differences.

headline: 'Pretty Woman' Finds Best Friend in Profits
abstract: LEAD: The romantic comedy ''Pretty Woman,'' released in the movie industry's off season, could well become the highest-grossing film this year.

headline: Ringling Brothers Plans Retail Chain
abstract: LEAD: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus said it would start a national chain of retail stores with a circus theme this fall. The company, owned by Irwin Feld and Kenneth Feld Productions, Vienna, Va., said it would open six stores a year, with the first scheduled for late October in the Fair Oaks Mall in Fairfax, Va.

headline: Cartier Sues On Imitations
abstract: LEAD: The French fashion house Cartier, saying its image was being ruined by imitations of its luxury merchandise, took eight Indonesian companies to court today.

headline: Zurich Journal;   A Marketplace for Drugs, a Bazaar of the Bizarre
abstract: LEAD: In an oak-shaded park a few hundred yards from Zurich's stately banks and elegant shops, a man named Sylvio carefully worked a hypodermic needle into a vein in his neck, then slowly injected a mixture of heroin and cocaine.

headline: Jordan Port Falls Still And Its Leaders Seethe
abstract: LEAD: The streets seem virtually deserted, the hotels are empty, most of the port structures lie still and more than 80 percent of the 11,000-strong tractor-trailor fleet sits parked and silent.

headline: U.N. Chief's Talk With Iraqi Breaks Off Inconclusively
abstract: LEAD: Talks aimed at persuading Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait broke off inconclusively tonight when Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, flew back to Baghdad after six and a half hours of discussions over two days with Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations.

headline: Buyout Unit Finds Banks In UAL Deal
abstract: LEAD: One month before a deadline for financing a $4.38 billion acquisition of the UAL Corporation, the employee buyout group has enlisted the tentative financial support of five major banks, according to United's unions and bank officials. But none of the banks have signed agreements to provide loans, and several obstacles remain to be overcome before the Aug.

headline: New Leader Of Anglicans: George Leonard Carey
abstract: LEAD: Bishop George Carey, a bishop for less than three years, was named today as the next Archbishop of Canterbury, spiritual head of the Church of England and 70 million Anglicans around the world.

headline: Fannie Mae Offers $300 Million Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced an off-calendar issue of debentures totaling $300 million through various securities dealers.

headline: An Investment Banker Moves to Brick Making
abstract: LEAD: Philip R. Mengel, an investment banker, is moving from an abstract business to a concrete one, and from New York City to Reading, Pa., where the company he will head makes concrete products, bricks and other building materials.

headline: 4 Traders Are Charged
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission charged today that four traders on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange engaged in a conspiracy to use their advance knowledge of customer orders to make illegal profits.

headline: China Finds a Han Tomb and 'Men of Mud'
abstract: LEAD: Workers building a road in central China appear to have stumbled on an archeological treasure: a 2,100-year-old network of underground vaults said to contain tens of thousands of terra-cotta sculptures buried with a Han Dynasty emperor, during one of the greatest civilizations of ancient times.

headline: Chief and Two Associates Are Leaving Hachette Unit
abstract: LEAD: Hachette Publications o f France announced the departure yesterday of Peter Diamandis, chairman and chief executive of Diamandis Communications, Hachette's United States magazine group and the publisher of Memories and Woman's Day. The development is part of a wide-reaching management shakeup at the company.

headline: Renault Rethinks Mack Trucks Bid
abstract: LEAD: Renault S.A., the French state-owned automobile maker, is reconsidering its $6-a-share offer for all remaining shares of Mack Trucks Inc. because of the company's revised forecast of losses for the year. The shares of Mack Trucks fell by $1.125 each today, to $5.25, in over-the-counter trading.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Arab League's Top Officer Quits Over Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Chedli Klibi, the Secretary General of the Arab League for more than 10 years, resigned today because of the Persian Gulf crisis, Arab diplomats said.

headline: Johnson Controls
abstract: LEAD: Johnson Controls Inc. hired Salomon Inc. to advise it of alternatives to maintaining ownership of the company's battery group. The company said the options to be considered included forming strategic partnerships to position the battery group better in the global market and selling all or part of the business.

headline: Accounting Board in Draft Of Nonprofit Group Rules
abstract: LEAD: The rule-making body for the accounting profession decided yesterday to issue for public comment proposed rules that would for the first time require nonprofit institutions like museums and churches to put certain contributions, like works of art and volunteer labor, on their books.

headline: Earthquake in the Philippines Kills at Least 258, Including 48 Children in One School
abstract: LEAD: A major earthquake registering 7.7 on the Richter scale killed at least 258 people on Monday on the main island of the Philippines, including 48 children whose school collapsed and 210 others caught in stampedes or in falling buildings, officials said.

headline: Thai Prime Minister Shakes Up His Cabinet
abstract: LEAD: After persistent accusations of corruption within his ruling coalition, the Thai Prime Minister shuffled his Cabinet today, replacing the country's longtime Foreign Minister and bringing in some well-known technocrats.

headline: U.N. CHIEF SAYS HIS TALKS FAILED AND LOOKS TO U.S.-SOVIET EFFORT
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that two days of talks here with the Iraqi Foreign Minister had failed to produce any concessions from Baghdad on its occupation of Kuwait or on the policy of holding an estimated 10,000 Westerners as hostages.

headline: Iraq Seen Looting Kuwait of Identity
abstract: LEAD: Having physically denuded Kuwait in nearly two months of military rule, looting computers, amusement-park rides and even street lamps and school blackboards, Iraq has embarked on a systematic effort to strip the nation of its very identity, exiled Kuwaitis and other recent refugees say.

headline: Burmese Military Cracking Down Again <
abstract: LEAD: The military Government of Myanmar has increased its forces in major cities after killing four demonstrators last week in Mandalay, Western diplomats in the capital, Yangon, said in telephone interviews Friday and today.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Excerpts From Speech by Yeltsin Before 28th Party Congress
abstract: LEAD: The following excerpts are from a speech before the Communist Party congress by Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic and a leader of the congress's insurgent minority, as translated by The New York Times.

headline: Some Soviet Items Aren't Scarce: Crime, Strikes, Fighting, Pollution
abstract: LEAD: The cracks in Soviet society are so visible these days that they have become part of the landscape like the gaping ruts that line Moscow's streets.

headline: USX Appoints Steel Unit Head
abstract: LEAD: Thomas J. Usher was promoted from executive vice president of the USX Corporation's heavy products division to president of its steel division, USS.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Dow Up 9.16, to 2,914.11, in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Stocks seesawed yesterday in persistent computer-assisted buying and selling programs before advancing slightly in light trading.

headline: Prices Up 20% In Argentina
abstract: LEAD: Argentine shopkeepers have pushed up food and drink prices by as much as 20 percent in the last few days after a fresh round of Government-imposed gasoline and utility increases, according to figures released today.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Czech Embassy Shelters Cubans
abstract: LEAD: Two Cuban students seeking political asylum and five dissidents asking to tour Europe and return were staying in the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana today, presenting Cuba and non-Communist Czechoslovakia with a tricky diplomatic problem.

headline: Needham Promotions
abstract: LEAD: DDB Needham promoted 10 employees to senior vice presidencies: Lauren Berger, Peter Gardiner, Judith Goldstein, Bob Huff, Alan Krinsky, Paul Manganiello, Carmine Marino, Joan Niborg, Steven Werby and David Wismer. The agency also named Gary Leeds treasurer.

headline: Haiti, Easing Uncertainty, Plans Elections Dec. 16
abstract: LEAD: After months of political uncertainty deepened by the recent return from exile of two widely feared figures of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship, Haitian electoral officials have announced plans to hold national elections in December.

headline: Santa Fe Subsidiary Offers $218.9 Million in Debentures
abstract: LEAD: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, the Chicago-based transportation, natural resources and real estate holding company, and its Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners L. P., which operates pipeline distribution of refined petroleum products, jointly announced the offering yesterday of $218.9 million in debentures by SFP Pipeline

headline: Syrians and Lebanon Allies Deploy Against Aoun
abstract: LEAD: Syrian troops and Lebanese soldiers loyal to President Elias Hrawi were deployed today around the gateways into the capital area's Christian enclave amid reports that an offensive to crush the rival Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, was imminent.

headline: Baghdad Rages at 'Foreigner' But Middle East Backs Away
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq remained unrepentant in the face of growing pressure today, saying in a speech that ''Iraq will firmly confront any imperialist or Zionist attempt from any side that may stand against Kuwait's uprising or infringe on Arab dignity and land.''

headline: U.S. Reports 0.4% July Gain In Construction Spending
abstract: LEAD: Construction spending edged up four-tenths of a percent in July for its first gain in four months, the Government said today. But analysts expect the industry to be weak the rest of the year.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Keith Evans has been named vice president and art director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, New York. Ron Henderson has joined the agency as vice president and copywriter.

headline: Iran-Iraq Talks Produce Progress On Ending Long Confrontation
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Iran today held their first direct talks since their 1988 cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. The talks could open the way to a summit meeting between Presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and the negotiation of a peace treaty to end 10 years of hostility.

headline: The Media Business;   New England Monthly Closes
abstract: LEAD: New England Monthly, a six-year-old regional magazine that has won two National Magazine Awards, will cease publication with its September issue.

headline: Mall Building Has Slowed
abstract: LEAD: Reflecting a cutback in lending by commercial banks, the number of new shopping-center starts in the United States fell sharply in the first half of 1990, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group based in New York.

headline: On Tapping Oil Reserve
abstract: LEAD: Key members of Congress, as well as many energy economists, are dismayed by the Bush Administration's reluctance to counter the last week's run-up in oil prices by selling stocks from the Government-owned Strategic Petroleum Reserve.      Although President

headline: Profits Off By 15.9% At Banks
abstract: LEAD: Mounting problems with real estate loans along much of the East Coast cut profits of the nation's commercial banks to $5.3 billion in the second quarter, 15.9 percent below those of the first three months of the year, the Government reported today.

headline: Soviets Urging U.N. Council To Back Iraq Air Embargo
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union is asking members of the United Nations Security Council to send their foreign ministers to a Council meeting next week to approve a plan tightening sanctions against Iraq and occupied Kuwait by imposing an embargo on air traffic there and seizing their merchant shipping, diplomats said today.

headline: Builders End Club in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Top executives of leading Japanese building companies have disbanded a social club in an effort to meet United States demands for an end to bid rigging in the construction industry, company spokesmen said today. The 32-member club had met monthly since 1983 at breakfasts, golf competitions and other activities.

headline: The Networks' New Advertising Dance
abstract: LEAD: Viewers of the new television series ''Northern Exposure'' on CBS Thursday evening could hardly miss the striking scenery and the quirky mooseburger meals depicted in the saga of a young New York doctor acclimating to a rugged Alaskan town.

headline: NCNB and Meridian Hurt by Bad Loans
abstract: LEAD: The NCNB Corporation and Meridian Bancorp yesterday joined a growing list of banking companies admitting that problems with real estate loans would hurt earnings in the third quarter.

headline: Stocks Outperform Expectations
abstract: LEAD: The performance of stocks in the second quarter turned out to be less gloomy than many financial analysts had predicted. In spite of sluggishness in the economy, many financial analysts said the market's performance had exceeded expectations.

headline: Newsweek and Times Mirror Set Ad Pact
abstract: LEAD: In a new twist on group advertising promotions offered by magazines, Newsweek and Times Mirror Magazines announced yesterday that they would team up to offer special joint advertising discounts and promotional deals for advertisers in their magazines. It is the first time that two separately owned magazine companies have joined forces in this way.

headline: Changes in China Offer Lessons for East Europe
abstract: LEAD: When China specialists think about how Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union can reorganize their economies, they tend to agree on one point: transforming socialist countries into market competitors will be a far more complex and painful task than is often acknowledged.

headline: Company News;   Prime Inns
abstract: LEAD: Prime Motor Inns Inc. said it expects a substantial after-tax loss for the fiscal year that ended Saturday because it is establishing additional reserves and writing down assets. It said the amount of the reserves and adjustments would be $150 million, of which $80 million was related to its investment in certain securities of Servico Inc.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., said it reached an intellectual-property-rights agreement with Outbound Systems Inc. that will allow Outbound to continue to offer its products. Details were not disclosed.

headline: Poll Says Young Watch Less TV Than Thought
abstract: LEAD: Some young Americans watch far less television than advertisers might hope, according to a survey conducted for Archie Comic Publications Inc. by Mark Clements Inc., an independent research company.

headline: Bond Markets Worried by Fall of Dollar
abstract: LEAD: The recent decline in the dollar, which has received at least tacit approval from the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department, is a source of growing concern to credit market participants.

headline: Senate Is Expected to Back New Term for Futures Head
abstract: LEAD: After a Senate hearing tonight, Wendy Lee Gramm, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, was expected to be reconfirmed for another five-year term.

headline: Businessland Cuts Staff 10%
abstract: LEAD: Businessland Inc., the nation's biggest computer retailer, said today that it was cutting its worldwide staff by 10 percent and shrinking operations in an effort to turn the ailing company around.

headline: In Zambia, Anger Over the Economy
abstract: LEAD: In riots here last week, residents of Mutendere Township, a dusty place of dirt roads and shabby housing, burned the flag of the nation's sole political party.

headline: Wall Street;   The Zero-Coupon Twist to the Old Convertible Bond
abstract: LEAD: THE market got news last week of two new pending issues of LYONS, one of the trademarked borrowing gimmicks from Merrill Lynch. A LYON, or Liquid Yield Option Note, is Merrill's zero-coupon twist on the old-fashioned convertible bond. Issued at a big discount from its value at maturity, a corporation's LYON gives the buyer the right to convert the bond into a fixed number of the company's shares, or an equal sum of cash, at the company's option.

headline: Retirement At Northrop
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that Thomas V. Jones, its longtime chairman, had retired and had been succeeded by Kent Kresa, the president and chief executive.

headline: Real Estate;  The Growth Of Specialty Buildings
abstract: LEAD: BETTING that tenants want to rub elbows with others in the same business, several Manhattan building owners are responding to the sluggish real estate market by creating specialty office centers aimed at specific industries.

headline: Bribe Charges Backed As Northrop Era Ends
abstract: LEAD: Thomas V. Jones survived a foreign bribery scandal at the Northrop Corporation in the 1970's and went on to build the company into one of the nation's largest military contractors. Now he is retiring as chairman amid allegations that he may have presided over the payment of bribes by Northrop in the 1980's in an effort to sell a fighter jet in South

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.N. Council Declares Void Iraqi Annexation of Kuwait
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to declare Iraq's formal annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Busch Spots Fight Rise In Beer Tax
abstract: LEAD: ONE of the newest campaigns from Anheuser-Busch is steeped in ''America the beautiful'' sentiment, with shots of farmers walking through their fields and working men at lunch, as an announcer explains how the country was built by people willing to give their fair share.

headline: Market Place;   A Short, Sad Tale Of In-Store Inc.
abstract: LEAD: THE story of In-Store Advertising Inc. as a publicly held company is now six weeks old, but to many buyers it probably seems much longer.

headline: Mideast Anxiety Jolts the Markets
abstract: LEAD: Stocks took one of their biggest tumbles of the year yesterday amid widespread anxiety and uncertainty about the Middle East, but the close showed a solid recovery from the far lower levels earlier in the day.

headline: Group Withdraws Offer for Talman
abstract: LEAD: An investor group dropped its $700 million offer for the Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Illinois, the state's largest savings institution. Talman said in a statement that a Chicago-area banker, Harrison I. Steans, leader of the investment group, had abandoned the buyout because the savings and loan association's revised earnings projections fell below his original expectations.

headline: Business and Health;   Programs to Keep Retirees Healthy
abstract: LEAD: AT the Campbell Soup Company's fitness center in Camden, N.J., Bill Brown, a 79-year-old retiree, leads an exercise class called flexibility.

headline: Challenge To Microsoft Advancing
abstract: LEAD: The effort to challenge the domination of the Microsoft Corporation's software that allows desktop computers to operate popular programs like word processors and spreadsheets gained momentum yesterday as three companies agreed on a single standard for the rival Unix software.

headline: Lahore Journal;   After the Big Cleanup, a City Worthy of Its Poets
abstract: LEAD: Above the cacophony of the bazaars and byways in this lively old city, new sounds are being heard these days: the rumble and clank of bulldozers on a rescue mission.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Canadian Airlines to Chiat/Day/ Mojo, Toronto, with a budget of $25 million.

headline: Chung Hyun Ri Journal;   Korean Spat: It's a Wall! No It Isn't! Is Too! Is Not!
abstract: LEAD: Amid the layers on layers of defenses leading up to the edge of the demilitarized zone, it is easy to miss one more, added almost as an afterthought 12 years ago: a steep grassy slope, topped with barbed wire, that falls off into a 20-mile cliff of cement facing North Korea.

headline: Ford Shutdowns
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it plans to close two assembly plants for one week beginning Sept. 10 because of a shortage of dealer orders for the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz cars made at the plants. Sales of the Topaz are off 21.9 percent so far this year compared with 1989, while sales of the nearly identical Tempo have fallen 1.5 percent in 1990.

headline: Mauthausen Journal;   At a Death Camp, Gypsies Confront Indifference
abstract: LEAD: The delegation of gypsies had come to the site of the Nazi concentration camp at Mauthausen to look for a part of their history, one that has been less examined and less lamented than the fate of other peoples in World War II.

headline: Ford Plant for Hungary
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to spend $60 million to $70 million to build an auto-parts plant in Hungary, the state news agency said Friday. The plant, which would also import Ford cars to Hungary, would be built southwest of Budapest, it said. Ford plans to manufacture ignition coils and electronic fuel pumps at the plant.

headline: Economic Scene;   Baby Boomers' Free Lunch?
abstract: LEAD: EVERYONE knows that America's rapidly aging baby boomers are burning the candle at both ends, consuming when they should be saving for retirement. Everyone also knows the boomers are depending on the rapid accumulation of cash in the Social Security trust fund to save their bacon.

headline: Punjab Theater Bomb Kills 2
abstract: LEAD: A powerful bomb exploded at a movie theater near Amritsar today, killing 2 people and wounding 45, the police said. They said they suspected Sikh extremists of setting the bomb, which went off at the theater in the town of Patti.

headline: I.M.F. Loan Bid by Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Brazil signed a letter of intent today for a $2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund but said it would not pay interest on its bank debt until it reached a new agreement with commercial lenders, the Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, said.

headline: Rebels Attack Center of Liberia Capital
abstract: LEAD: More than 300 rebels invaded central Monrovia today and were locked in bitter street fighting with Government troops.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Americans Released Seem to Be Healthy, A U.S. Official Says
abstract: LEAD: All of the American hostages from the Middle East who arrived in West Germany on Sunday are in satisfactory health, a United States official said today.

headline: Currency;   For Now, the Dollar Holds Its Own
abstract: LEAD: Well, not much happened. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual testimony to Congress on monetary policy was a little anticlimactic after he said the previous week that the Fed would lower interest rates to offset a credit squeeze. If anything, he signaled in his testimony that interest rates would not be moving lower again soon.

headline: Report Cites Concern Over Chip Industry
abstract: LEAD: The National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors is expected to issue a report on Thursday stating that the American electronics industry is endangered by a decline in strength of the American companies that produce sophisticated equipment and materials for making computer chips.
