headline: Group Says It Has Freed 2d Swiss Hostage
abstract: LEAD: A group calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squad said today that it had released a second Swiss hostage in Lebanon, a relief worker for the International Committee of the Red Cross.

headline: Brady Expects Some New Limits To Be Put on Deposit Insurance
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Bush Administration was leaning in the direction of limiting individuals and businesses to a maximum of $100,000 in deposit insurance, whether in one or several accounts.

headline: Talking Deals;   'Paralyzed' Contel In GTE's Grasp
abstract: LEAD: THE Contel Corporation, which earlier this month signed a definitive agreement to be purchased by the GTE Corporation, provides another example of a company forced into a deal at least in part because of debt it took on to make acquisitions.

headline: Liberian Army's 'Reign of Terror' Protested by U.S. and Other Embassies
abstract: LEAD: What many residents of this city call a ''reign of terror'' by Government troops against unarmed civilians thought to sympathize with rebels in this country's six-month-old civil war has worsened in recent weeks, diplomats and Liberian and foreign journalists say, prompting several embassies to file official protests.

headline: Seeq Technology
abstract: LEAD: Seeq Technology Inc., a semiconductor company, said it would stop manufacturing its own computer chips and would instead have them manufactured by other companies. The move will mean the dismissal of about 95 workers, about a fifth of the company's work force, and a one-time charge of $8 million to $10 million in the fourth quarter, which ends this month.

headline: Mack Trucks' Projection
abstract: LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc. increased its projected loss for the year by 38 percent Friday, to $180 million. Mack now expects sales to total $1.67 billion, compared with the $1.5 billion predicted earlier. Mack originally predicted a loss of $130 million. The truck maker lost $97 million for the first half of the year and went into default on its large bank loans.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   Ayer Promotions
abstract: LEAD: Ayer said it had promoted four executives to senior vice president: Donna F. Tuttle, chairman and chief executive of Ayer/Tuttle in Los Angeles; Mitchell Burg and Suzanne I. Kaufman, associate media directors, and Ephraim D. Goldstein, assistant director of marketing planning. Ayer also named as a director Glenn E.

headline: Kuwaitis Say U.S. Doubts Embargo Will Get Iraq Out
abstract: LEAD: Senior Kuwaiti officials say they believe the Bush Administration has concluded that it can no longer rely on the embargo of Iraq to force the Iraqi army out of the Persian Gulf sheikdom.

headline: Views on the Gulf: Lawmakers Versed in Vietnam
abstract: LEAD: Their lives were touched by the long, hard, painful war in Vietnam.

headline: Rich Man's Quest for Salmon Is Toast of a Soviet Outpost
abstract: LEAD: All summer long this pristine stretch of Marx-forsaken frontier has witnessed the strangest of sights: the Communist Party has been quietly catering to American plutocrats who fly over for a $6,000 week of premier sports fishing for Atlantic salmon.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Krystal Co., Chattanooga, Tenn., a fast-food chain, to the Bloom Agency, Dallas, for the creative portion of the account. Media buying is still handled by Bozell Advertising, Minneapolis. Total budget is $8 million to $9 million.

headline: 4-Year Treasury Notes Sell Well
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury held an unexpectedly successful auction of four-year notes yesterday, despite growing concerns about oil-fed inflation, Washington's failure to produce a budget agreement and a Government securities market that was otherwise uncommonly dull with minimal price changes.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   ISRAELIS TEST FIRE A DEFENSE MISSILE
abstract: LEAD: Israel conducted its first test of the Arrow air-defense missile today in a clear response to an Iraqi threat on Wednesday to attack Israel with chemical weapons.

headline: Higher Long-Term Rates Predicted
abstract: LEAD: The week before Labor Day is normally one of Wall Street's slowest periods. But with the Persian Gulf crisis becoming increasingly volatile, the atmosphere in the financial markets will hardly be holiday-like in the coming days.

headline: K.G.B. Veteran Wins Election To Seat in Soviet Parliament
abstract: LEAD: A former general of the K.G.B. who was dismissed after accusing the security agency of continued abuses has been elected to the Soviet Parliament, Tass reported today.

headline: The Executive Life;  When a Plug of Hair Is Worth a Pound of Image
abstract: LEAD: ''I LOOKED as though I had come from some sort of African tribal fertility rite,'' said Michael Prout, a 43-year-old program manager at the DCS Corporation, an aerospace engineering concern in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Iraq Is Said to Order Foreign Reporters Out
abstract: LEAD: A French television crew has been ordered out of Iraq, and other foreign correspondents have been told to leave, a spokeswoman for the French channel Antenne 2 said today.

headline: Merc May Trade in Rubles
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it was working with Soviet officials and economists to develop futures and options markets for the ruble.

headline: Troops' Message to Powell: When Can We Go Home?
abstract: LEAD: Wherever Gen. Colin L. Powell went today on his tour of American forces here, he was confronted with one question: When can we go home?

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Workers Strike In North Sea
abstract: LEAD: Maintenance workers on Britain's North Sea oil platforms went on a 24-hour strike today, the fourth in a series of protests over union recognition, pay and safety.

headline: Mexico's Hope for Industrial Might
abstract: LEAD: From down the highway, the Ford Motor Company plant, which manufactures more than 1,000 car engines a day for the United States, seems at first glance like just another brown hillock on the vast desert plateau that surrounds this boom town.

headline: 600 Resign at Saudi Aramco
abstract: LEAD: Amid fear that war could break out in the Persian Gulf, about 600 foreign workers have resigned from Saudi Aramco, and many more are expected to leave, a Saudi executive of the company said today.

headline: Electric Boat Cuts
abstract: LEAD: The Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation plans to lay off about 1,000 of its 8,000 salaried workers before Dec. 1, the company said in an employee bulletin. The layoffs will be spread among Electric Boat operations in several states, said Neil D. Ruenzel, a spokesman for the submarine builder.

headline: Oil May Affect Price of Tires
abstract: LEAD: Further jumps in crude oil prices could push up retail prices of American-made tires in coming months, a trade official of a rubber trade group said today.

headline: Transition at the Top For Goldman, Sachs
abstract: LEAD: John L. Weinberg, who has led Goldman, Sachs & Company through one of the greatest and most profitable expansions in the firm's 121-year history, announced yesterday that he would retire in November as senior partner and chairman.

headline: Quebec Renews Effort To End Indian Protest
abstract: LEAD: The work to remove the barricades set up by Mohawk Indians across the Mercier Bridge resumed today, after being halted on Thursday in the seven-week-old standoff between the Canadian Government and Mohawk Indians.

headline: The Rocky Road to HDTV
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Careers;   When Going To Executive Search Firms
abstract: LEAD: The role of management recruiters, also known as ''headhunters'' and ''search consultants,'' seems to confuse many executives, especially those who have suddenly lost their jobs. In desperation, they deluge recruiting firms with resumes and telephone calls demanding interviews immediately.

headline: Liberian Loyalists Slow Rebel Drive
abstract: LEAD: Government troops mounted a successful counterattack today, dashing rebel hopes of seizing the capital before a West African task force arrives to impose peace.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Robin Davenport has been appointed senior vice president of Sudler & Hennessey, a New York agency.

headline: Two Women's Magazines Have Setbacks
abstract: LEAD: Yesterday was a cheerless day for the women's magazine field as Woman magazine announced that it would cease publication and Woman's Day was taken off the auction block because no one would meet its owner's asking price.

headline: Owens-Illinois President Gets Chief's Post, Too
abstract: LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc., the big glass-packaging company, has named its president and chief operating officer, Joseph H. Lemieux, to the additional post of chief executive.

headline: Tokyo Stocks and Yen Fall After Iraqi Invasion
abstract: LEAD: Japanese stock prices fell sharply in afternoon trading today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait.

headline: Rig Count Falls in Week
abstract: LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 26, to a total of 996, according to a widely watched index of drilling activity released on Monday by Baker Hughes Inc. The oil industry toolmaker said the total was still well above the 870 of a year ago. The count reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

headline: A Summit Respite
abstract: LEAD: The symbolism and timing of the Sov iet-American summit meeting next Sunday seems more important than any prospects the conference may hold for a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Confidential Pact By Kansas Utility
abstract: LEAD: The Kansas City Power and Light Company has signed a confidentiality agreement with the Kansas Gas and Electric Company that will allow it to obtain non-public information about Kansas Gas.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a medical, agricultural and consumer products company, said its board had approved the repurchase of 10 million to 12 million shares of its common stock.

headline: Household Finance Sells 5-Year Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Household Finance Corporation yesterday offered $150 million of five-year notes at competitive bids.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., named Earl F. Wheeler, a general manager of programming systems, as senior vice president. I.B.M. also named Dr. James C. McGroddy, director of its research division, and Mary Lee Turner, director of corporate communications, as vice presidents.

headline: Campbell Soup Posts Loss Of $238.4 Million in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Capping a year of sharp cost-cutting and lagging international performance, the Campbell Soup Company announced a fourth-quarter loss of $238.4 million yesterday, deeper than the loss of $194.7 million a year earlier.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   GORBACHEV CLEARS WAY FOR GERMAN UNITY, DROPPING OBJECTION TO NATO MEMBERSHIP
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union and West Germany agreed today to let a united Germany join NATO and to lift virtually all other remaining barriers to German reunification.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Avis Inc., Garden City, L.I., named Robert D. Cardillo vice president of sales and marketing.

headline: Warsaw Journal;   Fighting Crime Just Doesn't Pay. Ask a Policeman.
abstract: LEAD: A few weeks ago, the police here went to war against one of the roving gangs of pickpockets that prowl the cavernous main train station.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   24-NATION GROUP EXPANDS AID PLAN IN EASTERN EUROPE
abstract: LEAD: Foreign ministers from 24 leading industrial nations agreed today to expand their economic aid program for Poland and Hungary to include the emerging East European democracies of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and East Germany.

headline: African Force Is Protecting Doe's Tribe
abstract: LEAD: Troops of the West African peacekeeping force in Liberia were ordered today to intervene to protect members of former President Samuel K. Doe's ethnic group, the Krahn, from being massacred.

headline: Boris Yeltsin, Man of the Hour?
abstract: LEAD: Vladimir Kvint, Professor of Political Economy of the U.S.S.R. and a former professor at the Communist Higher Party School in Moscow, is a member of the ''Siberian school'' of market-oriented economists. Professor Kvint, who is currently a distinguished lecturer at Fordham University, spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times through an interpreter.

headline: As Track Creeps South, Slow-Paced Provence Fights Fast Trains
abstract: LEAD: France's growing network of high-speed trains may be the envy of many Europeans, but plans to extend it to the country's southern Provence region are stirring more protests than pride.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Budapest Memorial to Jews
abstract: LEAD: Several thousand people crowded outside Hungary's main synagogue today as a memorial was dedicated honoring 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed during World War II. The memorial by the sculptor Imre Varga depicts a powerful tree, 33 feet across, shaped like an inverted menorah, or candelabrum, with leaves bearing the names of victims.

headline: Brazilian Debt Payments
abstract: LEAD: Brazil paid its creditors $3.7 billion in the first quarter of 1990, but the country's foreign debt rose by $2.2 billion, the central bank said today. The Brazilian debt rose to $116.9 billion in March, from $114.7 in December 1989, according to the bank. Brazil has the largest foreign debt in the third world.

headline: Tandy Introduces A New Computer
abstract: LEAD: The Tandy Corporation introduced a six-pound notebook computer equipped with hard-disk and floppy-disk drives priced at $1,999. The new machine will compete directly with similar models made by the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Zenith Electronics Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation.

headline: Chrysler Offers A Buyout Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had started an employee buyout plan for its hourly workers to reduce its work force by 600 without layoffs. Employees who accept the offer will receive between $12,000 and $65,000, depending on seniority, to leave the company, Chrysler said.

headline: Loews Increases Stake in Champion
abstract: LEAD: The Loews Corporation, the New York hotel and tobacco concern headed by Laurence A. Tisch, has raised its stake in the Champion International Corporation to 8.93 percent from 7.92 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it acquired 933,900 additional Champion shares between Aug.

headline: Ready for Prime Time or Not, Here They Come
abstract: LEAD: The new prime-time television season begins tonight with more than $4 billion worth of advertising committed to network programs, some of which may be seen only fleetingly.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Janet Robinson has been named group vice president of advertising sales and marketing for The New York Times Company's Magazine Group. Ms. Robinson, who was advertising director at Tennis magazine, replaces Harry Myers, who resigned.

headline: Stotler Move By Creditors
abstract: LEAD: Stotler Group Inc., a financially troubled commodity firm based in Chicago, announced last night that an involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition had been filed against it by three parties that say they are creditors.

headline: Hungary Joint Ventures
abstract: LEAD: The number of joint-venture companies in Hungary has grown more than sixfold in the last year, official figures showed today. The Ministry of International Economic Relations said there were 1,800 joint ventures in the country, compared with 280 at the end of June 1989. Three hundred of them registered in

headline: Failed Zambia Coup Weakens Leader
abstract: LEAD: A failed coup attempt against President Kenneth D. Kaunda early this morning appears to have further weakened his political standing, already shaky after three days of rioting.

headline: Chrysler Raising Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation will raise prices on most of its 1990 passenger cars on Monday. The nation's No. 3 auto maker said suggested retail price increases start at $60 for Dodge Daytona cars, which will have a base price of $9,805, and most Chrysler LeBarons, which will rise to about $12,555. The biggest increases are $160 on the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and Chrysler Imperial models, bringing their base prices to $21,020 and $25,655, respectively.

headline: Protests Close Refinery
abstract: LEAD: Student protesters today forced an important oil refinery in India's northeast state of Assam to close and choked supplies of crude to three others, a state official said. The Assam Chief Secretary, S. R. Sarwan, said in New Delhi that picketing by the All Assam Students Union in six state oilfields had forced the state-owned refinery in the state capital, Guwahati, to close.

headline: Hesitation on Soviet Economy
abstract: LEAD: Facing what may be the most critical choice of his presidency, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is once again widely seen to be seized by indecision.

headline: Riney Helps Foote, Cone In Creating a Parody Ad
abstract: LEAD: ''High in the mountains of France, near a village called Combloux, there's a source of clean, crystal-clear water thas s as refshshg g any on Earth,'' says the folksy voice of Hal Riney in a television commercial that began yesterday.

headline: Ashton-Tate Sells Software Product
abstract: LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it was selling its dBase Mac software product to New Era Software Group Inc., a Miami-based company specializing in software for Apple Computer's Macintosh.

headline: Dow, Rising For 2d Day, Ends Up 24.01
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 24.01 points to 2,758.91. Favorable results of the Treasury's 30-year bond auction produced a late rally after stocks had drifted in light trading most of the day.

headline: Why So Little Training for American Judges?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: IRAQ AIR BLOCKADE IS BACKED BY BUSH
abstract: LEAD: President Bush said today that he was prepared to support efforts to extend the United Nations naval blockade of Iraq to halting the air shipments that are now a hole in the international sanctions against President Saddam Hussein.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf: Man in the News;   Mediator Turned Risk-Taker; Hosni Mubarak
abstract: LEAD: For a man long known for his caution, President Hosni Mubarak has put himself in a hot seat, at the center of a storm he himself warned could be ''horrifying.''

headline: McDonnell Plans New Jet Transport
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it plans to begin producing a new long-range jet transport, called the MD-12X, next year. It said the first deliveries and initial commercial service of the aircraft would start in 1995. It said it expected to begin talks with at least two other companies for the wing and fuselage work packages and would begin to select partners by early next year.

headline: VW Building Its Plant in East
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen A.G. laid the foundation stones today of a new $3.2 billion car plant in East Germany.

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in July
abstract: LEAD: The prices farmers get for raw products were unchanged from June to July, but the overall commodity price index was still 2.7 percent above a year before, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Democratic Hungary Nibbles on Political Fringes
abstract: LEAD: Three months after parliamentary elections in which voters here chose to make a clean break with the Communist past, Hungary is still lingering in a prolonged state of transition, debating issues that many thought were behind them.

headline: Lease Improves Trump's Financial Picture
abstract: LEAD: The long-term lease that Donald J. Trump signed yesterday with Galeries Lafayette is worth between $50 and $65 million, bankers said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Management Is Shuffled
abstract: LEAD: After announcing last week that it was laying off 30 of its 150 employees in New York, Chiat/Day/Mojo said yesterday that it has reorganized the top management at the troubled office.

headline: Advest Buyback
abstract: LEAD: The board of Advest Group Inc. approved a plan to buy back up to two million shares, or about 20 percent of the company's common stock. The intermittent purchases will be conducted in the open market, Advest said. The company is a regional brokerage based in Hartford. Its shares closed today at $3.75, up 50 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSH, REVERSING U.S. POLICY, WON'T OPPOSE A SOVIET ROLE IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE TALKS
abstract: LEAD: President Bush dropped the longstanding American opposition to Soviet involvement in Middle East peace efforts during his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday, Administration officials confirmed today.

headline: Treasury Urges Restrictions On Bank Deposit Insurance
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that restrictions should be placed on insurance coverage of deposits at banks and suggested that the insurance premiums paid by the banks be pegged to the risk involved in their investments and loans.

headline: Study Gives Auto Outlook
abstract: LEAD: Japanese automobile makers will continue to increase their market share in the United States in the 1990's at the expense of domestic manufacturers, but at a slower rate, according to a study released on Tuesday by the consulting firm Arthur D. Little.

headline: Big Board Fines Shearson For Actions in Merger Talks
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange censured Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday and fined the brokerage house $500,000 for improper actions during the firm's 1986 merger discussions with the E. F. Hutton Group, Wall Street executives said.

headline: Japan Trade Group Fills Top Post in New York
abstract: LEAD: The Japan External Trade Organization has named Tetsuo Matsufuji president of its New York office. Jetro is one of the leading Japanese Government agencies that promote trade relations between Japan and other countries.

headline: Oil Price Slide Fails to Register At Gas Pumps
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices are 20 percent lower than they were at this time last year, but the price of gasoline at the pump has not dropped.

headline: Jordan Asserts U.S. Stopped Refugee Rescue Ship
abstract: LEAD: Jordan charged today that an American warship in the Red Sea turned back a ship en route to the port of Aqaba to pick up refugees from Kuwait.

headline: Bank Law Overhaul Proposed
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed sweeping changes in the nation's banking industry today, including the repeal of the three main Federal regulatory laws, to ease the financial stress on the industry and on the Federal fund that insures deposits.

headline: Ending Interference On FM Broadcasts
abstract: LEAD: A European consortium developing a system for digital radio broadcasting has come up with a solution for a problem that causes interference in FM radio broadcasts.

headline: Compromise Offered on Regulating Stock Index Futures
abstract: LEAD: A key Senator offered a potential compromise today in the vigorous debate over the Administration's proposal for changes in the regulation of stock index futures.

headline: Farm Credit Banks' Bonds Are Priced
abstract: LEAD: The FFCB Funding Corporation priced $350 million in consolidated systemwide bonds for the Farm Credit System banks for sale yesterday through various securities dealers and dealer banks.

headline: 'Junk Bonds' Post Sharp Price Decline
abstract: LEAD: Prices of some high-yield ''junk bonds'' fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted to the uncertainty in the Mideast and to concerns about a possible recession. Some mutual fund portfolio managers sold these speculative bonds to meet an increase in redemptions by nervous individual investors, traders said.

headline: U.S. Gulf Policy: Vague 'Vital Interest'
abstract: LEAD: In his statement to the nation on Wednesday explaining the decision to send American troops to the Arabian Peninsula, President Bush said that the defense of Saudi Arabia was of ''vital interest'' to the United States. But Mr. Bush and his top aides have not clearly defined just how the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait touches the lives of Americans or affects their future.

headline: Bhutto Is Formally Charged With Abuse of Power
abstract: LEAD: Benazir Bhutto, who was ousted as Prime Minister last month, was formally charged today with abuse of power.

headline: U.S. Will Allow Press To Go With Troops
abstract: LEAD: The Defense Department said today that it would allow a group of journalists to accompany American troops to Saudi Arabia. The first group of 12 to 15 reporters and photographers is scheduled to leave for Saudi Arabia this weekend.

headline: Israeli Defense Chief, in Washington, Seeks $1 Billion Infusion of Arms Aid
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, told senior Administration officials today that the increase in arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the soaring costs Israel has paid in the Persian Gulf crisis had seriously eroded Israel's military situation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    OIL AND THE MIDEAST       So far, the oil-price run-up reflects expectations, not reality. And the anticipation could be worse than the outcome. No one, of course, knows just what a war would bring. [Page A1.]      Oil prices plowed stubbornly ahead despite Bush's effort to tame them by announcing a test withdrawal from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

headline: Careers;   Educating Engineers For Top Posts
abstract: LEAD: MANY engineering schools have been broadening their curriculums to hone the management skills of their students, so that they can hold more top management positions.

headline: Recalling Kissinger's Visit, and Parades That End Abruptly
abstract: LEAD: What a difference 17 years make.

headline: Rates Fall Sharply At Citicorp's Sale
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper fell sharply yesterday, reflecting the increased demand for short-term credit because of the inability or the unwillingness of large lenders to make loans.

headline: Job Cuts Planned By Fisher-Price
abstract: LEAD: Fisher-Price Toys, a troubled unit of the Quaker Oats Company, said it would cut about 245 jobs at its headquarters here, and that between 300 and 400 jobs would be lost when a shutdown of a nearby plant in Holland, N.Y., is completed by November. Until recently, the plant made molded plastic parts that were shipped to an East

headline: Some Liberians Accuse the U.S. of Betrayal
abstract: LEAD: As the Liberian civil war nears the end of its eighth month, many Liberians in the United States feel betrayed by the Bush Administration because it has not responded to their pleas for help to end the fighting.

headline: Oracle Replaces Division President
abstract: LEAD: Oracle Corporation replaced the president of its Oracle U.S.A. division, a week after the company was forced to restate earnings for three previous quarters. Oracle, a leading producer of data base software, said Michael S. Fields, formerly head of United States field sales and consulting, had been promoted to president of Oracle U.S.A., replacing Gary

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds increased $2.38 billion, to $404.48 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $829.3 million, to $101.11 billion. The assets of the 252 general-purpose funds were up by $469.9 million, to $140.4 billion.

headline: Circle K Is Closing Unprofitable Units
abstract: LEAD: The Circle K Corporation has begun closing 201 unprofitable stores and will complete the job by the end of the month, Ray Cox, a company spokesman, said.

headline: Wheeling Accord Backed
abstract: LEAD: Members of the United Steelworkers union overwhelmingly approved a new contract with the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today, clearing a big hurdle in the company's attempt to reorganize.

headline: P.&G. Profit Surged 66.1% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the world's largest makers of consumer products, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had surged 66.1 percent, to $284 million, or 78 cents a share.

headline: Zambian Leader Assents to Multiparty Vote
abstract: LEAD: President Kenneth Kaunda bowed to opposition demands today and said he would clear the way for multiparty elections. If carried out, his decision will end nearly two decades of one-party rule.

headline: ENDS RECOGNITION OF REBELS; AGREES TO TALKS WITH HANOI
abstract: LEAD: In a major policy reversal, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that the Bush Administration was withdrawing its diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which includes the Communist Khmer Rouge, and opening negotiations with Vietnam on settling the Cambodian conflict.

headline: FACING BOYCOTT, IRAQ SLOWS OIL: THE IRAQI INVASION;   BLOCKADE IS HINTED
abstract: LEAD: American and British officials said today they would be prepared to organize an international naval blockade of Iraq to insure enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on the country by the United Nations.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Medical Holdings Inc., Dallas, said its American Medical International Inc. subsidiary, Beverly Hills, Calif., had completed the sale of its Swiss and Greek hospital companies for about $176.7 million.

headline: An Olympics of Drills and Lathes
abstract: LEAD: A platoon of young men, the cream of a new generation of machinists, have spent several days drilling, cutting and grinding metal in the nation's oddest machine shop - a carpeted hallway in the cavernous McCormick Center here. They were competing in the midst of the nation's largest manufacturing trade show for the right to represent the United States in industry's equivalent of the Olympics.

headline: Jordan Seems to Have Quit Shipping Food to the Iraqis
abstract: LEAD: Jordan appears to have stopped its shipments of food and other goods to Iraq, after more than a month of argument and delay.

headline: Talking Deals;   Moscow's Call To De Beers
abstract: LEAD: THE historic diamond deal announced last week by the Soviet Union and De Beers Centenary, a Swiss subsidiary of the huge South African mining group, took months of meetings and four sets of shuttle negotiations between London and Moscow.

headline: QUEBEC STRUGGLES TO FIND NEW ROLE
abstract: LEAD: These days, Quebec is a little like a partner in a marriage who concludes that the relationship has failed but finds divorce to be too costly. Less drastic measures, like legal separation, are never as cut-and-dried, or as cathartic.

headline: Cambodian Rivals Said to Accept U.N. Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: After two years of difficult negotiations, the four Cambodian factions agreed today on a United Nations framework for a comprehensive peace settlement, the Indonesian Foreign Minister said here tonight.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   East Germans Battle Over Final Day
abstract: LEAD: East Germany's elected coalition Government wrangled all day and into the night before reaching a compromise on whether the country should legally cease to exist a day before or a day after all-German elections set for Dec. 2.

headline: NO U.S. HOSTAGES RELEASED;   No Americans Permitted to Go After Iraqi Vow
abstract: LEAD: None of the roughly 1,000 American women and children trapped in Kuwait and Iraq left today, despite President Saddam Hussein's promise on Tuesday to permit them and other Westerners to depart. Baghdad said that it would require each one to procure an exit visa first.

headline: Plan on Oil Costs Discussed By World Bank and I.M.F.
abstract: LEAD: As the International Monetary Fund and World Bank today approved speeding up aid to countries hurt by the Persian Gulf crisis, interest grew in a proposal for producer and consumer nations alike to stabilize oil prices.

headline: Airport Project Shows Hong Kong's Unease
abstract: LEAD: As planes land at Kai Tak airport here, they swoosh down close enough to the windows of buildings to make passengers feel like peeping Toms.

headline: Trinidad Rebels to Be Charged
abstract: LEAD: Charges of treason and murder will be brought against 114 members of the Muslim group that sought to oust the Trinidad and Tobago Government, the police said today. The Muslims, including a 14-year-old boy, face the death penalty if convicted.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Chesapeake Packaging Co., a division of the Chesapeake Corp., Richmond, appointed George F. Barnes president of the Display and Packaging Co., a unit in Sandusky, Ohio.

headline: Australian Sales Cleared
abstract: LEAD: Australia's ruling Labor Party on Monday abandoned its opposition to selling state-owned businesses and agreed to the sale of two airlines and a satellite telecommunications company.

headline: Your Own Account;  Psst! Want a Hot Tip?
abstract: LEAD: With Wall Street in tatters, thousands of brokerage employees laid off and those who remain shell-shocked, how valuable is the research you're getting from your stockbroker?

headline: Baker Hints at Direct Contact With Phnom Penh
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Washington might further modify its Indochina policy by opening direct diplomatic contacts with the Communist Government of Cambodia.

headline: Computers Change the Face of Type
abstract: LEAD: The words you are reading are printed in a sober typeface called Imperial, a style created in 1957 and used in The New York Times since July 3, 1967. On the front page of this paper are far older type styles, like those of the headlines over some single-column stories, which are printed in Latin extra condensed, a late 19th century design used in The

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Texaco to Relocate Workers
abstract: LEAD: Texaco, which employs 67 Americans in and around Saudi Arabia, has made arrangements to relocate the workers and their families from the area, a company spokesman said today.

headline: Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in generally sluggish trading yesterday, despite a big drop in the value of the dollar, and interest rates for longer maturities rose slightly.

headline: International Report;   Brazil Data Show Recession
abstract: LEAD: President Fernando Collor de Mello's anti-inflation plan, begun on March 16, has produced Brazil's worst recession in 10 years, data from the Government Statistics Institute show.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    International

headline: Publishing World Is Shaken As Advances for Books Soar
abstract: LEAD: Many publishers were irate three weeks ago after Dell Publishing agreed to pay $12.3 million for Ken Follett's next two novels. Now, having had time to think it over, they are even angrier, in part because HarperCollins quickly bought three books by Jeffery Archer, for what the British author said was more than $20 million.

headline: Economic Scene;   What Price Cleaner Air?
abstract: LEAD: Like purer hearts or thinner thighs, cleaner air is an unalloyed virtue. But like other virtues, cleaner air can only be attained through sacrifice. And according to Paul R. Portney, an environmental economist at Resources for the Future in Washington, Americans may be on the verge of giving up too much for too little: They are not likely to get their money's worth from the sweeping amendments to the Clean Air Act now being cobbled together by

headline: Business Scene;   Airlines in Pull Of Global Magnet
abstract: LEAD: THE changes wrought by airline deregulation since 1978 go on and on. Many fares were cut drastically. Routes within the nation were revamped. The industry became concentrated in the hands of nine major carriers. And now globalization is bringing a new upheaval.

headline: Treasury Securities Up Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Prices of most Treasury securities inched higher in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as traders nervously reacted to sudden shifts in the foreign exchange and petroleum markets as well as a potpourri of rumors.

headline: In Mongolia, Taking Stock of Rare Animals
abstract: LEAD: This vast nation of steppes, rich in animal species, is beginning to count its living wealth to improve conservation.

headline: Tokyo Is to Ban Fish Nets Early
abstract: LEAD: Japan will stop drift-net fishing in the South Pacific this season, a year before the date set by a United Nations resolution, the Japanese Embassy said today.

headline: Stock Buyback Plan Announced by Carbide
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that it would take several steps to strengthen its businesses and increase its flagging share price, including a substantial stock buyback and the sale of some businesses.

headline: Soybean Case To Proceed
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge has let stand charges against a soybean futures trader who had charged that prosecutors in Chicago mishandled the grand jury.      Federal District Judge

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;   G. Gordon Liddy in Ad For Chilean Wines
abstract: LEAD: G. Gordon Liddy will join the Watergate rebound team by becoming a spokesman for Concha y Toro wines. The print ad, which depicts Mr. Liddy with a bottle under the headline ''G. Gordon Liddy on Graft,'' will begin in October.

headline: Bayer Set to Buy Citric Acid Plant
abstract: LEAD: Bayer USA Inc. said its parent company had signed a contract to buy the citric acid business and assets of a plant in Britain for about $100 million.

headline: Sikh Who Promoted Truce Is Shot to Death
abstract: LEAD: A Sikh leader who helped fashion a brief truce between the Indian Government and Sikh militants was assassinated today in the capital of Punjab.

headline: G.M. Is Setting Up Plant in Hungary
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian affiliate of the General Motors Corporation said it planned to build 200,000 engines and 15,000 Opel Kadett cars a year starting in 1992. G.M. has a joint venture with the Raba Railway Carriage and Machine Factory, which has a plant at Szentgotthard on Hungary's border with Austria.

headline: In South Africa, Joint Plea to End Black Strife
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government and the leaders of two black homelands jointly pleaded for peace today after fighting between black factions that has killed nearly 400 people and wounded more than 1,500 in weeklong battles.

headline: The Media Business;   For Authors, the Key Words Are in the Book Contracts
abstract: LEAD: Publishing used to be about trust. But today, the old relationships between authors and publishers have given way to growing differences over the contracts that define the business ties between them.

headline: 3d-Party Interest In Takeover Target
abstract: LEAD: The General Instrument Corporation disclosed that it had been approached by an unidentified financial concern seeking information about the New York-based electronics company. The disclosure came as Forstmann Little & Company formally began its friendly $1.6 billion tender offer for the company.

headline: Dow Falls 18.07 in Heavy Program Selling
abstract: LEAD: Investors turned cautious yesterday amid heavy program selling, depressing stock prices for the first time in more than a week and leaving the Dow 3,000 level as a barrier still to be crossed.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Bechtel Group, San Francisco, an engineering concern, said its Bechtel Houston unit had been awarded a contract to design and build a $140 million petroleum coke-sulfur recovery plant in Billings, Mont., for Conoco Inc., Houston, an oil and gas company.

headline: Paribas Expected to Seek Bigger U.S. Financial Role
abstract: LEAD: Eight months after botching the biggest takeover ever proposed in France, Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, guided by a new management team, is fashioning a strategy to help restore an image that was badly bruised by the failed 26.2 billion franc ($4.7 billion) bid for Navigation Mixte, the French conglomerate.

headline: State Dept. Tells Americans To Postpone Trips to Kenya
abstract: LEAD: The State Department advised American citizens today to defer all nonessential travel to Kenya because of anti-Government strife there.

headline: Federal Express Official Heads Smaller Concern
abstract: LEAD: Judith A. Rogala, a senior vice president at the Federal Express Corporation, has left the overnight delivery company for an entrepreneurial career as the president and chief executive of Flagship Express Inc., a small, new aviation services concern.

headline: Poorest Countries Seek Increases in Aid
abstract: LEAD: As the world's seven richest nations prepare for their annual economic summit meeting, to be held next week in Houston, the 42 poorest nations are knocking at the door to tell the haves what the have-nots would like to see come out of that exclusive gathering.

headline: TV Dumping Is Charged
abstract: LEAD: American color television tube makers and their unions asked the Commerce Department today to impose ''anti-dumping'' duties on color picture tubes assembled into sets in Mexico and sold in the United States at what they contend is less than fair value.

headline: Soviets Prepare to Evacuate 7,830 Citizens Still in Iraq
abstract: LEAD: Baghdad has assured Moscow that Soviet citizens still in Iraq are not directly threatened by the Persian Gulf crisis, but the Kremlin is drawing up plans to evacuate them anyway, the official press agency Tass said today.

headline: Market Place;   Cleaning Spills: Is It Profitable?
abstract: LEAD: FROM the Exxon Valdez to the Mega Borg, when a tanker's oil hits the water these days, huge sums are spent on booms, skimmers and personnel for the cleanup. But there are no pure plays in oil-spill cleanup companies.

headline: Gorbachev Foe Fails to Win Key Post
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev survived a bold challenge today from his most prominent adversary within the Communist Party, Yegor K. Ligachev, an orthodox Marxist who failed in an attempt to take the powerful new post of deputy party leader.

headline: Contel Chairman Is 80, But Shuns Retirement
abstract: LEAD: After finding a safe berth for the Contel Corporation, with the proposed merger of Contel into the GTE Corporation, some might expect Charles Wohlstetter to feel that his work is complete and think about retirement.

headline: Newmont to Offer Stock; Hanson Seeks to Cut Stake
abstract: LEAD: In a move to take advantage of the current boom in the gold industry, the Newmont Mining Corporation, the large gold mining concern that is 49 percent owned by Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, said yesterday that it plans to sell 3.6 million new common shares in a public offering.

headline: Apple Cuts Price On Macintosh PC
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. lowered prices on its Macintosh IICI personal computer by $1,500. Depending on which disk drive is included, prices now range from $5,969 to $7,269 for the IICI, which is the more compact version of Apple's high-end, separate monitor Macintosh. The price cut is effective only in the United

headline: Talking Business; with Weinberg of Hartmarx;   Merging of Roles Seen in Retailing
abstract: LEAD: The Hartmarx Corporation is divesting itself of 65 men's wear stores that it considers marginal, but it remains committed to the concept of dual distribution, in which a manufacturer also owns and operates retail stores. It will still operate more than 400 stores after the closings.

headline: Investor Acquires Stake in Watsco
abstract: LEAD: Watsco Inc. said H. Wayne Huizenga had bought 50,000 shares from the company, or about 4.8 percent of Watsco's class A common stock, for $10 a share and a five-year warrant allowing him to buy 45,000 class B shares at $11.25 each. Watsco is in the climate-control business through Gemaire Distributors Inc.

headline: Ladies' Home Journal Takes Russian Tour
abstract: LEAD: Never underestimate the power of a woman's magazine to spread the message about never underestimating the power of a woman.

headline: When Is It a Recession?
abstract: LEAD: At a time when many Americans believe that a recession has descended on the country, they are being told by Government officials to put their worries aside for the moment because other economic issues, mainly inflation, have to be dealt with first.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Market Place;   Small Investors Resisting Any Impulse to Sell, So Far
abstract: LEAD: The stock market was buffeted by waves of selling and sharply lower prices last week in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But there are signs that most individual investors have not yet begun to sell.

headline: Bush Scraps Intelligence Board, Appointing a New Panel of 6
abstract: LEAD: President Bush today scrapped the White House's 15-member advisory board on intelligence issues and replaced it with a 6-member panel composed largely of veteran intelligence officials and scientists.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, has formed a new unit, Hill & Knowlton International, for its operations outside the U.S. Thomas E. Eidson, president and chief operating officer of U.S. operations for the firm, was appointed president and chief executive of the new division. John D. Bergen, executive vice president of the parent company's Eastern region and general manager of its New York office, replaces Mr.

headline: Warning Strikes Hit 10 Cities in East Germany
abstract: LEAD: About 45,000 municipal workers in several East German cities walked off their jobs for a few hours today in warning strikes for better wages and job security in a united Germany.

headline: Reporter Finally Flees Kuwait After Weeks of Eluding Iraqis
abstract: LEAD: Caryle Murphy, a reporter for The Washington Post who escaped from Kuwait on Monday after almost a month of eluding Iraqi troops, said today that she finally fled to Saudi Arabia because remaining seemed largely fruitless and increasingly dangerous.

headline: Britain Clears 5 Oil Concerns
abstract: LEAD: The British Office of Fair Trading cleared five oil companies today of fixing gasoline pump prices in the face of rising oil prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month. The office's director general, Gordon Borrie, said the industry's reaction to events in the Persian Gulf followed a ''pattern one would expect in a competitive market.

headline: P.&G. Heir Leads Effort For Salvadoran Boycott
abstract: LEAD: James Gamble, 27, is a research technician studying low-pesticide apple orchards for the state agriculture agency in Massachusetts. He is also an heir to the Procter & Gamble fortune and namesake of the cofounder of P.&G. and is leading a fight to stop the company from buying Salvadoran coffee beans for its

headline: U.S. Softening on Subsidies
abstract: LEAD: Softening its position in global trade talks, the Bush Administration said today that it was prepared to allow some farm subsidies in a new accord to liberalize international trade.

headline: As Part of a Liquidation, Morgan Sells 'Junk Bonds'
abstract: LEAD: Morgan Stanley & Company has been selling a large number of ''junk bonds'' as part of a liquidation of a portfolio of these high-yield, high-risk securities. The selling has some traders worried that similar funds might also have to sell bonds.

headline: U.S. Reports A 0.7% Surge In Inventories
abstract: LEAD: Business inventories rose seven-tenths of a percent in July, the biggest pileup in a year, and sales fell five-tenths of a percent, the Government said today.

headline: Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.16 percent this week, up from 10.13 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.30 percent, up from 8.26 percent last week.

headline: U.S. TO CALL 40,000 RESERVES TO SUPPORT SAUDI TROOPLIFT; REJECTS IRAQI OFFER TO TALK
abstract: LEAD: To fill gaps in the United States military buildup in the Persian Gulf region, President Bush on Wednesday is expected to order a mobilization of reserves that will initially place about 40,000 Americans on active duty, Administration officials said today.

headline: Trump Hires New Ad Team
abstract: LEAD: The financially troubled Trump Shuttle has switched its account from Scali, McCabe, Sloves to another New York agency, Great Scott Advertising, according to a spokeswoman for the airline.

headline: Juice Bowl Unit Sold by Campbell
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company says it has sold its Juice Bowl Products subsidiary because it no longer fits in with the company's plans. Juice Bowl was sold to ABA Holding Inc. for an undisclosed amount. ABA Holding is the United States arm of Looza N.V., a Belgian fruit juice company.

headline: Bank Funds, C.D.'s Mixed For Week
abstract: LEAD: For the third straight week, yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mixed, in the week ended yesterday, as the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis continue to tug interest rates in different directions.

headline: Net Income Up 16.7% at Conagra
abstract: LEAD: Conagra Inc., the giant food company, has reported that strong performance from its prepared foods segment led to a 16.7 percent increase in earnings in the quarter that ended on Aug. 26.

headline: Anticipation, Not Actuality, Holds Sway Over Oil Prices
abstract: LEAD: Brushing aside President Bush's decision on Wednesday to tap the Stategic Petroleum Reserve as a test, traders pushed oil prices up to near $40 a barrel yesterday as worries about the conflict in the Middle East continued to dominate the markets. But so far, the run-up, which has more than doubled oil prices since the beginning of summer, reflects expectations, not reality.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Yeltsin Sets Quick Tempo, Gorbachev Tries to Keep Beat
abstract: LEAD: In a country where power has long been a game of older men, Boris N. Yeltsin's choice of a 32-year-old banking specialist to run the Finance Ministry of the vast Russian republic raised some eyebrows.

headline: Iraqis Are Reported to Send Home $3 Billion Taken From Kuwaitis
abstract: LEAD: Iraq has transferred between $3 billion and $4 billion in gold bullion, foreign currencies and goods seized from Kuwaiti financial and commercial institutions to Baghdad, Arab bankers in London and the Persian Gulf region said today.

headline: Deluge of Gulf Satellite Data
abstract: LEAD: Intelligence analysts can barely handle the deluge of photographs pouring into the Central Intelligence Agency from spy satellites monitoring Iraqi forces in the Persian Gulf, Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine reported. The respected industry journal will report in its Monday edition that experts at the C.I.A.

headline: Wall Street;   Stubbing a Toe on Primerica
abstract: LEAD: The markets are clearly of two minds about the Primerica Corporation, the financial conglomerate that owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the Commercial Credit Company and the A. L. Williams insurance operation.

headline: Security Council's Military Panel Reviews Naval Efforts to Enforce Trade Embargo
abstract: LEAD: The military arm of the United Nations Security Council met informally today to review naval efforts to enforce the Council's trade embargo against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.

headline: In Bhutto's Shadow, Women Who Succeeded
abstract: LEAD: As rumors began to circulate this week that Pakistan's new caretaker Government was about to name its information and broadcasting minister, one of the first visitors to the likely candidate's house was the editor of the country's newest daily newspaper.

headline: Three Drug Companies Post Strong Profits
abstract: LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company, Pfizer Inc. and the Upjohn Company said yesterday that they had double-digit gains in profits and sales of drug and health-care products in the three months ended June 30.

headline: Ford and G.M. Closing Plants
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company will close three plants this week and the General Motors Corporation will shut down a Chevrolet Caprice plant for two weeks because of slow sales, the auto makers said Friday.

headline: ARABS' SUMMIT MEETING OFF; IRAQI UNITS IN KUWAIT DIG IN; EUROPE BARS BAGHDAD'S OIL
abstract: LEAD: A hastily arranged Arab summit meeting that was to have convened on Sunday in Saudi Arabia to deal with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait fell apart today as Arab leaders sought to mask their divisions and disarray with assertions of brotherhood.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   15-Second Spots: Help or Hindrance?
abstract: LEAD: AS the use of 15-second commercials becomes more prevalant - they now represent about 40 percent of all television ads - many advertisers and agency executives have questioned the effectiveness of using so many short spots. Some have also worried that the use of 15-second commercials could spiral out of control, creating a hopelessly glutted television advertising environment.

headline: The Media Business;   Magazines Follow Readers to the Beach
abstract: LEAD: Summer is ending soon, but the lure of the beach remains strong -especially for magazine readers.

headline: U.S. Policy On Inquiries
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators who have opened civil proceedings on failed savings institutions to public scrutiny, including a case involving President Bush's son Neil, may expand the policy to include institutions not under Government control.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   SOVIETS SAY CRISIS WON'T MAR U.S. TIE
abstract: LEAD: The Gorbachev Government insisted today that its improved relations with the United States were in no way undermined by the Bush Aministration's growing military buildup in the Persian Gulf.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * American Express Bank Ltd., a banking subsidiary of the American Express Co., New York, named William J. Blomquist executive vice president and head of its Europe, Middle East and Africa region.

headline: Artillery Duels Violate Liberian Truce
abstract: LEAD: Rebel armored units fought a fierce artillery and rocket duel today with Government troops trapped inside the executive mansion and the main army barracks here in the capital.

headline: Swiss Set Bank Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The Swiss Government ordered the abolition today of four cartel-like agreements in the country's banking system.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * All News Channel, New York, a venture of Viacom Satellite and Conus Communications, named Matthew A. Riklin executive vice president.

headline: Kroger Picks President And Chief Adds Title
abstract: LEAD: The Kroger Company, a major supermarket chain, has named a president and chief operating officer, and its new chief executive has added the title of chairman.

headline: Lufthansa's Airbus Jets
abstract: LEAD: Lufthansa A.G., West Germany's state-controlled airline, said Thursday that it had signed an order worth more than two billion marks, or about $1.2 billion, to buy 20 new Airbus Industrie A321 jets and to take options on 20 more. The A321 seats up to 180 passengers.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about accounting standards for nonprofit corporations misidentified an official of the National Charities Information Bureau Inc. He is Ken Albrecht, president of the bureau, not Daniel Borochoff, an analyst.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Fearful of the Future, East Germans Promise to Work Harder Than Ever
abstract: LEAD: After spending a joyous Sunday celebrating with her new West German marks, Christine Liebe was back behind her dull gray sewing machine today, and her mood was far from jubilant.

headline: 10 Die as Rival Palestinians Clash in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Rival Palestinian guerrillas clashed with rockets and heavy machine guns in their largest district in Lebanon today, and the police said 10 people were killed and 50 wounded.

headline: Ruling on Allegheny Near
abstract: LEAD: United States Bankruptcy Judge Joseph Cosetti could confirm a bankruptcy reorganization plan for the Allegheny International Inc. as early as this week, officials close to the company and its creditors said today.

headline: In a Surprise Move, Hess's Chief Retires
abstract: LEAD: In a move that surprised the industry, Irwin Greenberg has retired as president and chief executive of Hess's Department Stores. He spent 14 years as president of the chain and also served as chief executive for the last five.

headline: Civil War in Liberia Threatening To Divide West African Neighbors
abstract: LEAD: The eight-month-old civil war in nearby Liberia is threatening to become a wider conflict as neighboring West African countries begin to take opposing sides, African and Western diplomats said today.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria to Share Arms Export Data
abstract: LEAD: The new director of a Bulgarian arms-export concern long presumed in the West to have supplied weapons to terrorist organizations said today that his company was willing to share with Western governments information on arms that might have ended up in terrorist hands.

headline: Bond Agrees To Resign
abstract: LEAD: Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur with worldwide holdings in brewing, real estate and publishing, will resign as chairman of his company to appease creditors under an agreement announced today.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Can the New dBASE Solve Ashton-Tate's Problems?
abstract: LEAD: Nearly two years after it rushed a flawed version of dBASE to market, the Ashton-Tate Corporation of Torrance, Calif., has finally brought out a new, improved update of the leading data base management program for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible models.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;  Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * The Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, will resume buying back its common stock. Since 1986, it has bought back 3.4 million shares under a program to repurchase 5.1 million shares.

headline: World Bank Is Beginning To Tap Smaller Markets
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank began borrowing money in the smaller financial markets of the world yesterday when it became the first nonresident borrower in New Zealand.

headline: Wall Street;   The Dubious Profits in Patriotism
abstract: LEAD: PATRIOTISM may be the last refuge of scoundrels, but it is often the first choice of companies seeking the ear of the investing public. Consider the case of American Spirit Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.
