headline: Boeing Gets Order From the Japanese
abstract: LEAD: The All Nippon Airways Company of Japan has ordered 17 more Boeing 747-400's in a deal valued at $3.5 billion, including parts and related equipment, the Boeing Company said on Monday. Delivery of the aircraft, the world's largest passenger jetliners, is scheduled to begin in 1995.

headline: Hopes Dying In the Rubble In Philippines
abstract: LEAD: A young vendor in the market here has become something of a hero in the wake of the earthquake that devastated parts of the city on Monday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   H.I.P. Uses Light Touch In Campaign
abstract: LEAD: FACED with increasing competition, the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has begun its first television campaign in three years, an effort aimed at dispelling what it says are some common misconceptions about health maintenance organizations.

headline: Trump Shuttle Looking to Expand Service
abstract: LEAD: The Trump Shuttle plans to become more than a shuttle by expanding its charter flights to the Caribbean and Mexico and by expanding service to Atlantic City in a move to make better use of its fleet and broaden its customer base.

headline: Computer Screen Dumping Charged
abstract: LEAD: Frustrated by what they say are the unfair pricing practices of eight major Japanese electronics companies, a small group of American makers of flat screens used in advanced portable computers filed an anti-dumping petition yesterday, calling for an investigation by the United States Government.

headline: Loss Reported by Circle K
abstract: LEAD: The Circle K Corporation said today that it lost $10.8 million in the quarter ended July 31, compared with a profit of $7.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in the same quarter last year.

headline: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. Rates had previously declined for four consecutive weeks.

headline: Prices to Rise on Champaign
abstract: LEAD: The Champagne Producers Bureau said today that the price of champagne grapes will increase by more than 20 percent this year, leading producers to predict a rise of 10 percent in the price of a bottle of champagne.

headline: 2 Airlines Cut Some Fares
abstract: LEAD: Two airlines said yesterday that they had lowered some domestic air fares for a short time. Other airlines have raised most ticket prices to account for higher fuel prices.

headline: Pratt Recalls Some Jet Engines
abstract: LEAD: Pratt & Whitney Inc. has recalled more than three dozen of its newest and largest jet engines because of a compressor problem that if left unchecked could prompt an engine to shut down during a flight.

headline: Managing;   Treasuring the Technology Guru
abstract: LEAD: AT TRW Inc. and the United Technologies Corporation, the title is ''vice president of science and technology.'' At Merrill Lynch & Company, it's ''executive vice president for operations systems and telecommunications.'' Chemical Bank sticks with the plain-vanilla ''chief technology officer.''

headline: Tourist Cancellations Are Reported in Israel
abstract: LEAD: Travel agents said today they had received cancellations and were being swamped by phone calls from anxious tourists worried about an Iraqi chemical attack on Israel.

headline: Redistribute the Burden for the Bailout
abstract: LEAD: Asking ordinary taxpayers to cover the costs of a financial debacle they neither caused nor benefited from was bad enough. But now, the Resolution Trust Corporation - the agency set up by the Government to dispose of the assets of the failed savings and loan institutions - is compounding the misery.

headline: Mexico Sets Telmex Sale
abstract: LEAD: Mexico started the sale today of its giant telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico S.A., whose privatization is a showcase for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's drive to spin off inefficient state-owned industries.

headline: MANDELA HOPEFUL ON BRITISH TALKS
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela expressed optimism today about the prospects of narrowing his differences with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over economic sanctions against South Africa, and backed off from comments that had suggested that Britain should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army.

headline: German Aid to Iraq Reported
abstract: LEAD: West German companies helped build a weapons factory in Iraq where a cannon was to be made, the German news magazine Der Spiegel said today. The Hamburg-based weekly said confiscated documents showed that the factory near Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, was designed to produce guns. Specialists fear that it was also the site where a cannon with a barrel 150 yards long and a range of 600 miles was to be built.

headline: Oil Executive Named President of Bow Valley
abstract: LEAD: Bow Valley Industries on Monday said that Jerry R. Wright would join the Canadian oil and gas company as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Business Scene;   Inventory Data Can Be Deceptive
abstract: LEAD: THE sluggish American economy is in danger of sliding into a recession. Few Americans dispute that; yet they are being told by economists to take comfort. The national economy will muddle through, as long as companies maintain small stockpiles of unsold goods. The problem with this thesis is that when sales plunge recessions can be born anyway, no matter how small the stockpiles.

headline: Pakistan's New Government Arrests Supporters of Bhutto
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan's new Government began rounding up supporters of the ousted Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, today.

headline: AUSTRALIA'S CHIEF SEES SUPPORT EBB
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who won election to a record fourth term just last March, is now facing tough economic problems and sharply eroding popular support.

headline: Business People;   Son of Ex-Chairman To Take Over at Tultex
abstract: LEAD: On Jan. 1, the Tultex Corporation will find a familiar name at the helm. John M. Franck will become chairman and chief executive of the sporting wear company that William F. Franck, his father, headed from 1953 to 1988.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   IRAQI LEADER SAYS HE WILL FREE FOREIGN WOMEN AND CHILDREN
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announced tonight that he would allow the departure of all foreign women and children, whom he had previously barred from leaving his country.

headline: Hicks, Muse Buys 2 Media Services
abstract: LEAD: Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas-based private investment group specializing in leveraged acquisitions, said it had agreed to purchase two media services companies, Neodata Services and the TMI Corporation, in transactions valued at $104 million.

headline: FED CONSIDERS CUT IN INTEREST RATES TO BOOST ECONOMY
abstract: LEAD: Expressing concern that banks have become overly cautious in lending money, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the central bank might need to cut interest rates to keep the economy moving ahead.

headline: Bush Hails Soviet Decision
abstract: LEAD: President Bush hailed the Soviet Union's decision to accept a united Germany as a member of the NATO alliance, describing the move as an act of statesmanship. Page A9.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Vietnamese in Bulgaria: Bitter Times
abstract: LEAD: Through the barred ground-floor windows of shabby workers' dormitories in a quarter of Bulgaria's capital known as Little Saigon, Vietnamese men sell scarce convenience store staples like Coca-Cola, instant coffee and cigarettes along with Canadian whisky and other hard liquor.

headline: Hussein Has The Market Over a Barrel
abstract: LEAD: As stock and bond prices plunged around the world last week, it appeared that investors were losing hope that the Gulf crisis will end quickly. If it doesn't, the markets' travails could continue.

headline: U.S. Deploys Air and Sea Forces After Iraq Threatens 2 Neighbors
abstract: LEAD: The United States has dispatched two aerial refueling planes to the United Arab Emirates and sent combat ships to sea in a rare exercise with the Persian Gulf nation after Iraqi threats to use military force against the Emirates and Kuwait, Bush Administration officials said today.

headline: Empire Federal Sells Auto Loans
abstract: LEAD: Empire Federal Savings of America has sold its $900 million portfolio of automobile loans to a General Electric Company subsidiary as part of the Federal Government's restructuring of the seized savings institution. The purchase is GE Capital Auto Financial Services' first significant push into the business of holding and servicing auto loans, a GE Capital spokesman said.

headline: Easing Local Phone Rules: Fight on Profit
abstract: LEAD: A year ago the Government granted the American Telephone and Telegraph Company greater freedom to raise or lower prices while eliminating most controls on its rate of return. The idea was to encourage better services, cut costs and create savings for consumers and shareholders.

headline: Dollar Loses Draw as Safe Haven in Time of Crisis
abstract: LEAD: The dollar, a longtime haven for investors in times of military and political crisis, has been all but shunned since Iraq invaded Kuwait.

headline: FORUM;  'We Want to Keep Working'
abstract: LEAD: I represent 700 workers at the Health-Tex Inc. plant, Danville, Va. Health-Tex, one of our country's quality names in children's wear, went through a faulty leveraged buyout in 1985. Although it was profitable before the buyout, it has been struggling since. Last October, the ten banks that control the debt put in a new management team.

headline: Japanese Wary Of Toys 'R' Us
abstract: LEAD: Eleven Japanese toy retailers have formed an association to try to protect domestic toy stores from competition by Toys ''R'' Us.      The Japan Association of

headline: Penguin Units Get New Chiefs
abstract: LEAD: Penguin Books USA announced yesterday that it had appointed Michael Jacobs president of its Viking Penguin division.      Mr. Jacobs succeeds Morton

headline: All About/The Shuttles;   Clipped Wings Along the Northeast Corridor
abstract: LEAD: It's Friday morning at La Guardia Airport and the shuttle business is even slower than usual. Richard F. Cozzi, wrapping up his first week as president of the Trump Shuttle, glances about anxiously, as if hunting for more passengers. A holiday that week has thinned the weekend rush; only a few people straggle into the Trumpterminal, ready to board a Trumpjet, sink into leather Trumpchairs and enjoy Trumpsnacks.

headline: Suitor Meets on Bid for Kay
abstract: LEAD: Executives of Ratners Group P.L.C., which is trying to acquire Kay Jewelers Inc. for about $410 million, met yesterday to reconsider the terms of its offer to Kay stockholders and bondholders. The company's plans were not disclosed, and no announcement about the offer was made last night.

headline: Kodak Is Sued Over Test Dye
abstract: LEAD: Victims of a spinal nerve disease sued the Eastman Kodak Company and four other companies over a dye used for diagnostic purposes. The 25 plaintiffs, who live in 18 states, contend they were not adequately informed of the dangers of Pantopaque, a dye that is injected into the spinal membrane.

headline: U.S. Intercepts and Frees 2 Iraqi Ships
abstract: LEAD: United States ships halted two Iraqi cargo vessels in the Persian Gulf today in the first test of the American-led naval blockade of vessels carrying cargo to or from Iraq and occupied Kuwait, the Pentagon said.

headline: BUSH SAID TO APPROVE PLAN TO ACTIVATE SOME RESERVES; U.S. TAKING OVER 38 AIRLINERS
abstract: LEAD: President Bush has decided to call up a limited number of military reservists because of the Middle East crisis, Administration officials said today, and the Pentagon commandeered 38 wide-body jets from 16 airlines to carry troops and cargo to the region.

headline: In Moscow, More Fanfare Than Action
abstract: LEAD: YOUNG & RUBICAM and Ogilvy & Mather opened offices with great fanfare in Moscow 18 months ago, and while both have been busy learning the ins and outs of doing business in the Soviet Union, the one thing they have not been doing much of is creating advertising.

headline: Israel's Envoy to Egypt Quits, Citing Rightists
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Ambassador to Egypt, Shimon Shamir, resigned today, saying he could not reconcile his political views with those of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing Government.

headline: Several Top Managers Are Named by Hasbro
abstract: LEAD: Hasbro Inc., the toy company, has named George R. Ditomassi chief operating officer for the company's games and international operations, one of several key changes in senior management this week. The company also named Alfred J. Verrecchia chief operating officer of domestic toy operations and manufacturing services.

headline: For Africa, a Nod at Democracy
abstract: LEAD: The Organization of African Unity, a collection of more than 40 disparate countries, welcomed an independent Namibia at its annual gathering today, listened for the first time to Nelson Mandela but heard only elliptically about democracy.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion: A New Gulf Alignment;   Iraqis, Bargaining on Anti-U.S. Sentiment, May Profit by Intimidating the Monarchies
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ushers in a new alignment in which Iraqis, Iranians and Palestinian hard-liners appear to share an interest in subduing the oil-rich monarchies of the region and challenging United States influence in the Arab world.

headline: Disney Sues an Executive
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company sued a former top movie executive on Thursday and accused him of trying to lure away other Disney employees and projects after the company released him from a contract.

headline: Big Japanese Bank Forms U.S. Unit to Handle Mergers
abstract: LEAD: The Industrial Bank of Japan, one of the world's largest banking institutions, announced yesterday that it had formed an American subsidiary to focus on the mergers and acquisitions business.

headline: Kansas Utility Bid May Be Sweetened
abstract: LEAD: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said in a letter to the chairman of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company that it would like to discuss its merger proposal and that it would be willing to consider adjustments to its offer. On July 23, Kansas City Power began a tender offer worth $857 million in cash for all Kansas Gas shares at $27 a share.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Jordan's Ruler: A Peacemaker or Just Indecisive?
abstract: LEAD: As the gulf crisis deepens, the quandary of King Hussein of Jordan is becoming more acute.

headline: Colombia Swears In President, a Foe of Traffickers
abstract: LEAD: Amid tight security, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo was inaugurated today as President of Colombia.

headline: Europeans Splurge on Vacations in Mauritius
abstract: LEAD: Americans may have spent less and stayed closer to home this vacation season, but if this tropical island tousled by breezes from the Indian Ocean is any indication, Europeans, flush with strong currencies, are splurging on the exotic.

headline: Universal Health
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth raised its stake in Universal Health Services Inc. to the equivalent of 11.4 percent of the company's class B stock, from 10.3 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it had held, and expected to continue having, discussions with Universal's managers about its investment in the company.

headline: Text of U.N. Resolution on the Iraq Air Embargo
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of United Nations Security Council Resolution 670, approving an embargo on air traffic with Iraq:       THE SECURITY COUNCIL,    REAFFIRMING its Resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 665 (1990), 666 (1990), and 667 (1990);

headline: Marietta Net Climbs 8.7%
abstract: LEAD: Earnings for the Martin Marietta Corporation, a leading aerospace and military contractor, increased in the second quarter because of the success of several space programs, the company said today.

headline: Durable Goods Orders Down 0.8% in August
abstract: LEAD: Durable goods orders to manufacturers slid eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today. Analysts said the report indicated that there were cutbacks in business investment plans because of Middle East uncertainties.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Leslie Beal has been promoted to assistant media planner at Martin Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis.

headline: New Jersey Backs Plan For Trump
abstract: LEAD: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission unanimously, if somewhat reluctantly, approved a bank loan package yesterday to help rescue Donald J. Trump's real estate and gambling empire.

headline: Patents;   Using a Gene To Prevent Crop Spoilage
abstract: LEAD: A biotechnology company in New Jersey won a patent this week for a method of preventing fruits and vegetables from spoiling by using genetic engineering to enhance their natural defenses against fungus.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amtech Systems Inc., Tempe, Ariz., a maker of semiconductor equipment, said negotiations for the planned acquisition of Tystar Corp., , had ended because of the weak condition of the semiconductor equipment market.

headline: Court Approves Shift at Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said a Federal bankruptcy court had approved an agreement giving a New York investment group control of the company, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The court approval will allow the investors, Japonica Partners, to take control of Allegheny on Aug. 15. The deal, announced on Thursday by committees representing the company's creditors and shareholders, is contingent on

headline: Liberia Peacekeepers Ask Rebel to Quit Port
abstract: LEAD: West African peacekeeping forces called today on the rebel group led by Prince Johnson to pull out from the port area of Monrovia, the Liberian capital.

headline: Zimbabwe Drops Plan For One-Party Statute
abstract: LEAD: In a move seen as a political setback for President Robert Mugabe, the country's governing party decided today to drop its campaign to legalize one-party rule, Mr. Mugabe had made a single-party state a linchpin of his plans for Zimbabwe, formerly the British colony of Rhodesia.

headline: Your Own Account;  The Pitfalls of Retiring Abroad
abstract: LEAD: More and more Americans are retiring abroad, convinced they can achieve a higher standard of living on their retirement income. ''In certain countries, like Poland, a Social Security check goes a long way,'' said Dale R. Detlefs, manager of the Social Security division for William M. Mercer Inc., a New York-based benefits consulting firm.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   As U.S. Forces Build, a Military Stalemate Shapes Up
abstract: LEAD: As American forces pour into Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf, there are signs that a military stalemate between Iraq and the United States is rapidly developing.

headline: Business and Health;   Hospitals Increase Use of Computers
abstract: LEAD: HOSPITALS - long important users of computerized information systems - are considering new products like bedside terminals and increasing their use of existing equipment in the hope of increasing efficiency, reducing costs and improving patient care. Computer makers and health-care consultants say the machines can save time and make life easier for nurses, who are in short supply in many urban areas.

headline: Crisis Spurs Campaign To Save Oil
abstract: LEAD: IN response to the crisis in the Middle East, the Federal Government began a yearlong public service campaign yesterday that urges Americans to ''Do Your Part, Drive Smart.''

headline: More Soviet Oil Urged
abstract: LEAD: Eastern European countries today asked Moscow to catch up on its contracted deliveries of oil in the face of rising world oil prices and falling supplies from the Soviet Union. The request came at a quarterly meeting of senior oil officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland.

headline: Japan Considers a Role in Gulf Force
abstract: LEAD: In what would be Japan's boldest involvement in a possible military confrontation since World War II, the Japanese Government indicated today that it was considering sending nonmilitary support personnel to back American and other forces opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

headline: Tech Notes;   Getting Photographs From Medical Imaging
abstract: LEAD: First there was medical imaging - electronic devices that produce video pictures of structures deep within the body using X-rays, sound waves or magnetic resonance techniques. Now there is a way to directly convert these electronic images into high-quality, instant, black and white photographs printed on film.

headline: New Kodak System for Showing Photos on TV
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to combine traditional picture-taking with electronics, the Eastman Kodak Company plans to sell a system for storing photographs on compact disks and displaying them on television sets and computer screens.

headline: Peruvian Plane Carrying 18 Crashes Off Newfoundland
abstract: LEAD: A Peruvian Boeing 727, believed to have 18 people on board, crashed in the sea 180 miles southeast of Newfoundland today, officials said, but a rescue plane found no wreckage in the area.

headline: Nynex to Release Document
abstract: LEAD: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it would release today a lengthy deposition by Guy M. Struve, a New York lawyer who led a 1988 investigation into lewd parties in Florida attended by a dozen of the company's purchasing managers and employees of some Nynex suppliers.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amerifirst Bank, Miami, said it would eliminate 50 staff and management positions and would decrease its asset size.

headline: Terms of Subaru Deal
abstract: LEAD: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. said last week that Subaru of America Inc. shareholders would receive a payment of $9 in cash for each share as part of the merger that was completed Friday. The merger will make Subaru of America a wholly owned subsidiary of Fuji, the Japanese manufacturer that builds Subaru cars.

headline: Continental Fare Cuts Set
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines said today that it was cutting fares by as much as 57 percent for travel during the next three weekends.

headline: An Experiment in the Catskills;  Elderly Community Linked to Hospital
abstract: LEAD: An experiment in retirement living next door to a general hospital is getting under way in the Catskill Mountains 90 miles northwest of New York City.

headline: Israeli Jets Destroy Lebanon Base Linked to Party of God Terrorism
abstract: LEAD: Israeli jets destroyed a base in southern Lebanon today that belonged to the pro-Iranian Party of God.

headline: Ottawa Gesture to Mohawks
abstract: LEAD: Canada announced today that it had bought a piece of land in an effort to help end a two-week armed standoff between the police and Mohawk Indians. But a Mohawk negotiator, Mavis Etienne, called the purchase ''a drop in the bucket.'' The standoff began after the village of Oka, Quebec, tried to expand a golf course on what the Indians call ancestral land.

headline: Profit? Loss? A Primer for Soviets
abstract: LEAD: Nikolai V. Panteleyev has the unenviable task of creating an accounting profession in a nation unfamiliar with profits and losses, let alone concepts like intangible assets, good will or fair value. He likens the job to teaching people to ''learn Chinese overnight.''

headline: Brazilian Capital Blacked Out
abstract: LEAD: Most of the capital, Brasilia, was without power today, and the Government said it suspected sabotage by striking electricity workers. Officials said four of the five transmission lines serving the area of 1.8 million people were out of action, trapping people in elevators and disrupting businesses.

headline: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Are Continuing to Decline
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts declined in the week ended yesterday. It was the 11th straight weekly drop.

headline: Factory Orders Fell 1.5% in June
abstract: LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. It was the third time this year that the monthly total of orders declined from the month before.

headline: Indian Soldiers Seize 12 Leaders Of Kashmir's Militant Separatists
abstract: LEAD: Indian troops captured the chief military commander of Kashmir's independence movement and 11 other militant leaders in Srinagar today as the Kashmiris met to discuss strategy, the authorities said.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Humorlessly, a Long-Ruling Party Looks at Itself
abstract: LEAD: Mocked by the people, scolded by its leader and stripped of its monopoly, the Communist Party settled into town today in something of a red funk, a septuagenarian patronage machine in need of a new patron.

headline: WHITE HOUSE BARS IRAQ FURNACE SALE
abstract: LEAD: The White House moved today to block the shipment of three advanced industrial furnaces to Iraq because of concern that they will be used on nuclear weapons-related projects.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Australian Meat and Livestock Corp., to Brouillard/LGFE, for the Fresh Australian Range Lamb program.

headline: Prices Rise on Treasury Issues
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in light trading yesterday, as market participants cautiously bought securities after reports circulated among traders that Washington budget talks were close to an agreement to cut the Federal budget deficit.

headline: Pinochet Irks Bonn With Potshots at Army
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Augusto Pinochet set off a diplomatic commotion with the West German Government this week by asserting that the reorganization of the German military after World War II had produced an army of ''drug addicts, long hairs, gays and union members.''

headline: Domino's Pizza In Marriott Pact
abstract: LEAD: Domino's Pizza will be on the menu at schools around the nation under an agreement the pizza delivery company signed with the Marriott Corporation. A subsidiary of Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., manages school lunch programs at more than 200 United States school districts, serving 120 million meals a year.

headline: Acquisitions By Japanese Rise Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Japanese purchases of American companies jumped sharply in the first half of this year, while American purchases in Japan remained small.

headline: Stocks Plunge in Manila
abstract: LEAD: Share prices in Manila sank today to 40-month lows after a bomb exploded on the first day of talks on the future of United States military bases in the Philippines, brokers said. Manila's composite index slid 10.18 points to close at 615.39, its lowest since recording 610.59 on May 29, 1987. Depreciation of the Philippine peso to an all-time low of 26 to the dollar, from 15, and violent street protests on Monday by students opposed to the bases weighed down the market at the opening, analysts said.

headline: Order for Blockade Largely Isolates U.S. At Security Council
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration's announcement that American warships are enforcing United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq left the United States largely isolated today at the Security Council, with most of the 15 members saying a new Council decision would be needed before military force could be used.

headline: Cray President Leaves In Rift With Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Marcelo A. Gumucio, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research Inc., resigned yesterday, saying that he and Cray's chairman, John A. Rollwagen, had agreed that their contrasting management styles made it impossible to work together.

headline: President Is Appointed For Monarch Capital
abstract: LEAD: Roger T. Servison, a marketer who helped to build Fidelity Investments into a mutual fund giant, is leaving to become president of the Monarch Capital Corporation, which sells insurance and annuities.

headline: Rise in Home Affordability
abstract: LEAD: Rising incomes and falling mortgage rates and prices enhanced the typical American family's ability to buy an existing single-family home in May.      The National Association of

headline: Badly Divided Arab League Votes To Return Headquarters to Cairo
abstract: LEAD: A bare majority of the Arab League crystallized the split in the Arab world tonight by voting to move the League's headquarters from Tunis back to Cairo.

headline: New Funds Bailing Out Bad Buyouts
abstract: LEAD: A $1 billion fund raised last week by two Chicago investors who make up the Zell/Chilmark limited partnership is a sign of how finance in the 1990's will differ from the 1980's.

headline: Officer Quits At Wasserstein
abstract: LEAD: Toby S. Myerson, a managing director at Wasserstein, Perella & Company in charge of East Asian operations, announced yesterday that he was rejoining his former law firm.

headline: Ulster Negotiations Delayed As Dublin Considers Its Role
abstract: LEAD: British and Irish officials said today that the unresolved question of when Dublin would enter proposed talks about returning a large degree of self-rule to Northern Ireland remained an obstacle to setting a date in the fall for beginning negotiations.

headline: Putting the Oil Reserve to the Test
abstract: LEAD: As the Government prepares to sell oil from the nation's emergency petroleum reserve for only the second time, experts across the industry agree that the extra oil should prevent any shortages even if there is a prolonged loss of imports from Iraq and Kuwait.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Liberating Machines From Keyboards
abstract: LEAD: One big obstacle to a wider adoption of computers is the keyboard. ''I had not even touched a computer before I came here, because I never learned how to type,'' confessed a man recently hired as a senior marketing executive by a large computer company. He has now learned to type - and to use a computer.

headline: Market Place;   Judge Upholds Bondholders In Home Shopping Case
abstract: LEAD: A Delaware judge ruled yesterday that Home Shopping Network Inc., which made millions of dollars at the expense of its bondholders, did so by cheating those investors.

headline: A G.M. Car With a Japanese Feel
abstract: LEAD: The Saturn, the soon-to-be-introduced car that General Motors has for five years heralded as an import fighter, lives up to the company's game plan: It feels and drives very much like a Japanese car.

headline: President Appointed At Plymouth Lamston
abstract: LEAD: Robert Tammero, who has been president both of Bloomingdale's and of Abraham & Straus, the New York store divisions of Federated Department Stores, has been named president of the Plymouth Lamston Stores Corporation, which is owned by Tribeca Holding Corporation, a New York-based investment firm.

headline: Iraq Tightens Its Food Rationing, Cutting Allowances Another 50%
abstract: LEAD: Less than two weeks after Iraq imposed food rationing to combat the United Nations trade embargo, President Saddam Hussein's Government announced today that it was cutting up to 50 percent of previous allowances for scarce foods and further restricting daily bread rations, reports here said.

headline: Sri Lankan Army Is Closing In on a Citadel of Resistance by Tamil Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Sri Lankan Army is closing in on Jaffna, the citadel and city that have symbolized Tamil resistance in an ethnic conflict that has torn apart South Asia's most developed nation.

headline: Citicorp Posts 37% Drop in Net
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that its earnings fell 37 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, despite continued growth in its highly profitable consumer banking businesses.

headline: Sandinista Leadership Rethinking Its Ideology
abstract: LEAD: In the past, Sandinista leaders reserved terms like ''coercion,'' ''authoritarianism'' and ''abuse of power'' to describe mortal enemies like the deposed Somoza dictatorship and the Reagan White House. Now, the Sandinistas have turned that language on a new target: themselves.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.06   8.12    8.87        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.49   7.46   7.99        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.48   7.48   7.92        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.75   8.90   8.31        30-YR.

headline: Managing;   Turning a Boss Into a Client
abstract: LEAD: Kathryn H. Tunheim liked her job as Honeywell Inc.'s vice president of public relations, but she was hankering for the excitement of running a profit center. Honeywell, meanwhile, wanted to halve the head count in Ms. Tunheim's department.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * CBS Records, New York, a subsidiary of the Sony Corporation of America, named Jon R. Peisinger president of its music video enterprises division.

headline: Money-Fund Yields Down
abstract: LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Tunis, Long Friendly to West, Bristles With Hostility to U.S. Gulf Moves
abstract: LEAD: When the United States began dispatching forces in the Persian Gulf crisis, Tunisia was one of the Arab countries whose support the United States took virtually for granted, Western diplomats and Tunisian officials here said.

headline: Renault-Avia Pact
abstract: LEAD: Renault, the state-owned French car company, will lend 500 million francs (about $94 million) to the Prague-based vehicle manufacturer Avia to help it produce a new range of light trucks, the state news agency C.T.K. reported. It said the deal was completed by Renault's president, Raymond Levy, during the visit of the French President, Francois Mitterrand, to Czechoslovakia on Thursday and today.

headline: Hijacker Sent Back to Moscow, With a Message
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet teen-ager who forced a passenger plane to go to Sweden last month because he was fed up with life in the Soviet Union was returned to Moscow today. Soviet officials hailed his extradition as a breakthrough in this country's struggle against a remarkable epidemic of hijackings.

headline: Economic Scene;   Deregulation: The Good News
abstract: LEAD: WHEN most people think about deregulation these days they are apt to focus on the dubious pleasures of selecting a long-distance phone company or pleading for service from the local cable television monopolist - or worse, on the sheer gall of the savings and loan bandits who made off with the keys to the United States

headline: The Appliance Brand-Name Game
abstract: LEAD: At Abt Television and Appliance here in this Chicago suburb, no fewer than 15 models of washers and dryers crowd the showroom. So why is Kitchen Aid, a Whirlpool subsidiary best known for its premium dishwashers and heavy-duty mixers, muscling into the market with its own brand of laundry appliances?

headline: Success Looms for Maker Of Civil War Film Series
abstract: LEAD: Ken Burns, the film maker whose epic documentary, ''The Civil War'' has been called a television masterpiece and the best American film of the year, is ''very guarded'' about how success may change his life.

headline: Nissan Adds New Model Of Infiniti Car
abstract: LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company, whose Infiniti luxury division has had a rocky start in the United States, introduced its 1991 lineup today, including a new midsized sedan in the $20,000 range -below the price of competing luxury cars like the smallest Mercedes-Benz and BMW models.

headline: Milton Roy Sets Sundstrand Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Milton Roy Company, a waste-water equipment maker that recently received a $160 million buyout offer from the Sundstrand Corporation, said its board had authorized talks with Sundstrand about the unsolicited offer.

headline: Savings Crime Bill Advances
abstract: LEAD: The House today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would strengthen criminal penalties for crimes involving savings and loan institutions and create a special national commission to study the causes of the savings and loan debacle.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Jeffrey Soinski has joined Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., New York, as vice president and management supervisor. Margot Pitlor has joined as an account executive.

headline: June Level Of Borrowing Rose Slightly
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board said today that consumers repaid car loans much faster than they took out new ones in June, a fresh sign of shrinking economic activity that slowed credit expansion.

headline: Wall Street;   If You Believe in Domestic Oil . . .
abstract: LEAD: The stock market just can't seem to make up its mind about oil.

headline: Syrian Says Israeli Raids Hinder Hostage Release
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Minister of Syria, Farouk al-Sharaa, accused Israel today of causing a delay in the release of a Western hostage by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon, but promised that his country and Iran would continue their efforts to gain the captives' release.

headline: 20 Killed in Shootout in Kashmir
abstract: LEAD: At least 20 people were killed in Kashmir today when their bus exploded after Indian security forces fired at suspected militants traveling in the vehicle, the authorities said.

headline: Dean Witter to Appeal
abstract: LEAD: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said this week that it would appeal a court ruling ordering it to pay $23.4 million to Daniel Waite, a former commodities broker who was dismissed in 1982. Mr. Waite contended that Dean Witter, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, had libeled and slandered him in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and in a statement to a potential employer.

headline: Nissan Motor
abstract: LEAD: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation introduced a redesigned 1991 Sentra that will be aimed at more affluent buyers. The base cost will be $7,999, up from $7,399. The introduction of the model at Nissan's Smyrna, Tenn., plant rounds out a new generation of cars and trucks offered by the Japanese manufacturer since 1988.

headline: 2 Debtors' Role in Silverado's Fall
abstract: LEAD: They were the highest of the highfliers, pillars of Denver's business and social communities, with dreams of reshaping the city's skyline and suburban shopping habits.

headline: U.S. Says It Is Ready to Cut Philippine Force
abstract: LEAD: The United States Government is prepared to reduce its military forces in the Philippines, an American official said today as talks on American bases opened.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Iraq's Statement on Kuwait
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from a statement today by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council of Iraq announcing Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, as translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation:

headline: Japanese-American Cultural Clash
abstract: LEAD: John Artise's frequent tip to Japanese managers - ''Don't ask a job applicant personal questions.'' - is often greeted with surprise. Without information on employees' religion, upbringing or home life, Japanese managers ask him, ''How are we going to know them and trust them?''

headline: Tisch Raises Stake In Bank of Boston
abstract: LEAD: Laurence A. Tisch, the president of CBS Inc., and members of his family have raised their stake in the Bank of Boston Corporation to 9.9 percent from 8.9 percent. They also said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that they might seek permission from the Federal Reserve Board to buy up to 15 percent of the Boston-based company.

headline: Mortgage Rate Down
abstract: LEAD: Interest on fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.98 percent last week, down from 9.99 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released last week by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the second consecutive week that fixed-rate mortgages were below 10 percent. The last time that occurred was in mid-January.

headline: Move by Ethics Panel Urged On Senators Tied to Keating
abstract: LEAD: The special counsel to the Senate Ethics Committee has recommended that the panel move forward in its inquiry on allegations that five Senators improperly intervened on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., Congressional officials said today.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * G.C.I. Group Inc., a public relations unit of Grey Advertising, New York, has acquired McAvoy Wreford Bayley, a financial consultancy, from the V.P.I. Group, London. Additionally, G.C.I. sold a minority share to the management of the aquired company, which will be known as McAvoy Bayley.

headline: Sri Lanka Rebels Said to Kill 35 Muslim Bus Passengers
abstract: LEAD: Tamil rebels stopped three buses and shot to death at least 35 Muslim passengers in eastern Sri Lanka, Defense Ministry officials said today.

headline: Philip Morris Names Tobacco Unit Leader
abstract: LEAD: Philip Morris Industries, the world's largest consumer-products company, said yesterday that it had named a new president for Philip Morris USA, its primary tobacco subsidiary and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes.

headline: British Aerospace To Fight Ruling
abstract: LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it would appeal a European Commission order that it repay illegal Government subsidies it received when it bought the formerly state-owned Rover car maker. British Aerospace said it would appeal to the European Court of Justice the order to repay $:44.4 million, or about $80 million.

headline: Bank Insurance Ceiling Backed
abstract: LEAD: A top Treasury Department official urged today that the current ceiling of $100,000 for deposit insurance coverage on individual accounts in banks and savings and loan associations be kept.

headline: K Mart to Acquire Stake in Officemax
abstract: LEAD: The K Mart Corporation has agreed to buy a 22 percent stake in Officemax, a chain of office supply stores. Terms were not disclosed. Officemax, a privately held chain based in Cleveland, also agreed to acquire the Office Square business of a K Mart subsidiary. Under the cash deal, K Mart also has the right to increase its stake in

headline: Japanese Gain In Beer Output
abstract: LEAD: Japan became the world's fourth-largest beer brewer last year, surpassing Britain, the Kirin Brewery Company, Japan's biggest, said on Thursday.

headline: Your Money;   Ways to Avoid Emotional Moves
abstract: LEAD: Although it is too early to gauge the wisdom of the investors who made sudden market moves - trading for oil shares or dumping stocks - almost as soon as Iraq invaded Kuwait, such moves are generally a mistake for individuals. Patience is more likely to be rewarded, as it has been since the crash of October 1987.

headline: Finance/New Issues;   Avco Financial
abstract: LEAD: Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are offered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.95 percent, or about 85 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Hussein Hardens Line, Saying Sanctions Deprive Children of Milk
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein renewed his call today for a holy war against American forces in the Persian Gulf and for the toppling of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

headline: Serbia Referendum Snubbed By the Albanians in Kosovo
abstract: LEAD: Voters in Serbia cast ballots today in a referendum whose passage could delay free, multiparty elections and reduce the autonomy of the Yugoslav republic's restive Kosovo region.

headline: 5,000 Positions To Be Cut at Volvo
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish car maker Volvo said it would cut 5,000 jobs this year and next because profits in the first six months of 1990 have declined by half. The company has already dropped 1,000 employees in the car and truck sector this year and plans to reduce the work force by another 4,000 through 1991.

headline: Iraqi Document: A Correction
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, excerpts last Sunday from a document described by the Iraqi Government as a transcript of a meeting between President Saddam Hussein and the United States Ambassador to Iraq misattributed some remarks. The following remarks should have been attributed to President Hussein, not to Ambassador April C.

headline: Kuwaiti Oil Concern Seeks Saudi Supply
abstract: LEAD: Kuwait's London-based overseas marketing and refining company said today that it was negotiating with Saudi Arabia to supply some of the 400,000 barrels of crude oil and refined products that it had received from Kuwait each day before the Iraqi invasion.

headline: Treasury Bonds Soar in Late Rally
abstract: LEAD: A late rally sent prices of Treasury bonds soaring yesterday after a further flight from stocks had lifted prices of the shorter maturities earlier in the session.

abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Complains About Barricade Around Its Main Office in Havana
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today that it was displeased with a barricade erected by the Cuban police in Havana around three sides of the United States interests section in Havana.

headline: AIR FORCE CHIEF IS DISMISSED FOR REMARKS ON GULF PLAN; CHENEY CITES BAD JUDGMENT
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney abruptly dismissed the Air Force's top-ranking officer today for publicly discussing Pentagon contingency plans for waging a war against Iraq, including specific targets for American air strikes.

headline: Smick Medley Adds a Name
abstract: LEAD: Manuel H. Johnson, who resigned earlier this year as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has joined the consulting firm of Smick Medley International Inc., the firm said yesterday.      The firm plans to call itself

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Man in the News;   The Exiled Emir: Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah
abstract: LEAD: One of the first tasks assigned to Iraqi troops when they invaded Kuwait in the early hours of Aug. 2 was to capture or kill Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait. Alerted early in the morning about the invasion, the Emir fled in a car to Saudi Arabia, minutes before the first Iraqis soldiers entered the grounds of Dasman

headline: USX Will Pay $34 Million For Wastewater Cleanup
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation has agreed to pay $34 million in costs and penalties for the cleanup of wastewater that was illegally dumped from its Gary, Ind., steel mill, Federal officials said today.

headline: Jordanians Meet Frustration In Search for 'Arab Solution'
abstract: LEAD: As Iraqi troops were storming toward Kuwait City on Aug. 2, King Hussein of Jordan was awakened at 6 A.M. by a phone call from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Curb on Textile Imports Is Passed by the House
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives today passed by 271 to 149 a bill already approved in the Senate to restrict imports of apparel and shoes. But the vote was short of the two-thirds majority needed to override a promised Presidential veto.

headline: FORUM;  A Different Savings and Loan Villain
abstract: LEAD: The savings and loan crisis, which may cost taxpayers $500 billion or more, was precipitated by the passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. This measure could not have been passed at a more inauspicious moment.

headline: Flow of Asians Fleeing Iraq Has Eased, Jordan Reports
abstract: LEAD: Jordanian officials said today that the immediate crisis caused by the influx of Asians fleeing Kuwait had begun to recede, with only 46,000 people remaining in transit camps that held more than twice as many a week ago.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Evacuation of Hostages Is Stalled As Iraqis Prohibit Foreign Flights
abstract: LEAD: A handful of Western women and children detained in Iraq or Kuwait for weeks flew out of here today, but plans to evacuate hundreds more were complicated by the Iraqi Government's refusal to grant landing rights to planes from other nations.

headline: 700 Women and Children Freed; Thousands of Westerners Remain
abstract: LEAD: More than 700 foreign women and children who had been detained in Iraq as human shields against an American military attack headed for home in the United States, Europe and Asia early today after being released by the Iraqi Government.

headline: Shearson and 2 Ex-Workers Face Fraud Charges in Ohio
abstract: LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and two former employees in Ohio have been accused of fraud in the sale of securities, Ohio officials said today.

headline: Japan-Europe Car Pact
abstract: LEAD: European Community officials said off the record today that the community and Japan were close to a deal under which Japanese car producers would be allowed to increase market share in Europe to almost double by 1999, when all quotas would be scrapped. The pact, which will set the pace at which the 12-nation bloc liberalizes its partly protected car market, will be an informal arrangement, the officials said.

headline: Crackdown in a 'Freer' Korea Puzzles Opposition
abstract: LEAD: Two years ago this summer Kim Keun Tae was out of jail for the first time in years, his release hailed as a harbinger that South Korea's new, more democratic Government was willing to tolerate dissent and end a decade of systematic repression.

headline: Economic Scene;   The Evidence Backs Greenspan
abstract: LEAD: IN his testimony this week on the midyear state of the economy, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, seemed to be tiptoeing through a mine field, spread with the dangers of recession, inflation, a worsening budget deficit and a weakened financial structure in the private sector.

headline: Leftist Palestinian Leaders Rally Arab Support for Iraq
abstract: LEAD: They were greeted like rock stars as they strode into the crowded hall. But the radical Palestinian leaders George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh today offered a packed convention of supporters little advice that seemed likely to help pull the Palestinian cause out of its current difficulty.

headline: Study Finds 'Uncounted' TV Viewers
abstract: LEAD: Hoping to attract more advertising to summer programs, ABC released a study yesterday that it said showed that millions of viewers watching television during summer vacations are not being counted in the regular Nielsen ratings.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ukraine Asks Moscow To Return Its Recruits
abstract: LEAD: The Ukraine, stepping up its defiance of Moscow, called today for the return of all Ukrainians doing compulsory service in the Soviet armed forces.

headline: Texas Instruments
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. said it would start a print advertising campaign to convince parents of the importance of education. The ads, created by McCann-Erickson, are not wholly altruistic; they point out how the company's calculators and other products can help American children compete in the global economy.

headline: 2 Contractors' Ratings Cut
abstract: LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced the debt ratings of two large military contractors, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation. Moody's Investors Service also cut the ratings of McDonnell Douglas.

headline: Pepsico Drink Deal
abstract: LEAD: Pepsico Inc. said it had signed an exclusive five-year contract to supply soft drinks to Ponderosa and Bonanza restaurants beginning next month. No financial details were released. The Metromedia Company owns the 1,200 Ponderosa and Bonanza locations.

headline: South China Floods Kill 108
abstract: LEAD: Floods caused by a typhoon have killed 108 people in China's southern coastal provinces of Guangdong and Fujian over the last week, an official report said today. The state flood control headquarters, quoted by the official New China News Agency, said the typhoon flooded 695,000 acres of farmland in the two provinces and destroyed 25,200 houses in Guangdong.

headline: Real Estate;  New Towers Push Toward Ohio River
abstract: LEAD: A $150 MILLION twin-tower office complex to be built over the next five years along Third Street here is the latest in a wave of development that is pushing the commercial district south toward the Ohio River.

headline: Purchasers Report Fall In Growth
abstract: LEAD: A monthly survey released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated a steep decline for the nation's manufacturing economy in July, reversing a three-month growth trend. Economists said the survey gave more credence to assessments that the economy is slowing, perhaps slipping into a recession.

headline: Premier of Trinidad Offers to Quit if Rebels End Coup
abstract: LEAD: Trinidad and Tobago's security chief said today there was scant hope of an early breakthrough in negotiations for the release of Prime Minister Arthur N .R. Robinson, who was taken hostage on Friday in a coup attempt by Muslim rebels and reportedly wired to explosives.

headline: A Mechanical Milkmaid: Will Cows Be Content?
abstract: LEAD: Robots have cleaned up nuclear power plants, assembled electronic devices and painted cars, but are they ready for one of mankind's oldest jobs - milking cows?

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds increased by $6.03 billion, to $401.94 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $1.39 billion, to $100.29 billion; 249 general-purpose funds were up by $3.7 billion, to $139.42 billion, and 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $946.9 million, to $162.24 billion, the institute said.

headline: Tech Notes;   Images of an Atom From an Electron Microscope
abstract: LEAD: With conventional electron microscopes, the material under study is illuminated with a broad beam of electrons. The electrons strike the object, are scattered, detected and then converted into an image. Because the electrons are scattered, image resolution is too poor to see individual atoms. Now, a team of researchers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratories in Tennessee has developed a microscope based on what they call Z-contrast imaging.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Home Products Corp. and Microgenesys Inc. have agreed to develop jointly Microgenesys's anti-AIDS product Vaxsyn HIV-1. The product is currently being tested.

headline: Inc. Magazine Plans A Version for Soviets
abstract: LEAD: Bernard A. Goldhirsh, the chairman of the Goldhirsh Publishing Group, said yesterday that a Russian-language version of Inc. magazine would be published in the Soviet Union, beginning in mid-1991.

headline: Polaroid to Build $90 Million Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said it planned to build a $90 million plant in New Bedford, Mass., to make advanced films for its new electronic imaging system called Helios. The plant is expected to be operating in late 1992, and it will create more than 100 jobs. Polaroid's president and chief executive, I.

abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Chip Sales Are Forecast
abstract: LEAD: A trade group predicted today that worldwide semiconductor sales will be essentially flat in 1990 but will return to double-digit growth in 1991 and remain so through 1993.

headline: Greek Publisher and Editor Sentenced in Phone-Tapping
abstract: LEAD: An appeals court has upheld the conviction of the publisher and the former managing editor of a Greek newspaper in the phone-tapping of the New York Times bureau in Athens, a court spokesman said today.

headline: Ashton-Tate Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Company, a computer-software producer based in Torrance, Calif., said it would introduce a new version of its dBASE IV software next Tuesday, but it cautioned against expectations that the product would help the company return quickly to profitability. A spokeswoman said the software, called dBASE IV Version 1.1, would be introduced to analysts and the media in New York.

headline: Above Southern France, a Ballet Against Fire
abstract: LEAD: The cool wind stirred in the morning, and hit 60 miles an hour by midday. Comdr. Robert Bardo, the chief fire-control officer for the 15 departments in Provence, sensed smoke in the air.

headline: He Didn't Ask, but Here's Some Advice for G.M.'s Bob Stempel
abstract: LEAD: THE General Motors Corporation got a new chairman last week: Robert C. Stempel, 57 years old, who joined G.M. in 1958 and rose through the ranks as an engineer. Gone is Roger B. Smith, 65, who retired after a turbulent decade marked by record profitability as well as a steady decline in market share.

headline: Foes of Mubarak Question U.S. Aims and Are Barred From Peace Journey
abstract: LEAD: As the magnitude of American military involvement in the Persian Gulf becomes increasingly clear to them, opposition politicians in Egypt have begun to question Washington's long-term intentions in the region and Cairo's close association with them.

headline: Manpower to Sell Some British Units
abstract: LEAD: Manpower P.L.C. said it had agreed to sell some of its British operations to a new company organized by affiliates of Prudential Venture Managers, Charterhouse P.L.C. and the Chase Manhattan Bank and including the executive directors of Manpower's Brook Street unit.

headline: Company News;   New Chairman of G.M. Promises Period of Stability
abstract: LEAD: Robert C. Stempel, the new chairman of the General Motors Corporation, promised on his first day in office today that the auto maker would not pursue a strategy of reorganization like the one that caused turmoil in the world's biggest auto maker in the 1980's.

headline: C.I.A. Fears Iraq Could Deploy Biological Arms by Early 1991
abstract: LEAD: Iraq has developed biological weapons that will be able to deliver significant quantities of the deadly agents on the battlefield by early next year, according to American intelligence reports.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: The economic summit of industrialized nations begins in Houston. Through Wednesday.    A 1,700-mile, 10-day race among 32 solar-powered cars begins in Orlando, Fla.    Consumer credit for May.       TUESDAY: Wholesale trade for May.    PC World Forum/Moscow, through Sunday.       WEDNESDAY: The Senate Banking Committee considers jurisdictional disputes between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: All About/Watches;   Watchmakers Are Ringing The Old Back In, as a Varied Industry Revives and Thrives
abstract: LEAD: If the modern watch industry had a theme song, it would probably be Peter Allen's ''Everything Old Is New Again.'' Mechanical watches, which all but ceded the market to quartz movements more than a decade ago, are best-sellers again. Analog faces, the ones with big hands and little hands, have recaptured a chunk of the market from digital displays.

headline: Nabisco Refinance Plan Set
abstract: LEAD: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said last night that it would begin its $6.9 billion refinancing program today, buying back some of its high-yield ''junk bonds'' in the open market, receiving additional equity and securing new bank loans.

headline: Chinese Dissident Criticizes U.S. on Human Rights
abstract: LEAD: Fang Lizhi, China's leading dissident, said in an interview broadcast tonight that the United States had a ''double standard'' for human rights that was tougher on the Soviet Union than on China.

headline: Business Diary
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       The Power of the Pencil at Eastern       For an airline to boast of correcting vital maintenance and repair problems is hardly the path to recovery. Who on Madison Avenue could craft a campaign around a message like this? But claims of ''full corrective action'' were the essence of Eastern Airlines' response to an indictment last Wednesday on 60 counts of ignoring upkeep and falsifying records - ''pencil whipping,'' as it was called.

headline: President of Turkey Advises Preparing for Military Role
abstract: LEAD: President Turgut Ozal, who has thrown Turkey's weight behind the United Nations sanctions against Iraq, prepared his people today for a possible military role in the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Business Scene;   How Fast to Shift To Free Markets
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Eastern European countries emerged from Communism last fall, there was much theorizing about how quickly they should make the transition to free markets. Many economists, in the East and the West, argued for a go-slow strategy to reduce the pain of unemployment and other social hardships.

headline: Alleghany Raises Stake in Cyclops
abstract: LEAD: The Alleghany Corporation, the New York-based financial services concern, has raised its stake in Cyclops Industries, the Pittsburgh-based steel company, to 10.7 percent, from 8.4 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Alleghany said it might acquire more Cyclops shares, depending upon market conditions, or it might seek to dispose of its stock.

headline: Khomeini's Tomb Attracts Pilgrims
abstract: LEAD: Here on the barren, sun-parched flats on the southern outskirts of Teheran, the Iranian Government is building a shrine to rival all but the greatest attractions of Islam - the final resting place for the man known here simply as the Imam.

headline: Pepsico Official Gets A Top Toys 'R' Us Job
abstract: LEAD: Toys ''R'' Us, the world's largest toy retailer, named a Pepsico Inc. executive, Larry D. Bouts, yesterday to head its fast-growing international business.

headline: Renewed Call For Chinese Stock Market
abstract: LEAD: After two difficult years of stop-and-go progress, a group of ambitious economic experts has taken another small step toward developing a centralized securities market in China.

abstract: LEAD: Amid signs that the Federal Reserve had acted to lower interest rates, the Dow Jones industrial average briefly broke through the magical 3,000 barrier yesterday.

headline: Hurricane Sets Off Floods, Killing at Least 23 in Mexico
abstract: LEAD: A hurricane killed at least 23 people this week when raging torrents swept into a river valley in eastern Mexico, devastating homes, roads and farmland, the authorities said today.

headline: President's Son Backed At Hearing on Conflicts
abstract: LEAD: The Government's leadoff witness at the hearing on conflict-of-interest charges against Neil Bush today supported Mr. Bush's contention that his fellow directors at a Denver savings and loan knew he had an interest in a partnership that was given a $900,000 line of credit.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Here Comes the S.E.C. on Fees
abstract: LEAD: In late August, Richard C. Breeden, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and members of his staff shared a birthday cake with members of the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry trade group. The occasion: the golden anniversary of the Investment Company Act of 1940, the law that regulates mutual funds.

headline: Yugo America Account To Buckley/DeCerchio
abstract: LEAD: Buckley/DeCerchio Advertising got a great gift to celebrate its second anniversary - the $8 million to $10 million account for Yugo America cars.

headline: Bonds Mixed Despite Jump in Oil
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in sluggish trading, as dealers ignored another big jump in oil prices and instead prepared for this morning's release of the August employment data.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Ambase Corp., an insurance concern, ended talks to sell its United States International Reinsurance Co.

headline: Kompong Chhnang Journal;   In a Sad Land, Hide and Seek With Khmer Rouge
abstract: LEAD: It is quiet now near the little town of Mnok, on the rail line between Battambang and Phnom Penh. On July 15, it was the site of one of the worst atrocities of this stage of the 20-year-old Cambodian war.

headline: Pressure Is Mounting to Tap U.S. Oil Stockpile
abstract: LEAD: After weeks of resisting calls to use the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to soften the impact of soaring oil prices, the Administration is feeling growing pressure from both Congress and its own ranks to change its strategy. And events could conspire to hasten a decision that Republicans could find politically advantageous.

headline: Careers;   Dual Majors Are Gaining Popularity
abstract: LEAD: IN an increasingly complex world, more students are considering whether to seek double majors at the undergraduate level. These double degrees not only enhance their chances of getting a job but also serve as a springboard to double majors in graduate school.

headline: Stock Fight By Murdoch
abstract: LEAD: Rupert Murdoch's global media and entertainment company, the News Corporation, has threatened to shift its headquarters outside Australia if it is not allowed to change its stock structure, according to newspaper reports today.

headline: Dallas Fed's President
abstract: LEAD: Robert D. McTeer Jr. has been named president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas effective in February. Mr. McTeer, who is 47 years old, replaces Robert H. Boykin, who is retiring after 37 years with the Dallas reserve bank. Mr. McTeer is senior vice president of the Baltimore branch of the Federal Reserve Bank in Richmond.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Remarks on Germany Prompt Tory Upheaval
abstract: LEAD: Anti-German remarks by one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's closest Cabinet allies has plunged her Government into crisis and forced its deep divisions over the European Community into the open.

headline: Industry Group Approves Incorporation of Accountants
abstract: LEAD: In a sharp break with tradition, the directors of the leading oversight body of the accounting profession voted at their July meeting to allow accountants to organize their practices as corporations.

headline: Suit Filed by Mitel Against A.T.&T.
abstract: LEAD: The Mitel Corporation, a Canadian telecommunications systems manufacturer, has sued the American Telephone and Telegragh Company in a Florida court for taking ''predatory actions'' against it.

abstract: LEAD: When measuring mutual fund performance, investors typically rely on a fund's total return - income plus change in asset value - as the best gauge of success. But this approach as a guide for where to invest can prove dangerous if the risk that a fund takes to earn its return is ignored.
