abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the address on the Persian Gulf crisis made by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, carried by Baghdad radio and the official Iraqi News Agency and translated from Arabic by The Associated Press:

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   Oil Prices Increase Sharply Again; World Financial Markets Tumble
abstract: LEAD: Oil prices rose sharply again yesterday and financial markets around the world plummeted as the international embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be taking hold.

headline: Dollar Drops Against Yen in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The dollar fell below 150 yen in slow European trading today amid growing speculation that interest rates will decline in the United States.

headline: Romanians Look Anew at Wartime Dictator
abstract: LEAD: For more than 40 years under Communist rule the 23d of August was National Day, marking the day in 1944 when Romania turned against its Nazi allies, declaring a unilateral armistice in its war with the Allies.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Font & Vaamonde Inc., New York, the Hispanic agency partner of Grey Advertising, has opened a public relations office in New York. It will be called FoVa Public Relations.

headline: Treasury Securities Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday and interest rates dipped in light trading, as dealers began to position themselves for tomorrow's release of August employment data.

headline: Electronic Data Systems And G.M.A.C. in Profit Rise
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation posted solid second-quarter earnings gains, but profits slipped 21.3 percent at the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which includes Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics.

headline: Hong Kong Unsure of Value of Refugee Pact
abstract: LEAD: When a new accord on the return of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong's crowded detention camps was announced last weekend, Government officials here hailed it a breakthrough. But in the past few days, officials have admitted no one is certain if the program will have any effect at all.

headline: Kuwaiti Washington Embassy Embattled Too
abstract: LEAD: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has thrown Kuwait's embassy here into turmoil and left Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah in the diplomatically precarious role of representing the exile government of an occupied country.

headline: Official Quits Italian Concern
abstract: LEAD: The top executive of the Italian chemicals company Enimont S.p.A. said last week that he was resigning because the company was unmanageable.

headline: Gulf Premium Added by Lloyd's
abstract: LEAD: In reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, marine underwriters in the Lloyd's of London insurance market have added a premium for ships traveling in the Persian Gulf.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly       SPECIAL COMMITTEE OF 24 - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.    SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Baker Talks of Threat On Embassy in Iraq
abstract: LEAD: The United States has received a warning from the Iraqi authorities threatening the death penalty for anyone harboring foreigners at the American Embassy in Baghdad, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today.

headline: Chrysler Delay On Luxury Car
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, which has said its financial problems would not hurt new-product development, said today that it would delay the development of its LX luxury car program.

headline: Wall Street;   Who Is Causing the Selling Pressure at AT&E?
abstract: LEAD: Everyone agrees that the next few months will be critical for the AT&E Corporation, the San Francisco company that will finally start marketing its wristwatch paging device in Portland, Ore., in the next few weeks. Even if the long-promised product works, of course, the company's optimism about sales might not be borne out, but a flop would make disputes over sales projections totally moot.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Smokers Vow Strikes As Cigarettes, Too, Disappear
abstract: LEAD: It happens like clockwork, all over the city. A truck pulls up to a boarded-up kiosk, unloads its wares, the sale window opens and within minutes smokers appear out of nowhere to take places in line, hopeful that for this day, anyway, their addiction can be fed.

headline: Even for J. Crew, the Mail-Order Boom Days Are Over
abstract: LEAD: Fourteen times a year it shows up, sandwiched between electric bills and sweepstakes come-ons, prompting a flash of recognition. There are more than 100 pages decorated with exultant models in rugby shirts, twill trousers and espadrilles, presented in meticulously shot photographs - the culmination of 8,000 rolls of film a year.

headline: Company News;   Whirlpool Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company formed a venture to operate Whirlpool's 750-employee vacuum cleaner plant in Danville, Ky. Terms were not disclosed, but Whirlpool will retain a large minority interest in the venture. Whirlpool vacuum cleaners at the plant under the Kenmore name for Sears, Roebuck & Company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Fuqua Industries, Atlanta, a consumer products company, promoted James M. Bahin to senior vice president for operations and John F. Bartels to senior vice president and chief financial officer. Colin W. Brown was promoted to senior vice president, general counsel and secretary, and James R. Foster was promoted to senior vice president for finance and corporate development and treasurer.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST, 24, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          Markets

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.93   8.00    8.93        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.40   7.41   7.93        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.29   7.29   7.66        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.54   8.52   8.06        30-YR.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iran's Quandary: Yesterday's Foe Today's Friend?
abstract: LEAD: Ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait seven days ago, Iran has kept markedly quiet, assailing the Iraqi move but saying little else about the expanding crisis in the Persian Gulf, an area that Teheran has traditionally viewed as its sphere of prime concern and influence.      Now that the United

headline: British Plea to Workers
abstract: LEAD: The British Government urged workers today to hold down demands for higher wages as the country's unemployment rate increased for the third straight month. The number of people out of work in June rose by 5,600, to a seasonally adjusted 1.62 million, or 5.7 percent of the work force, unchanged from May's revised figure, the Department of Employment said.

headline: Patents;   Protecting Child From Electric Plug
abstract: LEAD: An inventor in Des Moines, Mark Menninga, obtained a patent this week on a magnetically controlled device to help parents ''baby proof'' their homes by blocking a child's access to electrical plugs.

headline: A Crisis Builds At Jordan Sites Housing Asians
abstract: LEAD: Asian refugees from Kuwait and Iraq continue to pour into Jordan's desert refugee camps at the rate of 10,000 a day, relief officials said today.

headline: Curb on Some Program Trades to Be Tried
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved a one-year trial of a New York Stock Exchange rule that would curtail a type of computerized trading on days when the stock market swings widely up or down.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * CBS Records, New York, a unit of Sony Corp., named Marvin Cohn president of CBS Music Publishing.

headline: G.M. Cancels Plan For a Convertible
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had canceled plans for a convertible version of the Chevrolet Beretta because of mounting costs, engineering and quality problems and delays.

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE SAID TO RULE OUT A RATE SHIFT NOW
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to make no changes in interest rates until the Middle East crisis quieted down and a clearer picture emerged of its effect on the economy.

headline: South Africa Said to Capture Rebel Infiltrators as New Talks Near
abstract: LEAD: Armed guerrillas of the African National Congress's military wing, Spear of the Nation, are reported to have been captured while infiltrating South Africa from bases in exile, posing problems for talks between the Government and the congress.

headline: Hewlett In Move To France
abstract: LEAD: In a move reflecting the growing importance of the European market, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it was moving the headquarters of its personal computer group from Sunnyvale, Calif., to Grenoble, France.

headline: Compromise on Regulation Of Index Futures Advances
abstract: LEAD: A Treasury official said tonight that the Bush Administration would accept an agreement worked out among Republican and Democratic senators that would allow the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to retain most of its regulatory authority over stock index futures but would shift some power to both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal

headline: U.S. IS CHALLENGING COLLEGE FOOTBALL OVER TV CONTRACT
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission today charged Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and the College Football Association with illegally conspiring to limit the number of college football games shown on television.

headline: World Lawyers' Group Cancels Kenya Parley
abstract: LEAD: The International Bar Association announced today that it had canceled its annual convention scheduled in Kenya. The move came at a time of international criticism of the human rights record of the Government.

headline: World Markets;   Taking the Country-Fund Plunge
abstract: LEAD: The old saw about the stock market is buy low and sell high. But when it comes to country funds, investors have stood that truism on its head.

headline: Board of Peat Said to Back A New Head
abstract: LEAD: The board of KPMG Peat Marwick, the world's largest accounting firm, voted over the weekend to support Jon C. Madonna, a 47-year-old auditor who heads the San Francisco region, as the firm's next chairman, a director who insisted on anonymity said yesterday.

headline: Afghan Leader Insists on Retaining Power in a Pact
abstract: LEAD: President Najibullah of Afghanistan made it clear here today that he did not see himself as a barrier to a political solution in Afghanistan and was not prepared to give up effective powers to a transitional government in Kabul.

headline: Tiny Tonga Seeks Satellite Empire in Space
abstract: LEAD: Spurred by an ambitious American entrepreneur, a tiny South Pacific kingdom has started what amounts to a turf battle in space that could affect the future control of satellite communications between Asia and the United States.

headline: Delta Is Firm on New Planes
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of Delta Air Lines said today that the carrier would not abandon any of the orders and options it had for new aircraft, despite indications that the airline industry was facing lower profits.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Lower House in Poland Approves Bill to Make Citizens Stockholders
abstract: LEAD: Parliament's lower house today approved a plan that would give every citizen a share in any of several thousand companies now owned by the state.

headline: Citicorp Announces the End Of Weekly Paper Auctions
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp announced yesterday that it planned to discontinue the weekly auctions of commercial paper it has held for 12 years.

headline: France Says Iraq Seized Four At Envoy's Home in Kuwait
abstract: LEAD: France said today that Iraqi troops had entered its Ambassador's residence in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, forcibly removing four French citizens, including the embassy's military attache, who was released later in the day.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgarians Call On More to Quit
abstract: LEAD: Student leaders called today for more resignations in Bulgaria's governing Socialist Party after protests forced out President Petar Mladenov.

headline: In Just 2 Days, a Doubling of U.S. Troop Estimates
abstract: LEAD: By saying today that as many as 100,000 United States troops would be committed for duty in Saudi Arabia, Administration officials doubled the estimates provided two days earlier.

headline: CHILEAN MILITARY DEFENDS KILLINGS
abstract: LEAD: In an emotional national debate set off by recent discoveries of mass graves, the Chilean armed forces have defended the widespread executions after the overthrow of Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973 as a response to ''internal war'' instigated by Allende partisans.

headline: A Month of Crisis in the Persian Gulf
abstract: LEAD: Aug. 2 Iraq invades Kuwait hours after talks broke down between the two nations over oil production and debt repayment. Iraqi troops seize vast petroleum reserves and Kuwait's capital, plunging the Persian Gulf region into crisis. Witnesses report hundreds of casualties. The Kuwaiti ruler flees. President Bush calls the invasion ''naked aggression.

headline: New Unleaded Premium Gas From ARCO
abstract: LEAD: ARCO, the largest seller of gasoline in Southern California, introduced a new unleaded premium today that it says emits fewer pollutants into the air than other fuels of its type.

headline: All About/Yellow Pages;   Changing Shopping Habits Keep Those Fingers Walking
abstract: LEAD: Yellow Pages publishers are learning to behave less like utility companies and more like their advertising brethren on Madison Avenue. In the six years since the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Yellow Pages have gone from dowdy and predicatable - almost like the white pages - to venturesome and competitive.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Group Restricts Billboard Ads
abstract: LEAD: The Outdoor Advertising Association of America, in response to growing protests by special-interest groups that want to ban the use of billboards for tobacco and alcohol advertisements, said the international children's symbol - a stylized figure of a child walking - would be used to mark billboards that will be off-limits to advertising any product or service illegal for sale to minors.

headline: Net Down at Japan Brokers
abstract: LEAD: Japanese brokerages have had to make unusual revisions of their earnings forecasts for April to September because of heavy profit declines from a falling Tokyo Stock Exchange, officials said last week.

headline: MUSCOVITES VIEW BREAD AS SYMBOL
abstract: LEAD: Demoralized and suspicious, Moscow shoppers continued their search for scarce bread today, saying that the capital's empty bakery shelves seemed more a symptom of the withering of central Government management than of impending famine.

headline: Foe of Kenya's Leader Said to Flee to London
abstract: LEAD: A major critic of President Daniel arap Moi who took refuge in the United States Embassy during four days of violent anti-Government protests has left Kenya for London, the United States Ambassador said today.

headline: No Change Seen at Fed On Rates
abstract: LEAD: Despite pressure from the White House and Congress to lower interest rates quickly to try to prevent a recession, the Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to hold rates unchanged for the time being.

headline: U.N. OFFICIALS SEEK MORE REFUGEE AID
abstract: LEAD: United Nations officials called today for more money to cope with tens of thousands of people fleeing to Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait.

headline: Brooktree Wins on Patent
abstract: LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that a jury had ordered it to pay $25.6 million in damages stemming from an earlier finding that the company had infringed patents held by the Brooktree Corporation and that it intended to appeal the award.

headline: Volvo Stock Swap
abstract: LEAD: The Government gave its final approval to a deal between the Swedish car maker Volvo and Renault, the French state-owned automotive concern. Volvo and Renault will exchange 45 percent of the shares in their truck and bus operations and exchange 25 percent of stock in their car divisions, a news release from Volvo said.

headline: 2 Networks Say No To No Excuses Jeans
abstract: LEAD: The new advertising campaign for No Excuses jeans, starring Marla Maples, is unlikely to appear on any of the three major television networks, having run afoul of their standards.

headline: Occidental Notes Are Priced at $100
abstract: LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation offered $150 million in senior 20-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria Convenes a Post-Communist Parliament
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria reached down to its roots today to convene its first Parliament elected in genuine elections after more than 40 years of Communist rule.

headline: Treasuries Mixed in Slow Trading
abstract: LEAD: The prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, and the difference between short-term and long-term interest rates widened further.

headline: India Trying To Shore Up Its Tourism
abstract: LEAD: The shutdown of the major tourist attractions in the Kashmir because of violence there and an overbooked domestic airline have forced the Indian Government to take new steps to bolster its tourist industry.

headline: All About/Corporate Jets;   The Ultimate Status Symbol Still Sells
abstract: LEAD: People who sell corporate jets can talk a transcontinental streak about the security, convenience and flexibility their products afford. What they don't need to say is that these particular corporate assets are 600 mile-per-hour odes to success - faster than airliners, with interiors that make first class seem like steerage.

headline: Why Schools Belong in Offices
abstract: LEAD: The preliminary census results remind us once again that America is not an agrarian society. Probably less than a quarter of the population lives in rural areas, and even fewer toil in the amber fields of grain. Why is it, then, that the American educational system continues to be based on an agricultural model?

headline: Energy Plan in California
abstract: LEAD: California utility commissioners approved an incentive plan today for four state utilities to promote energy conservation.

headline: Inside the Nation's Best-Run S.&L.
abstract: LEAD: Herbert M. and Marion O. Sandler, the husband-and-wife team that runs the Golden West Financial Corporation, have had the good sense never to invest company funds in ''junk bonds,'' windmill farms or any of the other far-fetched ventures that have sunk so many savings and loans.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Michael V. Howe has been appointed president and chief executive of Young & Rubicam's Detroit office, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds John Sanders, who has been named chief executive of Wunderman Worldwide, the agency's direct-marketing subsidiary.

headline: JOB FIGURES DEPRESS BOND PRICES
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury securities plunged. The sharp price declines were fed by conflicting employment data released by the Government before trading began in New York and the losses became even more pronounced during the session.

headline: Wall Street;   Playing the Bankruptcy 'Endgame'
abstract: LEAD: Some people love inefficient markets, those murky bazaars where most investors have no idea what a particular security is worth and where their uncertainty produces vast differences between what buyers will pay and what sellers will demand. Back in the barbaric 80's, the people who called themselves risk arbitragers made money trading in takeover stocks, hoping to have guessed correctly (or, in a few unseemly cases, to have been accurately informed) about how the deals would turn out.

headline: ASK Computer To Buy Ingres
abstract: LEAD: ASK Computer Systems Inc., a supplier of manufacturing-automation software, said it would acquire the Ingres Corporation, a software producer, for $9.25 a share in cash, or a total of about $110 million.

headline: What Business Stands to Gain - or Lose - With Souter
abstract: LEAD: WHAT kind of businesses are likely to be happy if David H. Souter is confirmed by the Senate to succeed William J. Brennan Jr. on the Supreme Court? Probably the ones that are just like the reclusive workaholic jurist: straitlaced, attentive to detail and respectful of both tradition and the restrictions placed on it by

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   4 Nations Order Diplomats To Shut Missions in Kuwait
abstract: LEAD: Austria, Bangladesh, Greece and Switzerland ordered their diplomats today to pull out of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, appointed Frederick S. Schiff vice president and controller.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 16:       MONDAY       Dana Corp    Eastern Utils    Goodrich B.F. Co    Lilly Eli & Co    Oxford Inds    Russ Togs    Southern Co       TUESDAY       AAR Corp    Amer. Cap. Mgmt & Resh    Cincinnati Milacron    Federal Natl Mtg Assn    Hawaiian Elec Inds    Honeywell    ICM Ppty Invs Inc    K Mart Corp    Mellon Bank Corp    Natl.

headline: Superpowers Seeking an Angola Agreement
abstract: LEAD: In another sign of growing superpower cooperation, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to work jointly as mediators to revive Angola's stalled peace talks and end civil strife there, American and Soviet officials say.

headline: Japan Banks in China Loan
abstract: LEAD: In the biggest Japanese loan participation to China since Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy protests last year, 11 leading Tokyo banks have joined in an $82 million syndication loan for a television-tube plant in China, banking officials said Saturday.

headline: WALL STREET;  Bullion Coins Get a Boost From the Mideast
abstract: LEAD: Whatever his other shortcomings, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sure helped the beleaguered bullion coin business. Sales of the American Eagle , marketed by the United States Mint, and the Royal Canadian Mint's Maple Leaf have skyrocketed in the last four weeks.

headline: Economic Memo;   Quiet Moves at Bank Talks: A Reshaping of East Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Middle East crisis dominated the speeches and news conferences at the annual meeting this week of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. But away from the newsmakers, in hotel rooms outfitted with conference tables, Eastern Europe's emerging free market economies were quietly being shaped.

headline: Higher Fares On Foreign Flights Due
abstract: LEAD: Most of the world's airlines will seek to increase fares on international routes by about 7 percent to 8 percent by Oct. 1 to help cope with the rapid rise in fuel costs in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Creating a Giant Computer Highway
abstract: LEAD: Traced in the phosphors glowing on the screen of his computer, Robert E. Kahn sees the 21st century:

headline: CBS Records Chief Seen In 2-Year Pact
abstract: LEAD: Walter R. Yetnikoff, the 56-year-old chief executive of CBS Records, has signed a new contract under which he will remain as chief executive for two years and then become a consultant to the company, several top-level industry executives said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected gain that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis. The increase was a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy. [Page A1.]      Housing starts fell 2.6 percent last month from June, the sixth straight monthly decline, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, New York, resigned as agency of record for the Genesee Brewing Company, a beer maker in Rochester. They have handled the account since 1987. The agency said a decrease in spending on advertising to $3 million from $12 million in three years made the company a less attractive client.

headline: The Scandal Is the Lack of Funding for Medical Research
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: The Price of Confronting Iraq in the Oil Market;   Japanese Joining In Embargo Despite Impact on Economy
abstract: LEAD: Japan said last night that it would join its allies in halting all purchases of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, cutting off an eighth of the country's entire supply of oil.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    SUNDAY: Some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plan to meet in Vienna.       MONDAY: Personal income and expenditures for July.    The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills.       TUESDAY: The Treasury auctions two-year notes.       WEDNESDAY: Index of leading indicators for July.

headline: West German Inflation
abstract: LEAD: Soaring oil prices pushed West Germany's inflation higher in August, but economists said the rate for the year could still be kept near the 3 percent level. The Federal Statistics Office said today that West Germany's cost of living rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, for a rise of 2.9 percent over the last 12 months.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:    The Houston Summit

headline: New Arianespace Chief
abstract: LEAD: Arianespace this week named its Director General, Charles Bigot, to the post of president, replacing Frederic d'Allest as head of Europe's commercial satellite launching program. Mr. D'Allest announced his retirement last week. Mr. Bigot, who is 58 years old, had served in the consortium's second-highest post since 1982.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $3.67 billion, to $389.91 billion, for the week ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 160 institutional funds increased by $2.99 billion, to $94.81 billion. The assets of the 251 general-purpose funds were up by $313.30 million, to $134.70 billion.

headline: I.B.M. Is Joining Metaphor To Create a New Software
abstract: LEAD: I.B.M. announced a new business partnership yesterday with Metaphor Computer Systems, a privately held company in Mountain View, Calif. in which I.B.M. has a minority stake, to create new software that will allow individual programs to run with multiple computer operating systems.

headline: Research Profit Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The California Supreme Court has ruled that patients have no right to share in profits if their blood or organs become the source of lucrative scientific research.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * BBS of America, Spring Valley,N.Y., an importer of German road and race wheels, appointed Percy Herrmann vice president of sales and marketing.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE OIL JOLT       Oil prices fell and financial markets steadied around the world after the U.S. decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and reports that the oil-rich kingdom will increase its production. But the calm seemed tentative, with the economic outlook hinging entirely on the uncertain prospect of developments in the Middle East.

headline: Fares Cut by Northwest
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines said it had reduced fares to all five of its European destinations to as little as $358 round-trip. The fares are for fall and winter travel to London, Paris, Frankfurt, Glasgow and Amsterdam.

headline: Airbus Awarded Swissair Contract
abstract: LEAD: The Swiss national airline, Swissair, chose the European aircraft maker Airbus Industrie over the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to provide 26 new airliners in an order worth at least 2.3 billion Swiss francs (about $1.8 billion). The airline, which took options on an additional 26 aircraft, said it would buy seven 133-seat Airbus A320's and 19 170-seat A321's.

headline: Currency;   Surprises From the Fed
abstract: LEAD: Last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took the foreign exchange market by surprise, announcing Thursday that the central bank might ease interest rates because of dwindling credit from commercial banks and then, on Friday, actually pushing rates down slightly. The dollar fell sharply after his remarks but recovered some on Friday, partly because the June increase in producer prices was disappointingly high.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   With Simple Arms and Derring-Do, Guerrillas in Kuwait Vex the Iraqis
abstract: LEAD: The Iraqi-occupied land of Kuwait, economically stalled and abandoned by hundreds of thousands of people, has become a skirmishing ground as Kuwaiti guerrillas try to drive out the invading army, fleeing residents and Western diplomats say.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American National Can Co., Chicago, a can manufacturer, promoted Thomas N. Eagleson to senior vice president for manufacturing, food metal-North America, and Richard G. Sturdevant to senior vice president for manufacturing, beverage cans-North America.

headline: Ashton, After Delay, Ships New Program
abstract: LEAD: After more than a year's delay, the Ashton-Tate Company today began shipping an updated version of its flagship product, a program that is considered a key to the company's return to profitability. Dubbed dBase IV Version 1.1, the new program seeks to correct flaws in the original dBase IV announced in October 1988.

headline: Savings Units for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators put 65 more failed savings and loan associations up for sale today as part of the bailout of the troubled industry. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency supervising the bailout, said the institutions have a total of about $9.7 billion in deposits. Of the institutions put up for sale, 22 are in the Midwest; 18 are in the East, including Florida and Georgia; 17 are in the Southwest, and 8 are in the West.

headline: Mexico's Ruling Party Acts to Curb the Power Brokers
abstract: LEAD: Facing growing pressure to loosen their party's tight authoritarian structure, delegates of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party approved a series of measures today that are intended to weaken traditional party power brokers and increase democracy in the selection of party leaders and candidates.

headline: Profits Off For Some Big Banks
abstract: LEAD: Problems with bad real estate loans and sluggish demand for new loans are depressing profits of some large banks around the country, reports yesterday of earnings for the second quarter showed.

headline: U.S. Diplomats Return in Force to Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: On the southern edge of Managua, workers are readying an office building for a tenant that is determined to change the neighborhood.

headline: Britain Will Reopen Inquiry on the Titanic
abstract: LEAD: Britain said today that it would reopen a 1912 inquiry into whether many of those lost with the Titanic could have been saved by a ship that was nearby when the liner sank.

headline: Slain Soviet Priest: Victim of Martyr?
abstract: LEAD: The old woman at the grave knew everything about the slain priest, each detail, even that it was the blade of the ax and not its heel that struck him down.

headline: Coke's Chief in Europe To Head U.S. Division
abstract: LEAD: After a year heading the Coca-Cola Company's operations in the European Community, M. Douglas Ivester is becoming president of Coca-Cola USA. The move was one of a number of management changes announced by the company at its Atlanta headquarters yesterday.

headline: Gorbachev Sets Deadline for Militants to Disarm
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set a deadline today for the disarming of militant groups and warned that troops might be sent if such groups continued to endanger the lives of the civilian population.

headline: Barriers Are Down in Mohawk Dispute in Quebec
abstract: LEAD: Masked Mohawks helped soldiers today to tear down barricades set up seven weeks ago near the Mercier Bridge, avoiding a bloody confrontation.

headline: Israel Said to Fault U.S. Arms Sales
abstract: LEAD: Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel was quoted today as expressing disappointment with Washington's initial response to Israeli concerns about a planned $20 billion American arms sale to Saudi Arabia.

headline: Investor Group To Acquire McGaw
abstract: LEAD: An investor group led by James M. Sweeney, a health-care industry executive, said today that it has agreed to acquire McGaw Laboratories for $210 million plus what it called ''other consideration.'' The group has financial backing from Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

headline: Benetton Parent Buys 80% of Prince
abstract: LEAD: The holding company that owns the Benetton Group retail chain bought an 80 percent stake in the Lawrenceville, N.J., racquet maker Prince Manufacturing Inc. Last year, Prince had net sales of about $158 million, up from $105.2 million the previous year, while its earnings rose to $18 million, from $13.2 million.

headline: 50 Reported Dead in a Week Of Monsoon Floods in India
abstract: LEAD: Flooding has killed at least 50 people this week, Indian officials and news reports said today.

headline: Proposals for a U.S. Energy Policy: Some Possible, Most Not
abstract: LEAD: From the day Ronald Reagan arrived in Washington until the day before Saddam Hussein's troops reached Kuwait City, energy policy was a fringe issue in the United States. Now, the deployment of American troops in the Persian Gulf to assure a steady flow of oil has left many policy makers wondering whether the United

headline: Liberian President Captured by Rebels In a Fierce Gunfight
abstract: LEAD: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia was captured by rebel forces today, reportedly after being wounded in a gun battle in the capital, Monrovia.

headline: Prices of Treasury Issues Steady
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed and interest rates were basically flat in light trading yesterday, as dealers began coping with the peculiar demands of a holiday-shortened week.

headline: Managua Journal;   Uniting the Germanys, in a Latin American Setting
abstract: LEAD: If there is an important political upheaval in the world, you can probably find out about it by checking the stack of work in Georg Boomgaarden's in-basket.

headline: German Unity Drive Mired in Politics
abstract: LEAD: In their drive to advance the date of German unity elections by seven weeks to mid-October, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his East German partner, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, have plunged this signal event in their nation's history into the cauldron of German politics.

headline: Gauging Next Move by Hussein: Uneasy Wait in a Tense Standoff
abstract: LEAD: ''I can't predict what he's going to do,'' said President Bush about his current nemesis, President Saddam Hussein, at a news conference on Thursday. ''The unpredictable nature'' of the Iraqi leader, Mr. Bush argued, makes it impossible to say if war lies ahead.

headline: MARKET WATCH
abstract: LEAD: Is Iraq's Saddam Hussein another Hitler, who will gobble up neighbor after neighbor, until finally stopped?

headline: Boskin's View on Recession
abstract: LEAD: Amid a continuing barrage of weak reports on the economy, Michael J. Boskin, the Presidential adviser, said today that the chance of a recession during the next 12 months, while ''low,'' is ''certainly not zero.''

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Dean Scaros, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., the United States division of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, has been given the additional title of chief operating officer of the division. The promotion of Mr. Scaros fills the position left vacant since the retirement last year of G.

headline: Agreement On Maalox Is Canceled
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they were ending an agreement to transfer Rorer's Maalox antacid franchise in the United States to Procter & Gamble.

headline: Heinz Contract For O'Reilly
abstract: LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company has signed its chief executive, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, to a five-year contract that includes options to buy four million shares of stock, company officials said Friday.

headline: Savings and Loan Bailout, Soviet Style
abstract: LEAD: Read my lips: No more savings and loan crisis.

headline: Federal Reserve Coping With Power Problems
abstract: LEAD: The emergency power systems that kept the banking system in business after Monday's power failure in the financial district in Manhattan are showing signs of wear, causing a new round of problems.

headline: J. D. Power's Big Problem: Popularity
abstract: LEAD: THE advertising industry has a curious problem: It has discovered an automotive selling tool that may be working too well.

headline: Progress Made at Talks Between Two Koreas
abstract: LEAD: Senior officials from North Korea and South Korea resumed talks today and immediately reported progress in setting up a meeting between their Prime Ministers.

headline: Market Place;   Bank Stocks Emit Ominous Signals
abstract: LEAD: THE sharp drop in bank stocks is signaling a deep recession and possibly some bank failures, several strategists say. And while the broader market, battered though it is, does not yet fully reflect this, the severe drop in bank issues over the last year suggests that the overall market is likely to sink further in coming months.

headline: U.S. Ships Fire in Warning When Iraqis Refuse to Halt By MICHAEL R. GORDON
abstract: LEAD: An American warship fired six warning shots near an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman today after it refused to heed warnings to halt, officers said today. [In Washington, Defense Department officials reported that a second set of warning shots was fired by an American warship in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Morgan Stanley Debt Group
abstract: LEAD: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. has formed a unit that will trade and secure debt for less-developed countries, primarily in Latin America, and will provide financing for the public and private sector in developing countries.      The group will be headed by

headline: Allies Assess Japan Policy
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the European Community renewed pressure today on Japan to import more foreign goods.

headline: Bush Plans Address On Crisis in the Gulf
abstract: LEAD: President Bush is to address the nation on the Persian Gulf crisis today at 9 A.M., the White House said late yesterday.

headline: Solve Two Problems With a Gas Tax
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Gorbachev Denounces Estonia's Declaration
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denounced the latest separatist declaration by the Baltic republic of Estonia and said it was invalid under Soviet law.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Steve Greenberger is rejoining Campbell-Mithun-Esty, New York, as senior vice president and deputy media director. Mr. Greenberger was with the agency for six years before an 11-month stint with the Times-Mirror Company.

headline: Business and the Law;   Add Legal Costs To S.& L. Bailout
abstract: LEAD: WHILE the amounts may seem small compared with the billions of dollars being spent to rescue savings and loan institutions, the meters at hundreds of law firms involved in the rescue effort are ticking at a fast clip.

headline: NATO STRUGGLING TO REDEFINE ITSELF
abstract: LEAD: Having concentrated entirely on deterring Soviet aggression over the past 40 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is now struggling to find a new role for itself after the collapse of Communism and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

headline: U.S. Policy on Cambodia Shifts a Bit
abstract: LEAD: In a break from past policy of shunning the Cambodian Government, the Bush Administration announced today that it had accepted an offer by Phnom Penh to cooperate in examining what could be the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.

headline: I.R.S. Seizes Nevada Brothel
abstract: LEAD: The Mustang Ranch, a Nevada brothel, has been seized by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Mideast Fears Shake Tokyo Stock Market
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices plummeted today in unrelenting selling, sending the Japanese market to its second steepest drop ever and raising fears of a more prolonged slide.

headline: Farm Exports Steady
abstract: LEAD: The projected value of United States farm exports this year is holding steady at $40 billion despite a decline in the volume of wheat shipments, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Up; Dollar Off
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices in Tokyo climbed more than 4 percent in early afternoon trading today on a stronger yen and gains on Wall Street on Friday. Buying on improved market fundamentals and on optimism over the summit meeting between the United States and the Soviet Union on Sunday accounted for the morning's sharp gains in very thin trading, brokers said.

headline: Bush and Gorbachev, in Helsinki, Face the Gulf Crisis
abstract: LEAD: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Finland today for a snap summit meeting aimed at shoring up their collaboration against Iraq and coordinating their divergent approaches to the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Magazines Embracing Rural Virtues
abstract: LEAD: In the mostly urban world of magazines, few things seem to attract readers - and publishers - quite as much as the virtues, real or imagined, of the countryside.

headline: In Soviet Town, ''Anton Druzhinin' Means Power
abstract: LEAD: In this provincial city 50 miles northwest of Moscow, the Communist Party is not a platform, a faith or a movement. It is essentially Anton F. Druzhinin.

headline: Dow Off 12.13; Transport Average Drops
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, but the Dow Jones transportation average fell sharply amid continuing reports that UAL Inc. was having trouble arranging financing for a proposed union buyout.

headline: In Cars, Muscle vs. Mileage
abstract: LEAD: Experts on automobiles say technologies are readily available to make cars go much farther on a gallon of gasoline, reducing the demand for oil and therefore lessening the impact of events like the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But a renewed taste for cars with muscle is devouring gains in fuel economy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 13, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Sallie Mae Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, will redeem on Sept. 10 all of its outstanding 9.25 percent fixed-rate notes due Sept. 10, 1992, which were issued in 1987. The notes will be redeemed at 100 percent of the principal amount, with interest accrued up to Sept. 10 of $46.25 per $1,000 principal amount.

headline: Hong Kong Increases Emigration Estimate
abstract: LEAD: Even though it seeks to play down the mass flight from this British colony as the 1997 Chinese takeover approaches, the Hong Kong Government conceded this week that a record 62,000 people were expected to emigrate this year.

headline: Japanese Buy Pebble Beach Golf Course
abstract: LEAD: A Japanese company has bought the famed Pebble Beach Golf Links and related properties on the Monterey Peninsula for a price estimated to be as high as $1 billion.

headline: Pathe Makes A Payment
abstract: LEAD: The Pathe Communications Corporation has paid another $50 million toward its $1.3 billion purchase of the MGM/UA Communications Company.

headline: Sandinistas Accused as Burial Sites Are Unearthed
abstract: LEAD: For years, Justina Cardenas Gomez has known what happened to her brothers when they disappeared here in 1983. But she guarded the secret for fear of meeting the same fate.

headline: Texas Gas Pipeline Sold
abstract: LEAD: KCS Group Inc. said today that it had signed a definitive contract to acquire 90 percent of a 150-mile intrastate natural gas pipeline in Texas from the Morgas Company of Conroe, Tex., for $21.5 million. It said the Moran family, which controls Morgas, would retain a 10 percent interest. KCS said the 12-inch main line runs from north of Houston to 20 miles northeast of Madisonville, and six lateral lines connect to multiple sources of natural gas supply and market outlets.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: Construction spending for May.    Purchasing managers report for June.       TUESDAY: Factory orders for May.    The Group of 24 developing nations meets with Secretary of State Baker on international monetary matters in Brussels.    The Government is expected to announce a bond issue to finance the savings and loan bailout.

headline: Chase's Share Price Is Lowest in 12 Years
abstract: LEAD: The share price of the Chase Manhattan Corportion closed at a 12-year low yesterday, and interest rates on its long-term debt rose - a result of the banking company's weak earnings and unconfirmed rumors of its difficulties in borrowing money, analysts said.

headline: Business and Health;   Unions Joining Discount Plans
abstract: LEAD: While labor unions are still actively campaigning for a greater Government role in health insurance, a growing number of them have agreed to participate in discount health-care plans. With no immediate prospects for a national system, union officials say the discount plans can help stretch the limited dollars available for wages and other benefits as health costs keep rising.

headline: GTE-Thorn Talks End
abstract: LEAD: The GTE Corporation and Thorn EMI P.L.C. said yesterday that they had ended negotiations for GTE to buy Thorn's lighting business. GTE and the British company were unable to agree on terms for the deal, which would have made GTE the second-largest lighting company in the world, after Phillips of the

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE OIL JOLT       Bush and Gorbachev reaffirmed their commitment to reverse Iraq's conquest of Kuwait but reported no agreement on specific new measures to accomplish that aim. Some differences emerged at the summit meeting in Helsinki. [Page A1.]      The Persian Gulf crisis could benefit some military contractors by increasing demand from Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern countries for certain airplanes, tanks and missiles.

headline: Your Own Account;  Marking Out Your Own Path
abstract: LEAD: As senior vice president for planning and development at the New York Mercantile Exchange, Jan Kay spent much of her time traveling around the world to develop new markets. She particularly enjoyed the time spent in Spain.

headline: C.D. and Bank Funds Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mixed for the week ended yesterday. It was the second consecutive week in which yields ended mixed.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * W. R. Berkley Corp., Greenwich, Conn., an insurance holding company, appointed Gordon A. Ennis senior vice president of insurance services. He succeeds Barry J. Gilway, who resigned.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Pennzoil to Lift Chevron Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Pennzoil Company said today that it planned to increase its stake in the Chevron Corporation to nearly 10 percent by using the $480 million remaining from its 1988 settlement with Texaco Inc.

headline: Sydney Journal;   Immigrant Spice in a Once-Bland Australian Diet
abstract: LEAD: Near the heart of this city, the bustling streets of Chinatown sparkle with the glassy look of Hong Kong, and in some fashionable restaurants these days, Australians are eating spicy Indian chicken on pizza.

headline: PAPER IS BOMBED IN JOHANNESBURG
abstract: LEAD: A bomb exploded today at the offices of an Afrikaans-language weekly newspaper that reported the existence last month of a right-wing plot to kill President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela.

headline: U.S. Shift Dismays China
abstract: LEAD: China issued a stern and disappointed response to the announcement that the United States was withdrawing support for China's closest ally in Cambodia. Page A2.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * ARCO, Los Angeles, promoted to senior vice presidents: Harrell E. Bilhartz Jr., who becomes president of ARCO Alaska; E. Kent Damon Jr., for planning and control, and Anthony G. Fernandes, who becomes president of ARCO Coal Co. William C. Rusnack, who was also named senior vice president, becomes president of ARCO Transportation Co.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Grey Advertising's British agency, Grey Communications Group, London, is acquiring a minority stake in Davies Ireland-Smith, a London-based medical and health-care agency. The new company, which will be called Davies Ireland-Smith Grey, is the seventh health-care agency in the Grey network.

headline: Amerada Hess In Norway Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Norwegian unit of the Amerada Hess Corporation said it had agreed to buy the British Petroleum Company's 4.4 percent stake in Norway's Brage oilfield, which is due to start producing in 1994. Nils Gulnes, managing director of Amerada Hess Norge A.S., declined to give the terms of the deal, which has to be approved by

headline: POLISH PARLIAMENT REBUFFS PREMIER
abstract: LEAD: In another blow to the political standing of the Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the Polish Parliament has rejected two of the five Cabinet changes he proposed on Friday.

headline: Iran Offers To Sell More Oil to Japan
abstract: LEAD: Iran has offered to increase its exports of crude oil to Japan to cover the loss of supplies from Iraq and Kuwait, a Government official said today.

headline: Mattel's Shift On Barbie Ads
abstract: LEAD: For about 20 years, Mattel Inc. has sold ethnic versions of its legendary Barbie Doll.      There is a black Barbie, an

headline: Mirage of Arab Unity
abstract: LEAD: The political map of the Arab world has been remade, or perhaps erased, overnight.

headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE LAST MONTH BY A SHARP 0.4%
abstract: LEAD: In a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected increase that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis.

headline: Two Companies Out of Bidding
abstract: LEAD: The General Instrument Corporation said two companies that had expressed an interest in the New York-based electronics concern are no longer interested in a transaction. Neither comForstmann Little & Company has already agreed to pay $44.50 a share, or $1.6 billion, for all of General Instrument's outstanding shares.

headline: Climate Change and Coal
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Talking Deals;   A Polaroid First In Minolta Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation's agreement last week to let the Minolta Camera Company of Japan take over the job of marketing Polaroid's most sophisticated instant camera to consumers was not the kind of deal anyone would have embraced around Polaroid's headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., until relatively recently.

headline: Impasse Ends on U.S. Bill to Aid Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have reached agreement on the structure of an economic aid package for Eastern Europe that would allow the President to provide technical help to Moscow for the first time, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

headline: Soviet Oil Output Off, Worsening Shortages
abstract: LEAD: Compounding the shortages brought on by the Middle East crisis, Soviet oil production has fallen more than half a million barrels a day since last year.

headline: 2 Colombian Drug Suspects Extradited to U.S. by Bogota
abstract: LEAD: Two Colombians charged with being drug traffickers were extradited to the United States today, the first such extraditions since President Cesar Gaviria took office last month.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Worries About Radiation Continue, as Do Studies
abstract: LEAD: New studies continue to raise the troubling possibility that even the low levels of radiation emitted by most computer monitors have the potential to cause health problems.

headline: Violence Grips Hong Kong and Triads Are Blamed
abstract: LEAD: Six people were killed and 23 injured today in an attack on a crowded neighborhood mah-jongg club that has shocked the people of Hong Kong and focused new attention on a surge in crime and violence here.

headline: Czechoslovak Compensation
abstract: LEAD: More than 220,000 Czechoslovaks who suffered during 41 years of Communist rule will probably share around $95 million in compensation, officials said today. Those eligible include people in political trials between the Communist takeover in 1948 and its ousting last year. Many others who emigrated had their citizenship revoked when they left Czechoslovakia.

headline: Dow-Datatimes Deal
abstract: LEAD: Dow Jones Information Services and Datatimes have agreed to a joint marketing and service deal to combine their electronic libraries, the two companies anounced on Monday. Datatimes is a subsidiary of the Oklahoma Publishing Company, with a minority share owned by Dow Jones & Company. The arrangement will allow researchers to search electronically through the computerized files of 640 newspapers, magazines, news services and financial data sources.

abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization            June 29   June 22   June 30       1990   1990   1989        Gasoline production, daily   7.3   7.1   7.7        Distillate production, daily   3.0   3.0   2.9        Gasoline stocks   215.3   216.2   219.9        Distillate stocks   110.1   109.8   100.6        Crude imports, daily   6.6   6.5   5.6        Product imports, daily   2.1   3.0   2.2        Crude stocks   384.3   383.9   333.9        Crude production, daily   6.9   6.9   7.3        Refinery utilization (%)   90.7   87.6   91.2

headline: Neutral States of Europe Start Shedding Their Postwar Shell
abstract: LEAD: Neutrality just isn't what it used to be anymore.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: A table last Sunday listing the performance of world stock markets was out of date. The data, supplied by Goldman, Sachs & Company, were for the week ended July 27. The table for the week ended Aug. 3 appears today on page 26.

headline: Your Money;   Locating Business For Tax Benefits
abstract: LEAD: State and local taxes can play an important role in whether a business has an anemic profit margin or a hefty one. So people who own small businesses should choose their locations carefully. Although some say that things like a strong work force are more important, others say it sometimes pays to relocate.

headline: Revamping Approved, Resorts Names Officer
abstract: LEAD: Resorts International Inc. announced yesterday that a Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey had approved its plan to emerge from bankruptcy law protection. In a separate move, the company said it had named Jack O'Donnell, the former president and chief operating officer of the Trump Plaza hotel and casino in Atlantic City, as executive vice president and chief operating officer of Resorts' Atlantic

headline: Business and the Law;   Judicial Struggle In Asbestos Cases
abstract: LEAD: Asbestos litigation has turned into a kind of three-dimensional judicial chess game, with plaintiffs, defendants and judges all struggling among themselves.

headline: Japanese Discord on Iraq Raises Doubts About Premier's Trip
abstract: LEAD: The crisis in the Persian Gulf has stirred unusual discord in Japan over how boldly to assert its leadership in denouncing Iraq and seeking oil supplies from other countries in the region, Government officials say.

headline: Trump Shifts Casino Posts
abstract: LEAD: A management shake-up was announced on Tuesday at Trump Taj Mahal, the newest and most expensive casino in Donald J. Trump's troubled empire.

headline: Compaq Cuts Prices On Some Computers
abstract: LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it had cut prices up to 20 percent on several of its most advanced personal computers, including two models introduced last spring.

headline: Rafsanjani Stresses Iran's Military Role For Security in Gulf 13>
abstract: LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani has declared the readiness of Iran to restore security to the Persian Gulf area and he called for the army to be put in readiness.

headline: Eastern's Maintenance Case
abstract: LEAD: Attorneys for Eastern Airlines met yesterday with representatives of the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn but were unable to reach an agreement in a grand jury investigation of the carrier's maintenance practices at three airports.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   Iraqis Shut Pipeline to Turkey After Ships Sail Away Empty
abstract: LEAD: Apparently already feeling the effects of an American-orchestrated boycott, Iraq sharply reduced the flow of oil today through twin pipelines that cross southern Turkey and normally transport more than half its oil exports.

headline: For Muscovites, A Pizza Purge
abstract: LEAD: Pizza Hut is struggling with Moscow's bureaucracy to keep its two new restaurants open after inspectors shut them, a company official said today.

headline: New Valid Logic President Wants More Market Share
abstract: LEAD: Valid Logic Inc., the second-largest supplier of electronic design automation systems, yesterday named L. George Klaus to the newly created position of president and chief operating officer. Mr. Klaus, who is 50, will also be a member of Valid's board.

headline: Your Money
abstract: LEAD: For people who are afraid of the risk that investing in stocks entails - as are many, given the events of the last week and a half - but who want to share in the market's potential for appreciation, zero-coupon convertible bonds offer an answer.

headline: Marketing Post Filled at Pepsi
abstract: LEAD: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had named David Novak as executive vice president of marketing for its soft drink business.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Canton Industrial Corp., Canton, Ill., a truck company, said it was in talks with Abbott Products Inc., Chicago, an industrial contractor, about consolidating the companies.

headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   ISRAELIS CONDEMN BAGHDAD'S STRIKE
abstract: LEAD: Israeli leaders publicly condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait today and warned that it would contribute to a further destabilization of the Middle East, but they also appeared relieved by the move.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Mubarak's Stand Against Iraq Wins Praise From His People
abstract: LEAD: Seyyed Abdel Rizzak stirred fresh mint leaves into his small glass of steaming tea this afternoon as he said, ''If Hosni Mubarak was not popular among the Egyptians for all these years, now he is a hundred percent, a thousand percent popular among all the sects, left and right.''

headline: Amid Discord, Talks on Boat People Are Put Off
abstract: LEAD: A 28-nation conference on Vietnamese boat people was postponed today when it became apparent that differences between the United States and Vietnam on one side and the Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong on the other have not been bridged.

headline: A Threadbare Men's Wear Industry
abstract: LEAD: Sales of men's clothing, which some economists view as an unorthodox indication of the nation's economic health, are in their longest and deepest slump in a decade.

headline: G.N.P. Rate For 2d Period A Weak 1.2%
abstract: LEAD: In what many analysts see as a further sign of a weakened economy, the Government confirmed today that growth was listless even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait jolted oil prices.

headline: HAITI WANTS U.N. TO MONITOR VOTE
abstract: LEAD: Haiti has become the first United Nations member to request that its elections be monitored by the organization to insure that they are free and fair.

headline: Zapata Selling 90% of Fleet
abstract: LEAD: The Zapata Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to sell 90 percent of its drilling-rig fleet to a European group for $280 million.

headline: Telecom Chief Gets MCI Post
abstract: LEAD: O. Gene Gabbard, chairman and chief executive of Telecom USA, will become executive vice president and chief financial officer of the MCI Communications Corporation after the completion of MCI's acquisition of Telecom, MCI said yesterday. Mr. Gabbard, 50 years old, has led Telecom USA, based in Atlanta, since its formation in 1988 through the merger of his former company, SouthernNet, and the Teleconnect Company.

headline: Amoco-Soviet Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Corporation said today that a subsidiary, the Amoco Eurasia Petroleum Company, had signed an agreement with the state gas business of the Soviet Union that could lead to the development of petroleum resources in the Soviet Union. The accord gives Amoco an opportunity to conduct a study of the technical and economic feasibility of developing several fields in western Siberia in cooperation with Soviet organizations, Amoco said.

headline: Market Place;   Ranking The Money Managers
abstract: LEAD: MANY stock indexes hit record highs this year, but most money managers earned less in the market in the first six months than they would have earned with Treasury bills, according to CDA Investment Technologies.

headline: In South Korea, Hope at Last In Budding Links With North
abstract: LEAD: When the Berlin wall fell last year, South Koreans sat transfixed, their eyes on Europe but their minds on their own border of barbed wire, mines and tank traps, and they glumly concluded that it could never happen here. Now no one is quite so sure.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Top Iraqi Aide Sees Gorbachev On Gulf Crisis
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sent his Foreign Minister to meet today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev over the Persian Gulf crisis as the Kremlin maintained unequivocal criticism of what its press agency called ''Iraq's unprovoked invasion of Kuwait.''

headline: Factory Orders Up 2.1% in May
abstract: LEAD: Orders received by the nation's factories climbed a healthy 2.1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today, but the $5 billion rise was mainly attributed to higher production by auto makers worried about a possible strike this fall.

headline: Business Diary/July 8-13
abstract: LEAD:    INTERNATIIONAL       The Best Little Summit in Texas       A summit conference meant to celebrate the triumph of free-market economics became a demonstration of laissez-faire diplomacy as well. For every country and cause, the final communique had a clause. As the conference in Houston ended, West Germany came away with the right to unilaterally aid the Soviet Union, Japan the right to aid China.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Reserves Face the First Major Test of Their New, Broader Role
abstract: LEAD: In calling up the reserves, President Bush is offering the first test of a military structure reorganized over the last two decades to give the part-time soldier a more central role in the application of American military force.

headline: Car-Radiator Maker Names Chief
abstract: LEAD: Richard T. Savage has been named chief executive of the Modine Manufacturing Company, which prospered during a long hot summer of overheated automobile radiators.

headline: Digital Has Its First Loss Ever
abstract: LEAD: Feeling the effects of a changing computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported the first quarterly loss in its 25-year history as a public company and declared a $400 million charge for retraining staff, closing operations and reducing total employment by 5,000 to 6,000.

headline: Mileage Bill Gets a Lift In Senate
abstract: LEAD: With a vote that suggested strong support for requiring that cars be made much more fuel-efficient, the Senate opened debate today on legislation that would force auto makers to raise sharply the gas mileage of cars they sell.

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Dips
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade surplus shrank 10.3 percent in July from the period a year earlier, largely because of increased imports, the Finance Ministry said last week.

headline: Kurile Island Deal Rejected
abstract: LEAD: Japan today rejected as premature a Soviet proposal to share ownership of Soviet-held islands in the Kurile chain, which Japan claims. The issue is a longstanding sore point that has prevented the Soviet Union and Japan from signing a peace treaty to formally end World War II. Earlier this week, a political commentator, Vsevolod Ovchinnikov, wrote in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, that the dispute over the islands could be settled if Tokyo and Moscow agreed to place the islands under United Nations trusteeship.

headline: Optimism On Latin Debt
abstract: LEAD: Traders in debt issued by third world countries expect the loans of Latin American nations to rise in value on the debt market next year, a magazine survey said.

headline: Vehicle Sales Drop By 4.7%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in mid-August, a decline that analysts attributed to record high sales a year ago.

headline: Willamette Issue Of 10-Year Notes
abstract: LEAD: Willamette Industries has offered $150 million worth of 10-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Times-Prentice Hall Venture
abstract: LEAD: Prentice Hall and The New York Times will offer a program to help college students and professors use current events in studying major subjects, according to a joint announcement from the companies yesterday.

headline: Finance/New Issues;   Large Loss For Circle K
abstract: LEAD: The Circle K Corporation, a convenience-store chain that sought bankruptcy protection last month, said today that it had a large loss in its fourth quarter, which ended on April 30.

headline: 52 Rich Hong Kong Investors To Be East German Citizens
abstract: LEAD: Fifty-two rich Hong Kong executives will pay $960,000 each and invest nearly $10 billion more in return for East German citizenship, the East German Government said today.

headline: I.B.M. Outlook On Revenues
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that most of its revenues in 1991 would be derived from sales of new products introduced in 1990 and 1991.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Japan
abstract: LEAD: Toys ''R'' Us Japan Ltd. said it plans to open a sixth Japanese store in October 1991, despite fierce opposition from local toy retailers. Since January, the company has announced plans to open five outlets in Japan in the next three years, setting off protests from local merchants and putting the issue of large stores on the agenda of United States-Japan trade negotiations.

headline: Money System Fails, Kremlin Is Warned
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief economic adviser, reflecting the inner tensions of the Kremlin, warned today that the Soviet monetary system was ''disintegrating'' because of ''scorched earth'' measures of opposition within the Government to a transition to a free-market economy.

headline: Garrard Jewelers Is Sold to Asprey
abstract: LEAD: The British royal family's favorite jeweler, Garrard, was sold to Asprey P.L.C., a luxury-goods company, as part of a merger deal worth $:75 million, or $135 million. Asprey said it had agreed to buy the Mappin & Webb jewelery and silver group, which owns Garrard, from the Sears P.L.C. department store chain.

headline: Pollution Raises Cost Of Bailout
abstract: LEAD: Pollution problems at properties the Government has taken from failed savings institutions will add billions of dollars to the cost of the savings and loan bailout, Government officials and environmental experts said today.

headline: New Rate Rules For Truckers
abstract: LEAD: To compensate for rapid increases in fuel prices, the Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday that trucking companies could increase shipping rates with only three days' notice, rather than the seven days normally required.

headline: Chrysler's Incentives
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said last week that it would continue its incentive programs for a wide variety of its 1991 cars and light trucks. The sales incentives, with cash rebates ranging from $500 to $1,000, are available on all domestically produced vehicles except for mini-vans, convertibles, standard-size vans and wagons.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * Ketchum Communications, working through the Advertising Council, has prepared an ad campaign for the State Department. The effort, which advises Americans on how to travel abroad safely, begins next month.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH ORDERS NAVY TO HALT ALL SHIPMENTS OF IRAQ'S OIL AND ALMOST ALL ITS IMPORTS
abstract: LEAD: President Bush ordered the United States military today to block exports of Iraqi oil and all imports to Iraq except some food shipments, Administration officials said. The blockade would fulfill the President's threat to halt Iraqi commerce.

headline: Your Own Account;  Avoiding the Poverty of Elder Care
abstract: LEAD: CONSIDER THIS. A couple scrimps and saves to provide for a major financial goal: a comfortable retirement. When they retire, one develops Alzheimer's disease and is forced to go to a nursing home for round-the-clock care. The nursing home bills then eat up the assets of both.

headline: Swiss Investor in Settlement
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss investor has agreed to settle Federal charges that he bought shares of Rorer Group Inc. while possessing nonpublic information about a pending merger between Rorer and Rhone-Poulenc S.A.

headline: Jury Orders Ernst to Pay $18.9 Million
abstract: LEAD: A Honolulu jury has decided that the accounting firm of Ernst & Young should pay $8.9 million in actual damages and $10 million in punitive damages to a group of tax-shelter investors. The jury has found that the investors relied upon fraudulent financial forecasts, reviewed by Ernst & Young, before they put $8.9 million into various partnerships that turned out to be worthless.

headline: Mutual Funds;   When Small Is Beautiful
abstract: LEAD: The long-heralded rebound of small-company stocks paid off for mutual fund investors during the first half of 1990. The 85 small-company stock funds had returned an average of 5.4 percent as of June 28, head and shoulders above the 2.2 percent logged by all stock funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., in Summit, N

headline: Thousands in Korea, Opposing Roh, Clash With Police
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of protesters clashed with the riot police today after a huge anti-Government rally drew together South Korea's splintered opposition and attracted about 300,000 people.

headline: Airlines Scramble to Serve Berlin
abstract: LEAD: With the reunification of Germany only weeks away, airlines are lining up to provide service to an undivided Berlin that is quickly re-establishing itself as one of Europe's pre-eminent centers for business and government. And no carrier stands to gain more than Lufthansa A.G., the state-controlled West German airline that has been barred from flying here for 45 years.

headline: France to Attend Talks on Atom Arms Curb
abstract: LEAD: France said today that for the first time it would attend talks on curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.

headline: South Korea's Hopes For China Trade Ebb
abstract: LEAD: Two years ago, the road to China was a winding, almost secret path for South Korean business executives, but one that was illuminated with hope. After a number of bitter encounters, that hope has given way to disappointment and frustration.

headline: Cheney With the Admirals
abstract: LEAD: With tension running high in the Persian Gulf region after Iraqi ships ignored American warning shots, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met here today with the commanders of the United States' naval blockade of Iraq.

headline: Finding a New Weak Link
abstract: LEAD: I always thought the division of Germany after 1945 was unnatural. The wartime allies, at Teheran and Yalta, were clearly thinking of Germany as a whole, even while demilitarizing and deindustrializing it to make sure that it could not start another war. In a sense, what is happening on Oct. 3 is what might have happened shortly after the war, if the United States and the Soviet

headline: Tech Notes;   A New Lease on Life for the Printed Word
abstract: LEAD: For libraries around the world, the enemy is time. Since the 1850's, when all-rag paper became prohibitively expensive, printing has been done on wood-pulp paper. But alum, a component in that paper, reacts with atmospheric moisture to form an acid that dissolves the wood fibers: books become discolored and brittle.

headline: Disadvantage for U.S. in the Desert: Fewer Tanks
abstract: LEAD: If the crisis in the Persian Gulf should lead to full-scale war, United States and Iraqi forces would square off in a desert four times the size of France in a battle unlike any other in American history. While most American, British and Israeli military experts say United States aircraft in the region could quickly smash an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia,

headline: OPEC LEADER URGES HIGHER OIL OUTPUT
abstract: LEAD: The president of OPEC said today that the organization should help alleviate any oil shortages caused by the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: Nordstrom Opens New Jersey Store
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of shoppers waited outside the Paramus, N.J., store of Nordstrom Inc. yesterday when the company's first store in the metropolitan New York area opened at the Garden State Plaza. Store employees gathered around the three-level atrium and applauded the first shoppers as they entered. ''It's something that we started when we opened our Tyson Corner store in Virginia a couple of years ago,'' said Cody Kondo, Nordstrom's vice president and general manager.

headline: Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were very narrowly mixed in thin trading yesterday, as credit market participants sat back and waited to see what the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, says to Congress today.

headline: Zambia Gets Relief on Debt
abstract: LEAD: Zambia, which has one of Africa's largest debt burdens, was granted relief on $2.4 billion of its debt last week at a meeting of its creditors in Paris, Finance Minister Gibson Chigaga said today.

headline: Market Place;   A Dire Forecast On Oil Supplies
abstract: LEAD: NOT all oil is created equal, and that fact could prove to be a key factor in the problems world economies will face if the stalemate in the Middle East lasts through the winter.

headline: Shearson Unit Seeks Agency
abstract: LEAD: Lehman Brothers, a unit of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., is searching for an agency to handle its print advertising account, a spokesman said yesterday.

headline: Economic Scene;   East Germany's Morning After
abstract: LEAD: IF one tottering socialist economy can manage the transition to capitalism, goes the conventional wisdom, that economy is East Germany's. But getting there, suggests Steve H. Hanke, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, is unlikely to be half the fun. For paradoxically, East Germany's great asset - instant access to the markets and wealth of West

headline: BellSouth Project In New Zealand
abstract: LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation announced it was proceeding with its plans to develop an advanced cellular telephone network in New Zealand after approval from that nation's Commerce Commission. A BellSouth spokeswoman, Carlton Hill, said the Atlanta-based company plans to spend $100 million over 10 years to develop the network and will begin offering cellular phone service to New

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * GGK Holding A.G., the Swiss holding company that is a joint owner of the New York advertising agency Lois/GGK, has formed a partnership with Trimedia Group A.G., a holding company in Zurich. The new company will hold 100 percent of GGK and 65 percent of Trimedia. The sale is not expected to cause any changes at Lois/G

headline: World Markets;   Ominous News From Japan
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of Japan's increase of its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent has raised new questions about how much higher world interest rates will go and how many more investors will be drained from weak world equity markets.

headline: Signs in Canada Of a Recession
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Government said last week that its composite leading indicator, a gauge of the economy's upcoming performance, fell four-tenths of a percent in May. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline.

headline: Tech Notes;   M.I.T.'s Video Version of the Hologram
abstract: LEAD: The Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is experimenting with holograms using a video image. Holograms, images created on flat surfaces by laser light that appear to be three-dimensional, are now frequently seen as decorative art, on credit cards among other things. Video hologram technology, when perfected, might offer architects the ability to draw a house on a computer screen and then examine its three-dimensional appearance or it could become the basis of three-dimensional television.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Beth Rockwood has been named director of media planning at the New York office of Young & Rubicam. The agency also named George Sharpe to the new position of director of media business development. Don Davis, Carla Loffredo and Diane Spencer have been named group media directors.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   GERMANS IN TALKS ON POLITICAL UNITY
abstract: BONN, July 6 - The treaty is also likely to detail the timing for East Germany to accede to West Germany under Article 23 of the West German Constitution, which allows former German states to join the federal republic upon their request.

abstract: LEAD:          $   Construction Spending    July   June    May        Monthly percent change     0.4    -0.9    -0.9        Economic Activity     Aug.
