headline: Sudan Asserts It Just Helps Refugees Go Back to South
abstract: LEAD: The Government said on Saturday that it was helping about 190,000 refugees return to the south, where they had fled famine and civil war.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Ritz Carlton Hotel, Chicago, to Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk & Ayer, Ayer's Chicago affiliate, with an estimated budget of $1 million. The account had been with Haddon Advertising Inc., Chicago.

headline: Founder of Kaypro Sees Life in the Company Yet
abstract: LEAD: Innovation and unorthodoxy have long ruled at the Kaypro Corporation, reflected in the design of its personal computers and the style of its headquarters, a secluded compound near a beach, where employees munched health food from the company snack bar while they worked.

headline: Polish Investors Angry
abstract: LEAD: Dozens of angry investors besieged the office of a Polish financier today after it closed for lack of funds and a newspaper reported that the financier might have vanished abroad. The newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, said employees of Lech Grobelny, once Warsaw's best-known black market currency dealer, had closed his Safe Savings Bank after telling a prosecutor it had run out of money.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * The Minority Advertising Intern Program, operated by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, had 54 interns participating at 32 agencies in 6 cities this summer. The 10-week program, which began in 1973, has sponsored 570 interns to date, with about 25 percent going on to careers in advertising or related fields, the association said.

headline: Spot Gold Plummets $26.70, Its Biggest Drop Since 1983
abstract: LEAD: Precious metals prices plunged yesterday, with gold bullion posting its biggest one-day drop since early 1983. Platinum and silver prices also dropped, as investors and traders who bought bullion in reaction to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sought to unload their holdings.

headline: Polly Peck Chairman Reacts to Stock Slide
abstract: LEAD: Asil Nadir, who built an international conglomerate after arriving in Britain as a Turkish-Cypriot emigrant in the 1960's, is now trying to protect the company from recent punishing attacks on its stock price.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Text of the Declaration After the NATO Talks
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the final declaration issued by the NATO summit conference here today:

headline: Japan's Price Tag on Gulf Aid Bears U.S. Imprint
abstract: LEAD: A decision by Japan to pledge $1 billion in aid for the military buildup against Iraq came after United States officials expressed unhappiness over the original package announced by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, American and Japanese officials said today.

headline: Savings Bond Sales Up
abstract: LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds rose 5 percent last month for their best August performance in four years, the Treasury Department reported today. It said sales totaled $653 million last month, up from $622 million a year earlier and the largest for the month since $1.1 billion was posted in 1986.

headline: UAL Shares Jump On Davis's Offer
abstract: LEAD: The UAL Corporation's stock price jumped $6.625 today, to $97.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after the investor Marvin Davis offered late Thursday to join an employee buyout of the company, which runs United Airlines.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Does Software Lose Credibility When It's Inexpensive?
abstract: LEAD: How much is software worth? Is a $5,000 accounting program 100 times better than a $50 accounting program? Those are among the questions raised by Pacioli 2000, a new $49.95 accounting package for personal computers from, or compatible with those from, the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: Monoclonal Backs Quidel Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc., which sells fertility-test kits, said it had reached an agreement with the privately held Quidel Corporation under which Monoclonal would exchange about 9.7 million of its common shares for all shares of Quidel.

headline: Your Own Account;  Loosening the 401 (k) Rules
abstract: LEAD: There's usually little to cheer about when the Internal Revenue Service issues regulations on what companies and individuals must do to comply with legislated tax changes.

headline: Home Loan Bank Interest Rates Set
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday set the interest rate on $931 million in debentures consisting of one-year and three-year maturities through its regular dealer selling group.

headline: Waiting for Better Times at America's Shipyards
abstract: LEAD: Worldwide orders for new ships have begun to recover after one of the industry's longest slumps. Yet the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, for one, has recently disbanded a team of managers, designers and engineers capable of building new ships at the company's yard here.

headline: Brazil Stops Debt Interest
abstract: LEAD: The president of Brazil's central bank announced today that the country would not make any payment this year on overdue interest owed on its $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.

headline: ECONOMIC REFORM: A KREMLIN INTRIGUE
abstract: LEAD: The Kremlin added a touch of mystery to the misery of the economic crisis today, announcing that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after considerable hesitation, had finally decided to choose a single plan for economic reform but that he would not present it himself to Parliament.

headline: Stocks in Tokyo Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Tokyo stocks plummeted by more than 3 percent today, after being down more than 5 percent in the afternoon. Brokers bemoaned a complete absence of buying interest because of concern over future developments in the Middle East, which is being viewed in an increasingly pessimistic light. ''The market is basically discounting itself now for a war,'' one trader said.

headline: Company News;   A.T.&T. to Cut Computer Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would shrink its computer equipment operations by up to 650 people through job transfers and possible layoffs.

headline: Directors Retiring At Campbell Soup
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said that two directors are retiring, including Dorrance H. Hamilton, a major shareholder who leads a faction favoring the sale of Campbell but who will be succeeded by someone who supports her views. Mrs. Hamilton, 62, will become a director emeritus on Monday. She leads a Dorrance family faction that owns about 18 percent of Campbell.

headline: Emerson Electric Creates a Spinoff
abstract: LEAD: The board of the Emerson Electric Company on Monday approved the spinoff of its six military-related subsidiaries into a company called the Esco Electronics Corporation. Emerson said the spinoff would allow it to focus on faster-growing and more profitable businesses.

headline: Sales Up, Inventories Off in June
abstract: LEAD: Business sales rose 1 percent in June for the second consecutive month, while inventories declined four-tenths of a percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: Wall Street;   New Jersey Dilemma: Raise Tolls or Call Bonds?
abstract: LEAD: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has hit a budgetary pothole, with the gap between revenues and expenses expected to hit $94.4 million next year.

headline: Panama Companies Sue U.S. for Damages
abstract: LEAD: A group of companies based in Panama have filed a $30 million lawsuit against the United States Government, charging that the Government failed to protect their property in the invasion of Panama last year.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * The animated dancing raisins that represent the California Raisin Advisory Board will be used in a public service announcement this fall for the American Library Association. The television spot, which will be the first public service announcement featuring the raisins, will have the characters performing a rap song encouraging children to read.

headline: Genentech Agrees To Delay Merger
abstract: LEAD: Roche Holding Ltd. and Genentech Inc. agreed to a United States Government request to extend until Aug. 31 the waiting period required under Federal antitrust law for review of their proposed $2.1 billion merger. The Federal Trade Commission had requested more information on the merger on March 23, and the two companies said in a joint statement that they were now in ''substantial compliance'' with that request.

headline: Pakistan's Caretakers Face Mountain of Tasks
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who will head a caretaker government until national elections on Oct. 24, has named a Cabinet of experienced administrators, a significant number of whom once belonged to Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party.

headline: World Markets;   France's Buying Binge Takes Its Toll
abstract: LEAD: STATE-CONTROLLED French companies are breaking the mold. Rather than tending to their home market, they are aggressively buying abroad, both in Europe and the United States. Some, like Renault, are positioning themselves for the economic union of Europe in 1992; others, like Rhone-Poulenc, are pursuing the grander goal of a top ranking in their industry, worldwide.

headline: New Choctaw Bid To Acquire Justin
abstract: LEAD: Choctaw Securities L.P., an investment group led by the Kansas City executive Perry H. Sutherland and the New York investor Barry S. Rosenstein, has offered to acquire Justin Industries for $18 a share, or $153 million. An earlier bid by Choctaw of $18.50 a share was rejected by the Fort Worth-based company in

headline: Wall Street;   A Little Bad News in Aviation Leasing
abstract: LEAD: The unquestioned assumption underlying many real estate investments of the last decade was that assets would always increase in value. But a friendly takeover announced last week, the $1.3 billion purchase of the International Lease Finance Corporation by the American International Group, highlights another sort of collateral whose unfaltering appreciation has been an article of faith with some investors: airplanes.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Citing Disunity, Arab League U.N. Observer Quits
abstract: LEAD: Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League's observer at the United Nations and its chief representative to the United States, resigned today, citing bitter divisions in the Arab world since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

headline: Touche Sets $19.75 Million Settlement
abstract: LEAD: The accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche has agreed to pay $19.75 million plus expenses to a former audit client, the Inter-Regional Financial Group, to settle a lawsuit that was in its 12th week of trial in state district court in Minneapolis, the two sides said yesterday.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ousted but Unrepentant, Jakes Keeps the Faith in a Prague Villa
abstract: LEAD: Secluded, idle and unrepentant, Milos Jakes sat in the villa that is his sole remaining perquisite from the days only eight months back when he ruled Czechoslovakia. He ruminated about the collapse of a system and professed his unaltered faith in Communism.

headline: USAir Terminal
abstract: LEAD: biUSAir Group Inc. said it planned to develop a new $250 million terminal at Philadelphia International Airport. The 41-gate terminal is scheduled for completion in the third quarter of 1993. USAir said preliminary plans call for 22 jet gates, some capable of handling wide-bodied aircraft, and 19 gates for its USAir Express regional airline affiliate.

headline: Large Cutbacks At Laura Ashley
abstract: LEAD: Laura Ashley said it would sell or close most of its factories and cut its work force by one-fifth in an effort to survive. The retailer of English country-style women's clothing and home furnishings operates nearly 500 stores worldwide, 185 of them in the United States.

headline: Managers Value Money
abstract: LEAD: A new survey indicates that managers, who once listed job security as their top priority, now value money more highly. Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago-based job-placement company, said a survey of 600 managers discharged from Fortune 1,000 companies found job security now ranks second in their hearts to the size of their paycheck.

headline: Your Money;   Ways to Trim Tax Liabilities
abstract: LEAD: Savvy taxpayers will use the last three months of the year to pare their tax liabilities, while strengthening their personal finances. And there are a number of ways to do this, regardless of uncertainty over what Congress may do on the tax front.

headline: North Korean Exile Says Kim Staged Incident in 1950 War
abstract: LEAD: A former North Korean ambassador to Moscow, now in exile here, says that the North Korean leader invented a border incident with the South to start the Korean War in June 1950.

headline: Yields Mixed Amid Worry
abstract: LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

headline: Market Place;   Goals of T.C.I. In Cable Spinoff
abstract: LEAD: FEW company officials try to placate both Wall Street and Washington with the same maneuver. But John C. Malone, president of Denver-based Tele-Communications Inc., is ready to try.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Gives Leadership 2 Years To Rejuvenate the Soviet Economy
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that if the troubled Soviet economy failed to begin rebounding in two years, then the Communist leadership of the party would quit ''of its own accord.''

headline: U.S. Promotes Gasohol Use
abstract: LEAD: The Energy Department has recommended stepped-up production of ethanol, a corn-based moonshine that is blended with gasoline to make cleaner-burning gasohol.

headline: 2 Accounting Groups Split on Rule-Making
abstract: LEAD: In a defiant challenge to the authority of the Financial Accounting Standards Board to set accounting policy, the leading professional group of accountants has alerted the board that it plans to consult the board's experts less often and that it may issue its own rules, even when the board staunchly opposes them.

headline: Oil Users Pay Price; Japanese Stocks Fall
abstract: LEAD: Japan has cut off an eighth of its oil supply as it joins its allies in halting purchases from Iraq and Kuwait. The move raises fears for Japan's economy, and stock prices fell sharply in Tokyo this morning.

headline: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
abstract: LEAD: After declining for more than three months, yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were reported mixed in the week that ended yesterday.

headline: Trump Is Said to Name First Boston as Adviser
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump will use the First Boston Corporation rather than Merrill Lynch & Company to reorganize some of his casino debt, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

headline: Careers;   Encouraging Environment Expertise
abstract: LEAD: A PROFESSOR at Tufts University, Anthony D. Cortese, thinks he is one of a kind - the first at any university to hold the title of dean of environmental programs.

headline: Diplomats' Position in Kuwait: Gray Area in International Law
abstract: LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis poses questions of international law that appear clear cut in the case of United Nations actions, but murky when it comes to the protection of foreign diplomats in Kuwait.

headline: Auto Makers Split on Tax
abstract: LEAD: Sharp disagreement among Detroit auto makers over the need for a rise in gasoline taxes could reduce the industry's influence in the debate over reducing the Federal budget deficit, the American Automobile Association says.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Official Talks of Record Grain Crop
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union, the world's biggest grain importer, could harvest a record 260 million tons this year, but waste and inefficiency may cause food shortages, a top farming official said today.

headline: 2 Cereal Giants Fight Over Shredded Wheat
abstract: LEAD: To the nation's biggest cereal makers, shredded wheat is worth fighting for. And their arena is the courtroom, as well as supermarket shelves.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Some Picks for the Oil Play
abstract: LEAD: Given the sharp rise in world oil prices, what are the prospects for mutual funds that invest heavily in oil and other energy companies?

headline: Lender Backs Raynes Deal
abstract: LEAD: Martin J. Raynes, the New York real estate broker and converter of cooperatives, has reached a tentative agreement with his leading bank lender that will reduce his equity interest in the troubled Lincoln Towers, a huge cooperative conversion project on the West Side of Manhattan, bankers said yesterday.

headline: Bond Sells Assets To Lower Its Debt
abstract: LEAD: Bond Corporation Holdings, the Australian-based conglomerate, said it had sold more assets to cut its debt of $6.67 billion (Australian), about $5.3 billion (United States). It said that in April it had sold its Observation City seaside resort in northern Perth to Pakwell Pty. for $77.34 million (Australian).

headline: JAPAN DEFENDS AID IN MIDEAST EFFORT
abstract: LEAD: Jolted by mounting criticism of Japan in Washington, Government officials asserted today that Japan had done more than any other country outside the gulf region to aid the American buildup in the Middle East and pledged another $3 billion in assistance to the region.

headline: Thousands Flee South Lebanon as Battles Spread
abstract: LEAD: Artillery and rocket exchanges between warring Shiite Muslim militia forces covered a wide area in a disputed region of southern Lebanon today, and thousands of civilians fled their homes fearing an expansion of the conflict.

headline: Aquino Orders Halt to Offensives In Provinces Damaged by Quakes
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino ordered a halt today to military offensives against Communist rebels in Manila and three provinces devastated by a strong earthquake in July.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:       Debt

headline: Closings at Ford
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut down its plants next week in Atlanta and Kansas City, Mo., because of a shortage of dealer orders. It said it had closed a plant in Lorain, Ohio, because of a shortage of interior trim materials. The Atlanta plant produces the Taurus and Sable mid-sized cars, while Kansas City produces Tempo and Topaz compact cars.

headline: Nissan and Hitachi
abstract: LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company and the electronics giant Hitachi Ltd. are studying the possibility of creating a company to develop and manufacture information systems for automobiles. Potential projects include facsimile machines, navigation systems, digital telephones and other devices to be built into Nissan automobiles, the companies said.

headline: Heavy Schedule of Auctions This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, an offering tomorrow of 30-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corporation to finance the bailout of savings institutions and Wednesday's auction of seven-year notes.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Israeli-Soviet Trade Ties
abstract: LEAD: Israel and the Soviet Union agreed today to establish trade ties, Israeli officials said. The president of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Vladislav Malkevitch, said trade between the countries, which do not have diplomatic relations, could top $1 billion in four years. Direct trade stands at less than $10 million a year.

headline: Iraq Is True Victim, Hussein Tells U.S. In Taped Broadcast
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq told an American television audience today that Iraq was not the invader when it entered Kuwait, but instead was the victim of annexations and conspiracies.

headline: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Splits Account Team
abstract: LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Detroit has split its account management team into two parts. One group will serve the agency's primary client, Chrysler Jeep Eagle. The other will try to find new accounts.

headline: ARAFAT'S FORCES GAIN IN LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: Guerrillas loyal to the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, today evicted followers of a rival leader, Abu Nidal, from the main Palestinian refugee district in southern Lebanon after fierce gun battles in which 30 people were killed and 85 wounded, the police said.

headline: New I.B.M. Mainframes Due
abstract: LEAD: Responding to technological innovations that threaten the superiority of the high-power mainframe computers at the heart of its empire, the International Business Machines Corporation tomorrow will introduce its first new generation of mainframes in more than five years.

headline: Dobsonville Journal;   Bulldozers Visit a Township, Followed by Misery
abstract: LEAD: After waiting nearly five years in vain for a proper house, Calvin Mukondeli spent his savings of nearly $190 as a down payment on a prefabricated shack of wood and metal that he built for his wife and three children.

headline: THE IRAQI INVASION: Man in the News;   Arab of Vast Ambition Saddam Hussein
abstract: LEAD: With a single, swift military action, Saddam Hussein has dispelled the image he has assiduously tried to cultivate in the West as a man who can be trusted.      Iraq's 53-year-old

headline: Britain to Cut Force in Germany by a Half
abstract: LEAD: Britain said today that it planned by the mid-1990's to withdraw half of the more than 66,000 troops it has stationed in West Germany and to cut the nation's overall regular forces by 18 percent.

headline: Company News;   Perry Drug Agrees To Acquire Stores
abstract: LEAD: Perry Drug Stores Inc. said it had signed an agreement with Reliable Drug Stores Inc. to acquire 24 more former Revco drugstores throughout Michigan. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: West Africa Force Repels Attack by Liberia Rebels
abstract: LEAD: West African troops sent to Monrovia to end Liberia's eight-month-old civil war repulsed an attack today by rebels loyal to Charles Taylor, the Ghana news agency reported.

headline: KREMLIN MAVERICK LEAVES THE PARTY; MORE MAY FOLLOW
abstract: LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the popular maverick of Soviet politics, announced today that he was quitting the Communist Party, dealing a sharp new blow to the once-monolithic force even as it struggled to stay united.

headline: Bankers Call for Rescue Of World Trade Talks
abstract: LEAD: A conference of more than 150 nations closed here today with a call to rescue the Uruguay Round, the floundering multinational effort to break through global trade barriers.

headline: ULSTER NUN KILLED WITH 3 POLICEMEN
abstract: LEAD: A Roman Catholic nun and three policemen were killed today when a bomb ripped through a car near Armagh in Northern Ireland, the police said.

headline: Market Place;   Some Lessons In Power Outage
abstract: LEAD: The fire at a Consolidated Edison plant yesterday showed just how fragile - and resilient -the nation's trading systems are.

headline: Acid Test for New Hearst Magazines
abstract: LEAD: With virtually no advance publicity, Jupiter, a sprightly looking astrology magazine, appeared last winter on newsstands across the country. A second issue followed months later.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: LEAD: * Body Copy, a quarterly advertising trade magazine that was started in Los Angeles last year, will suspend publication, its publisher, David Breznau, said.

headline: U.S. Speeding Arms to Arab Allies
abstract: LEAD: The United States is expediting large-scale arms sales already negotiated with Egypt and Saudi Arabia and is giving higher priority to new weapons requests from other Middle Eastern allies, the Pentagon said today.

headline: MOSCOW JOINS U.S. IN CRITICIZING IRAQ
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union and the United States joined tonight in urging a worldwide halt of arms deliveries to Iraq after what they called ''the brutal and illegal invasion of Kuwait.''

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.    PREPARATORY COMMISSION FOR THE INTERNATIONAL SEABED AUTHORITY AND FOR THE INTERNATIONAL TRIBUNAL FOR THE LAW OF THE SEA - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Apple Bank for Savings, New York, a subsidiary of Apple Bancorp Inc., appointed Thomas S. Fiumefreddo, an assistant vice president and mortgage appraiser, as vice president and chief appraiser of its commercial mortgage division.

headline: Oil Problem Termed 'Manageable'
abstract: LEAD: The International Energy Agency said today that while the global oil-supply situation ''is not comfortable,'' it is ''manageable'' enough that there is no need to call on the agency's 21 members to tap their strategic petroleum reserves. But the agency did say its members should be ready to draw on reserves quickly in an emergency.

headline: Sharper Image
abstract: LEAD: The Sharper Image Corporation, a retailer of unusual high-technology products, announced today that it would cut its nationwide workforce by 10 percent. The layoffs of about 110 of the company's 1,100 workers include corporate and store employees. The layoffs come amid a sales slump for most types of retailers.

headline: Grenade Attack in Djibouti

No one claimed responsibility for the attack Thursday night in Djibouti, a small country on the Red Sea that is used as a staging area for French forces sent to the Persian Gulf region.

abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Cabinet unanimously approved an economic package today that includes harsh new taxes to help pay for the absorption of Soviet Jewish immigrants.

The 9.125 percent senior notes due in 1993 were priced at par to yield 77 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

headline: Article 123090 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: During the first quarter of this year, savings and loan associations sold ''junk bonds'' with a face value of $1.3 billion, according to a study by K. H. Thomas Associates, a bank and savings industry consulting firm in Miami.

headline: PROXY IN KUWAIT ISSUES THREAT;   Hostage Warning
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's new proxy government in Kuwait threatened to take hostages or nationalize foreign property today in the face of international calls for sanctions in response to President Saddam Hussein's takeover of his oil-rich neighbor.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   U S Sprint In Rebuttal To A.T.& T.
abstract: LEAD: A hard-hitting new television campaign by U S Sprint reaches out and thumps American Telephone and Telegraph.

headline: The Industry Fights Back Over Taxes
abstract: LEAD: THE advertising industry has been waging a fierce battle with legislators who want to tax advertising or restrict ads for cigarettes and alcohol. So far, the intense lobbying by Madison Avenue and its clients has kept tax laws and regulations off the books.

headline: Lord, Geller To Be Merged
abstract: LEAD: The WPP Group P.L.C. said Friday that it would merge two of its companies - Brouillard Communications and Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc. - to form Brouillard/LGFE.

headline: $73 Million Sought From Eddie Antar
abstract: LEAD: A Federal District judge ordered Eddie Antar to turn over $73 million he made through his Crazy Eddie electronics empire. Federal officials say Mr. Antar, who has been missing since he appeared in court on Feb. 13, made the money with fraudulent record-keeping and insider trading at Crazy Eddie Inc., now defunct.

headline: Scientists Seek One-Shot Children's Vaccine
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations Children's Fund and the World Health Organization are calling on world leaders to support an intensified effort to produce a single children's vaccine that could in one shot eradicate diseases that kill nearly eight million children each year and cause some 900 million cases of severe illness.

headline: Jackson Urges U.S. Diplomacy
abstract: LEAD: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson called on the Bush Administration today to move quickly, diplomatically and militarily if necessary, ''to secure an end to the military aggression by Iraq.'' In a telephone interview, Mr. Jackson assailed the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, and said, ''He must know he has pushed us over the line and that his insistence on the occupation of Kuwait and the threat against Saudi Arabia is an extreme act of provocation that would be met with force.

headline: Chip Maker Reports Loss
abstract: LEAD: After just a one-quarter return to profitability, the National Semiconductor Corporation reported a loss for its first quarter, which ended on Aug. 26.

abstract: LEAD: The Kellogg Company has filed suit in Federal District Court in Iowa to protect the company's right to make what it says are truthful claims in advertising for its Frosted Flakes, Special K and Bran Flakes cereals.

headline: Keep Politics Out of Scientific Research
abstract: LEAD: Decisions about medical research belong in the realm of cool, unemotional scientific logic. Why then have we allowed politics, activism and social hysteria to turn our nation's health research priorities on end? headline: Israel Says It Will Block Exports Bound for Iraq at Jordan's Border
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli military announced its first tangible involvement in the gulf crisis today by saying it will begin blocking exports of Palestinian-produced fruits, vegetables and other items shipped through Jordan to Iraq.

headline: Gas Concerns To Settle Suit
abstract: LEAD: Attorneys General in Missouri and Kansas announced an antitrust settlement today in principle in a $1 billion natural gas price-fixing case.

abstract: LEAD: Lucy Gaspe gazed up St.-Michel Street, past a crowd of reporters and television crews, past knots of police officers with pump-action shotguns crouching behind a wall of sandbags, to a barricade of upturned police cars and a front-end loader at the crest of the hill.

headline: For Vietnamese in U.S., Uneasy Ties to Home
abstract: LEAD: The young man in the toque and clipped mustache, chatting with customers at what has become one of Vietnam's best restaurants, is a symbol of the economic strength and potential of the Vietnamese exiles in the United States, as well as of their ambivalence about closer ties between the two countries.

headline: Excerpts From Economic Declaration by Chiefs of Seven Industrial Nations
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Economic Declaration issued today by the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada at the conclusion of their summit meeting:

abstract: LEAD: As medical science prolongs life, an increasing number of people are outliving their mental abilities to make financial and health-care decisions. And these elderly people are often poorly served when responsibility is handed over to other parties by the courts, reports the Committee on Legal Problems of the Aging of the Association of the Bar of the City of New

headline: Tokyo Stocks Rebound
abstract: LEAD: After falling to new yearly lows in morning trading today, prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded in the afternoon to close in positive territory. The 225-share Nikkei index closed up 150.16 points, or 0.63 percent, to 23,962.07. Traders said rumors of a change of Government in Iraq created an excuse to buy.

headline: Goodyear, Citing Costs, Reports Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's second-largest tire producer, yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $9.4 million, reflecting costs associated with belt-tightening and reorganization.

headline: Rebels in Liberia Are Said To Have Killed 200 Civilians
abstract: LEAD: Rebels have killed about 200 foreigners in Liberia whose governments contributed soldiers to a West African force sent to end the nation's civil war, the Ghana News Agency reported today.

headline: Siege at a London Nightclub
abstract: LEAD: A gunman took more than 100 hostages in a nightclub here early today and demanded to be flown to Beirut before surrendering 10 hours later, the police said. The gunman was finally persuaded to leave his last six hostages and walk to the top of a flight of stairs, where officers were waiting, a police superintendent, Alex Edwards, said.

headline: Crisis Aids Military Contractors
abstract: LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis could benefit some military contractors by increasing demand from Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern countries for certain airplanes, tanks and missiles, Government officials and industry executives say.

headline: U.S. Pact With Northrop
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today ordered the release of a secret agreement made in February between the Government and the Northrop Corporation. The pact lists the criminal investigations the Government declined to pursue against the company in exchange for a $17 million payment to settle charges of false testing on the Air Force cruise missile.

headline: All About/Coal;   Will Coal, the Plentiful Old Standby, Pick Up Speed?
abstract: LEAD: All it takes to give coal more luster is a crisis in the Middle East. With the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait cutting off about a fifth of the world's oil supplies, coal demand can only increase. But even before the recent jump in oil prices, the United States coal industry was growing enough in both size and efficiency to make healthy profits.

headline: Any Move Toward a Peaceful Settlement Could Precipitate a Military Revolt at Home

headline: Business People;   After 3 Years of Growth, Imo Creates New Posts
abstract: LEAD: Imo Industries has grown so much in the three years since it was spun off from the Transamerica Corporation that it has created the posts of president and chief operating officer. It is bringing in Robert W. Womack to fill them.

headline: Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Unsure What Program to Buy? Sample Some
abstract: LEAD: ''Shareware'' has become increasingly popular with businesses, government agencies and educational institutions. Shareware is commercial software that differs from the more conventional programs primarily in the way it is distributed and priced. The underlying philosophies of shareware are that good software need not be expensive and that users should be able to try software before buying it.

headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: THE REJOINING OF GERMANY - EUROPEAN VOICES;  A Shield Against Responsibility Falls
abstract: LEAD: It always bothered me and my wife that many people on the Western side of the Berlin wall seemed to be indifferent to the suffering and deprivation of people on the other side. The wall shielded them from their responsibility for people on the other side.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   4 European Nations Planning a New Focus on North Africa
abstract: LEAD: Increasingly alarmed by the potential for unrest in North Africa, four southern European nations have begun organizing a major international initiative to bolster political stability and economic development in the Mediterranean region.

headline: 11 Drug-Cartel Figures Arrested in Colombia
abstract: LEAD: The Colombian police have captured 11 leading members of the Medellin cocaine cartel in a big operation in the central part of the country, the news agency Colprensa reported today.

headline: 10.6% Inflation In Britain
abstract: LEAD: Britain said Friday that its annual inflation rate broke through the psychologically important 10 percent level in August for the first time in eight years.

headline: Developers in China Hit Hard Times
abstract: LEAD: After a five-year development binge that has dotted Beijing's perpetually hazy skyline with dozens of new office and hotel towers, the Chinese are suddenly learning that the flip side of a boom is a bust.

headline: July Home Resales Up 3.3%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in July, the second straight monthly increase, as mortgage rates dropped into the single digits, a real estate trade group reported today.

abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department granted permission today to the Federal Express Corporation and Alaska Airlines Inc. to begin air service between the United States and the Soviet Union. It was the first of several route decisions expected under an agreement the two nations signed in June.

headline: Business Diary
abstract: LEAD:    OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST       Prices at the Pump       Gas station owners seemed to react to the oil crisis with the quickened reflexes of commodities traders last week. Retail prices soared an average of 12 cents a gallon by Wednesday, with analysts blaming psychological factors, motorists blaming gas station owners, gas station owners blaming Arabs and oil companies.

headline: Saudi Force's Chief Vows Iraq's Leader 'Will Be Destroyed'
abstract: LEAD: The newly appointed top commander of the joint Arab force here said today that the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, would be swept aside unless Iraqi troops left Kuwait.

headline: Confidence on Israeli Oil
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Armand Hammer, said today that Israel, dependent on imports for all its oil, could eventually find enough to export. Dr. Hammer, who heads a consortium drilling for oil off Israel's Mediterranean coast, said he was confident enough oil would be found to make Israel an exporting country.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   As Forces in Gulf Build, U.S. Weighs Its Options

abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Ameritrust Corporation, which reported big losses in the first half of this year, has resigned, the bank holding company said on Tuesday.

headline: Rights Group Says Baghdad Has Seized Exiles in Kuwait

abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Government today approved Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's request for sweeping emergency powers to begin a crash housing construction program for Soviet Jewish immigrants.

abstract: LEAD: The English Channel tunnel project suffered a setback today when the British-French consortium building the undersea rail link said it was having difficulty winning support for a new $3.8 billion loan.

abstract: LEAD: American workers are earning less after inflation than they did a decade ago, while the gap between rich and poor has grown wider, according to a new study.

abstract: LEAD: The Centel Corporation said it intended to sell its electricity operation, which provides service to more than 136,000 customers in Colorado and Kansas. Centel said it expected to reach an agreement to sell the business before the end of the year. The operations generated revenues of $165 million and earnings of $29 million last year.

headline: Setbacks Are Seen for Bond Rally
abstract: LEAD: Analysts and money managers say that the bond market rally that began in late spring has been sidetracked for the time being, but that it has not been derailed. Consequently, yield levels, which had been inching lower, are likely to have an upward bias over the next few weeks at least.

abstract: LEAD: Rothmans International P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the Dutch pipe and cigarette tobacco company Theodorus Niemeyer B.V. from Gallaher Ltd., a subsidiary of American Brands Inc., for 245 million guilders, or about $130 million. Niemeyer is mainly engaged in making fine cut and pipe tobaccos under such trademarks as Samson, Javaanse Jongens, Sail and

headline: Home Builders See Recession And Blame the Savings Crisis
abstract: LEAD: For the first time since the recession of the early 1980's, the rate of new housing construction has dropped for five consecutive months, providing further proof, home builders say, that the economic and regulatory fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled one of the country's biggest industries into a recession.

headline: Soviet Trading In Commodities
abstract: LEAD: A newly created Moscow Commodity Exchange is selling seats for about $162,000 and plans to begin trading next week, a Soviet news agency reported Friday.

abstract: LEAD: Motorists - which is to say, almost everyone - are howling over the recent increases in gasoline prices. But with shifts in energy use in the time since the last oil shock, the public is focusing on what is most visible, but not most damaging.

headline: Ford Truck Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company extended its truck-buyer incentive program through Sept. 26, the official introduction date of its 1991 models. The program had been set to expire on Wednesday. The incentive program offers special financing rates and cash allowances of $600 on Ford Aerostar, F-series trucks, Econoline van and Club Wagons, $1,500 on Ford Bronco 2 and Broncos and $1,000 on Ford Ranger.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Albania Says the West Delays Refugees' Visas
abstract: LEAD: Albania accused Western embassies in Tirana today of delaying visas to some 6,000 refugees holed up in foreign missions there, saying that it had agreed to let them go West and that the delay was creating tensions.

abstract: LEAD: * Accor S.A. of France accepted 53.2 million units of Motel 6 L.P. in response to its tender offer that expired this week, giving it more than 99 percent of Motel 6. The remaining units are to be acquired in a merger at the tender price of $22.50 a unit.

headline: Careers;   Executives Cautiously Optimistic
abstract: LEAD: A survey on the views of American business leaders was released last week, and the findings indicated a ''guarded optimism'' about the economy. Because of the Middle East crisis, an update was quickly made to get the executives' reaction. They supported President Bush's stand.

headline: Soviet Magazines Testing the American Market
abstract: LEAD: In the ultimate capitalist test, Soviet publications are gingerly making their way on to American newsstands in a market already saturated with foreign policy journals and glossy travel magazines.

headline: SOVIETS ARE DEEP IN TROOP RUMORS
abstract: LEAD: At 3 A.M. on the night of Sept. 10, detachments from the Ryazan airborne division set off down the road for Moscow 125 miles away. Later that day, 30 Ilyushin 76 planes landed at the Ryazan airfield, carrying two regiments in battle gear, with equipment. Closer to Moscow, said an account made public this week, the Dzerzhinsky Division, under the command of the Ministry of Internal

headline: Managing;   Proper Conduct in the Workplace
abstract: LEAD: Several years ago, Borden Inc. asked a dozen or so employees to devise a smoking policy for the company's Columbus, Ohio, headquarters. The group - comprised of smokers and nonsmokers, men and women, executives and secretaries, oldtimers and newcomers - set rules that were more restrictive than the smokers wanted but also stopped short of the total ban that many nonsmokers had been pushing.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Allen P. Adamson has been appointed senior vice president and group director at Ammirati & Puris.

headline: Security Council's Rare Unity May Be Threatened Over U.S. Warships in the Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The United States appears to be heading for a disagreement with the other members of the United Nations Security Council over the use of naval forces to impose a blockade on Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

headline: TV License In Rare Shift
abstract: LEAD: The owners of WSNS-TV in Chicago lost a lengthy license renewal battle today when the Federal Communications Commission, in a rare move, said a competing applicant was more deserving to run the station.

headline: Romania Seeks Lines of Credit
abstract: LEAD: Romania intends to send the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund a clear signal that it is committed to fast economic reform when the two institutions hold their annual meeting in Washington later this month, the national bank governor, Mugur Isarescu, said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis, said it would build a theme park and resort in Spain if it is able to attract international partners.

headline: And Now, A Show From Our Sponsor
abstract: LEAD: Bozell, the giant New York advertising agency, has created a series of commercials for Valvoline Oil, but the real news is that the campaign will be broadcast next week during a special television program the agency also created for its client.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH VOWS NOT TO BE COWED BY THE TAKING OF 'HOSTAGES'; IRAQ SHIFTS THEM TO TARGETS
abstract: LEAD: As Iraq began moving Americans and other foreigners to military and industrial installations, President Bush declared for the first time today that those trapped in Iraq are indeed hostages. He vowed that ''America will not be intimidated'' by Iraq's efforts to use them as shields against attack.

headline: Larger Costs of the Crisis
abstract: LEAD: While the Bush Administration openly frets over the budgetary burden of confronting Iraq in the Persian Gulf, many economists fear that the military bill will be dwarfed by the indirect costs that result from higher energy prices.

abstract: LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry cleared Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s $211 million acquisition of Source Perrier S.A.'s non-cola soft-drinks business. The purchase includes two plants in the Paris area and another in Marseilles for various brands of a Perrier unit that includes Oasis and Bali orange squashes, Pschitt sodas and Gini lemonade.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   At Jordan Desert Camp, No End to the Refugees
abstract: LEAD: Kjell Madsen looked out across the stony desert toward Iraq, and pondered for a moment the two questions that hang like storm clouds over the effort to assist Asian refugees fleeing to Jordan from Kuwait: How many are of the Asians are yet to come, and how long will they have to remain here, in conditions that even nomads would not envy?

headline: Stocks Firm In Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Tokyo stocks were firmer at midday today in thin trading because of little negative news from the Persian Gulf over the weekend. Institutional selling clashed with buying bargain-hunting individuals seeking deals after prices fell by 16.3 percent in August, largely because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

headline: Wall Street;   Redemption on the Jersey Turnpike?
abstract: LEAD: By rights, these should have been disastrous weeks for the bonds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Promise of Yalta: Redeemed at Last?
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's acceptance of NATO membership for a united Germany brings the West closer to achieving the failed promises of Yalta in February 1945 for freedom, democracy and self-determination for all of Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Ghana Is Said to Strike Liberian Rebels
abstract: LEAD: In a move that could signal a new offensive role for the West African peacekeeing force in Liberia, Ghanaian planes reportedly attacked rebel positions in Monrovia.

headline: U.S. Insurance Offered For Mideast Transport
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration has begun providing discount insurance to owners of vessels and airplanes that travel in the Middle East. The unusual move is intended to provide relief for United States shipowners and airlines that pay by sharply higher war-risk insurance rates in the troubled region.

headline: Air Fare Rise Is Approved
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department gave the go-ahead today for airlines to charge 7 percent more for most international flights beginning next week to cover increasing fuel costs.

headline: Saudi Stake of U.S. Companies
abstract: LEAD: The Saudi Arabian port of Yanbu was the site where the boycott and blockade of Iraq were first tested. Tankers were turned away there without being able to take on oil from Iraq that flows there through a pipeline.

headline: Turning Marinas Into the Holiday Inns of the Water.
abstract: LEAD: Say goodbye to the 40-slips-and-a-bait-shop days, the time when mom-and-pop marinas contributed a modicum of service to enhance, but not disturb, tranquillity at the water's edge.

headline: As the Iraqis Search for Support, They Will Restore Full Iran Ties
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq have announced after two days of high-level talks that they are resuming diplomatic relations, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

headline: Manville Plan Urged By Judge
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge took the first steps yesterday toward consolidating hundreds of thousands of asbestos cases from around the nation into one large class action before him, in what he described as an effort to control the enormous legal costs.

headline: Mulroney Hints at Force Against Mohawks
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that unreasonable demands by militant Mohawk Indians may force the Canadian Government to send in the army to end six-week-old standoffs at two places in Quebec.

headline: Phone Company In Bond Offering
abstract: LEAD: The Southern New England Telephone Company offered $100 million in 40-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Former Casino Analyst Sues Trump
abstract: LEAD: Marvin B. Roffman, the casino analyst who was dismissed by his Philadelphia brokerage firm in March after he criticized the Taj Mahal casino owned by Donald J. Trump, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in the Federal District Court in Philadelphia against Mr. Trump and the Trump Organization.

headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: A New Face For NATO;   Military Must Change As the Threat Wanes
abstract: LEAD: The military strategy outlined by NATO leaders for adapting to the end of the cold war marks a break with 40 years of military planning and deployment. But the new concepts - including multinational units and smaller and more mobile forces - will pose a challenge to those who must put them into action.

headline: Bell South to Test Wireless Phones
abstract: LEAD: The Bell South Corporation applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to test tiny wireless telephones in Atlanta over the next two years. Bell South said the test, which would involve up to 300 handsets, would use as much existing cellular telephone technology as possible. Some experts say that such a system, known as a personal communications network, could prove cheaper than current cellular telephone service.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   To Baghdad, Poison Gas Is 'Poor Man's A-Bomb'
abstract: LEAD: Poison gas, a weapon no United States serviceman has had to confront since 1918, could make the Arabian desert virtually impassable for American ground troops in a no holds-barred war with Iraq.

headline: Sri Lankans Kill 42 Rebels Linked to Muslim Massacre
abstract: LEAD: Government troops tracked down and killed 42 Tamil rebels held responsible for massacring Muslim villagers, officials said today.

headline: Oil Crunch '90: The Game Has Changed
abstract: LEAD: If oil prices stay up, how will the poorer countries - and companies - pay their energy bills?

headline: Hitachi's Quest for Super Chips
abstract: LEAD: A good place to view the intense pressure to be first, the incredible expense, the dedication and the hyperbole that surround Japanese high technology these days is Hitachi Ltd.'s giant research laboratory here in the suburbs of Tokyo.

headline: Accor Is Gambling on U.S. Motels
abstract: LEAD: The $1.3 billion deal by the French hotel and restaurant company Accor S.A. to purchase Motel 6, the Dallas-based chain of economy motels, may be the boldest move yet by two executives already known for their boldness and management skills.

headline: Hong Kong to Try 5 Beijing Foes; Charge: Illegal Use of Megaphones
abstract: LEAD: In a few days, the British Government will put on trial five prominent pro-democracy campaigners accused of using hand-held megaphones without a permit at demonstrations here. Critics say that the move is an attempt to appease the Government in Beijing.

headline: So Close To 3,000 - And Then So Far
abstract: LEAD: Just when everyone knew the program traders were going to bail them out by buying stocks, they didn't. That may be the simplest summary of a week when the Dow Jones industrial average first failed to close over 3,000 by the smallest margin possible, and then saw prices crumble in the final moments Friday.

headline: 12 Nations Meet on Trade
abstract: LEAD: Senior ministers from 12 nations that trade across the Pacific Ocean opened talks here today to try to settle several complex issues and lay the groundwork for a sweeping reform of the world's trading system.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Amdura Corp., Denver, a hardware distribution company, said Hardware Distribution Co. was the high bidder for certain operating assets of its Amdura National Distribution Co. unit, but the bid was not disclosed.

headline: Jordanian King Begins Effort in North Africa
abstract: LEAD: King Hussein left today for a tour of North Africa, and diplomats said he would also travel to Britain and West Germany in an effort to defuse the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Your Own Account;  Out on Your Own? Watch Your Step
abstract: LEAD: Many people who decide to leave their jobs and set up their own business make amistake when analyzing how much money they must earn: They underestimate the real value of their current salary and benefits package and ignore the tax implications of self-employment.

headline: TV Needs More Than 1 Ratings Agency
abstract: LEAD: The latest spat over the accuracy of television ratings should not be dismissed as just another round of posturing among symbiotic elements of the advertising industry. The rift marks no less than the collapse of the ''social contract'' that for decades bound the networks, advertisers, agencies and, ex officio, the viewers they buy and sell.

headline: After Silence, Japan's Army Pushes for Armed Gulf Role
abstract: LEAD: After four decades of silence, Japan's military has openly split with some of the country's political leaders in a bitter debate over whether and how Japan should contribute forces to the Persian Gulf in what may become the military's first excursion abroad since World War II.

headline: Israelis Weigh Putting 9 Policemen on Trial
abstract: LEAD: Police investigators recommend putting nine police officers on trial on charges of torturing Palestinian inmates, but high-ranking officials have requested a review of the evidence, Israeli newspapers reported today.

headline: Oldsmobile Rebate
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Oldsmobile division said it set new incentives on 1990 cars in an effort to clear out vehicles from this model year. Beginning immediately, cash rebates will be offered on these Oldsmobile vehicles: Cutlass Calais $750; Cutlass Ciera $1,000; Cutlass Supreme $2,000 at participating dealers; 88 Royale $1,500; Custom Cruiser $1,000; 98 Touring Sedan $1,000; Toronado $2,500 and Silhouette $1,250.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Wins a Test Against Premier
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland decisively lost a test of strength with Lech Walesa this weekend, exposing his Government's precarious foundation of support and raising questions about whether his Cabinet could survive without changes.

headline: Rating on $4.7 Billion Debt Of Pacificorp Is Upgraded
abstract: LEAD: The rating on about $4.7 billion of Pacificorp debt has been upgraded, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

headline: Market Place;   How to View E-Systems Stock
abstract: LEAD: FOUR years ago, analysts expected E-Systems Inc., which makes highly sophisticated military electronics, to elude likely cutbacks in Pentagon spending and prosper.

headline: Your Own Account;  The Many Faces of a Pension Plan
abstract: LEAD: Robert A. Ely has handled his family's finances with a fair amount of confidence over the past 29 years. But as he weighs the possibility of retiring next spring, he feels overwhelmed by the number of options he must sort through in deciding how he will receive his pension.

headline: Itoh Weighs Soviet Site
abstract: LEAD: C. Stoh & Company, the Japanese trading concern, is considering opening a branch office in Khabarovsk in the far eastern part of the Soviet Union by March 1991 to conduct research on trade regulations and market prospects in the region, an Itoh spokesman said today. The office would be the company's third in the Soviet Union, after ones in Moscow and Leningrad.

headline: Congress and the Crisis: To Intervene or Not?
abstract: LEAD: While the President has been mounting the fastest military buildup in modern history, Congress has been sinking deeper into a political quandary over how or whether to assert its role in foreign policy and armed conflict.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, an electronics company, said its stock plan of reorganization for emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection had been confirmed by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.

headline: Low-Cost Housing in Trenton;  Project Blends With 19th-Century Area
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to create a prototype that can be replicated in other older cities, construction will begin this fall in downtown Trenton on 14 duplex houses designed to be affordable and to preserve the 19th-century character of a reviving neighborhood.

headline: A SWISS HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss Red Cross worker who had been held hostage in Lebanon for 10 months was freed today and handed over to Swiss authorities, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Corrections Detroit Set For Talks With U.A.W.
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers. At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers.  LEAD: Contract negotiations between the Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union, which have historically been fractious, show signs of being much tamer this year. But the apparent calm may be deceiving.

headline: AMMAN ASKS FUNDS TO HELP IN CRISIS
abstract: LEAD: The Jordanian Government made a strong public plea for international financial aid today, warning that unless it is compensated for enforcing the international embargo against Iraq, the nation's economy may collapse.

headline: New Democratic Party Wins Ontario Election
abstract: LEAD: The New Democratic Party ended a five-year Liberal Party rule in Ontario and gained its first Legislative majority in elections in Canada's biggest province on Thursday.

headline: Ecolab and Henkel In European Venture
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to establish a sizable presence in the European cleaning business, Ecolab Inc. of St. Paul has agreed to swap 19 percent of its equity and pay $74 million to Henkel, a West German manufacturer of detergents and cosmetics based in Dusseldorf.

headline: Dow Up 14,85 to 2,628.22, on Light Volume
abstract: LEAD: Stocks advanced a bit yesterday in another day of light activity, heavy program trading and growing apprehension over the nation's deepening economic slump.

headline: Prices of Long-Term Bonds Increase
abstract: LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted moderate gains yesterday and interest rates fell, while the shorter maturities were essentially unchanged. Dealers said the long end of the Treasury debt market was buoyed somewhat by a rise in the August jobless rate to a two-year high. But the same Government report revised downward the number of jobless in the prior two months.

headline: Canadian Troops Surround 20 Heavily Armed Mohawks
abstract: LEAD: The standoff between about 20 heavily armed Mohawk Indians and the Canadian Army continued with the militants surrounded in a detoxification center on Indian land after about 400 soldiers seized most of the Indian community of Kanesatake here today.

headline: Planes Ordered By AMR Eagle
abstract: LEAD: The regional airline subsidiary of the AMR Corporation will become the largest operator of ATR aircraft in the world with its order this week for $1 billion worth of aircraft.

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LOWEST IN 7 YEARS
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit narrowed a surprising 35 percent in June, to $5.07 billion, its lowest level in seven years. Exports surged to a record and a slowing economy at home cut imports sharply. But economists expect rising oil prices and other factors to push the deficit back up again.

headline: Kenyan Opposition Lawyer Asks for Refuge at Embassy
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Kenyan lawyer, who has been in the forefront of the push for a multiparty democracy, has sought refuge in the United States Embassy in Nairobi, the American Ambassador said today.

headline: Text of Resolution by U.N. Security Council
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the Security Council resolution authorizing military action to halt all maritime trade with Iraq:

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Spanish Leader Stirs a Storm By Sending Warships to Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The dispatch of three Spanish warships may have done little to tip the strategic balance in the Persian Gulf, but it has stirred a stormy debate in Spain over whether this long-isolated country should become more involved in world affairs.

headline: Markets Closed For Holiday
abstract: LEAD: Financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday for the Fourth of July.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   20,000 in Bucharest Demand Release of Student
abstract: LEAD: More than 20,000 people gathered outside government buildings in Bucharest today in the biggest opposition protest since the December uprising that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator.

headline: Madrid Journal;   Spain Frets a Bit as Third-World Tide Sweeps In
abstract: LEAD: Over the last five centuries Spain has successively expelled Arabs, Jews, Masons and Protestants. In the same period, millions of Spaniards left the country, emigrating first to the New World and more recently to northern Europe, where they found work, sent for their families and became part of local societies.

headline: Patents;   New Method Of Prognosis On AIDS
abstract: LEAD: Researchers affiliated with the University of California at Los Angeles have obtained a patent on an experimental test to predict whether a person infected with the AIDS virus will quickly develop symptoms.

headline: Peru Suspends Cuba Pact
abstract: LEAD: Peru has indefinitely suspended a year-old trade pact with Cuba because Havana missed a $5.2 million payment last month, a spokesman for Peru's Central Reserve Bank said today. The payment was due on June 8, but Cuba neither paid nor asked Peru for refinancing, said Juan Zuniga, the bank spokesman.

headline: Investment Group Raises USAir Stake
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by the New York money manager Michael H. Steinhardt has raised its stake in the USAir Group to 9.46 percent from 8.38 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Contel Agrees to Takeover Offer by GTE
abstract: LEAD: In a move that would sharply expand both its local telephone operations and its fast-growing cellular telephone business, the GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Contel Corporation to acquire the Atlanta-based company in a stock swap. The deal would be worth about $6 billion, based on yesterday's closing stock prices.

headline: Gannett Names Head Of Merged Divisions
abstract: LEAD: Gary Watson was named yesterday as president of a newly consolidated newspaper group at the Gannett Company, effective Oct. 1.

headline: Taiwan Plans to Cut Tariffs
abstract: LEAD: Taiwan will reduce tariffs on 1,900 goods in a move intended to support its attempt to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Finance Ministry said last week.

headline: Airlines Announce Plan to Cooperate
abstract: LEAD: USAir and Air France announced a joint marketing program for coordination of schedules, marketing and joint facilities. As part of the deal, each carrier will be able to buy blocks of seats from the other for resale on designated trans-Atlantic flights. The agreement, which was in the form of a letter of intent, is the first of its kind between Air France and a leading United States carrier.

headline: Sentencing of Milken Is Delayed by Judge
abstract: LEAD: A Federal District Judge postponed the sentencing of Michael R. Milken yesterday to allow for a possible hearing on Government allegations of crimes the former financier has said he did not commit.

headline: 'I Do Not Fear German Nationalism'
abstract: LEAD: It is an unavoidable process because a country with one tradition and one language has the right to find unity for itself. Nothing can stop such a natural trend. We have to respect this natural urge, this tendency to be a single nation.

headline: British Homosexuals Report Rise in Attacks
abstract: LONDON, Aug. 18 - "We think attacks are increasing for a number of reasons," said Chris Woods, a reporter for Capital Gay, a weekly newspaper for homosexuals. "The AIDS and HIV epidemic has had an impact with the aid of the tabloids, which label it the gay plague. In the last 20 years, lesbian and gay politics have progressed dramatically in this country, but the police attitude reflects a 60's approach to a 90's problem. They still project us as a homosexual underworld, with various vices, who need to be controlled. That is absolute baloney."   Mr. Woods and other campaigners said that the national detection rate for murders of homosexuals is roughly 55 percent, while that for all murders is 80 to 90 percent. They also said that more than 5,000 gay men were arrested in Britain last year for sexual offenses such as public indecency and importuning. Of those, 1,000 were arrested in London, they said, representing a 350 percent increase. The Gay London Policing Group, which collates data, estimates that there are more than 1,000 attacks against homosexuals in London each year but says that most victims do not report the crimes because they fear the incidents will be trivialized or that they themselves will come under investigation.   "We are pushing for the police to start monitoring and recording such assaults as anti-gay," said Paul Burston, of the Gay London Policing Group. "But they refuse, saying it would be an administrative nightmare and not practicable. They said the same thing to the black community years ago, and are now monitoring attacks against them as racially motivated."   A spokesman for Scotland Yard said that all murders, whatever the sexual orientation of the victim, were thoroughly investigated. He said that solving murders involving homosexuals could be hampered because they were more likely to meet strangers. Of the 176 murders committed in Britain in 1989, the spokesman said, 145 were solved.   The spokesman ruled out monitoring attacks, saying that ethnicity was easier to determine than sexual orientation and that it was offensive to question victims about their sexual behavior unless it was vital to an investigation.   Advocates say that British homosexuals are far less politicized than those in the United States, and that a gay protest that attracts half a million people in New York City draws 30,000 in London.   "The level of intolerance is probably the same here as in the United States, but our ability to deal with it is much less," Mr. Woods said. "Lesbians and gay men in this country have far less political power than in the United States.   "But things are changing, and people are moving into a more offensive position," he said. "We are saying that this is a blunt question of civil liberties, that gay men and lesbians are being denied fundamental human rights."

headline: Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar
abstract: LEAD: Inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed most stock prices lower yesterday, including airlines and other users of petroleum products, but sent oil and oil-service stocks sharply higher.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Employee of Libyan Embassy Arrested in Berlin Bombing
abstract: LEAD: A Libyan Embassy employee in East Berlin has been arrested for the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin discotheque that led to an American air raid on Libya.

headline: Failed S.&L.'s Cost Disputed
abstract: LEAD: A study prepared for the House Banking Committee suggests that the Government will end up paying $4.37 billion to bail out a failed California savings and loan association, more than double original estimate of $1.7 billion, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today.

headline: Appointment At Whittle
abstract: LEAD: Whittle Communications, a specialized media company based in Knoxville, Tenn., said yesterday that it had named Gerry Hogan, the president of Turner Entertainment Networks, as a vice chairman.

headline: Mainframes Aren't Museum Pieces
abstract: LEAD: When makers of personal computers and work stations talk about mainframe computers, they often call them dinosaurs.

headline: Free Fuel for the Troops
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia is diverting hundreds of thousands of barrels of jet and diesel fuel daily from exports and supplying it free to the international force on its territory. Page A14.

headline: No War Unless Iraq Strikes, U.S. Gulf Commander Says
abstract: LEAD: The commander of American forces in Saudi Arabia said today that there would be no fighting here unless Iraq launched an attack.

headline: President of Syria Will Visit Iran to Discuss Crisis in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria will make his first trip to his ally Iran next week to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis and Western hostages in Lebanon, diplomats said today.

headline: UAL Suspends Jet Purchase Talks
abstract: LEAD: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said today that it had suspended negotiations for a large aircraft purchase at the request of the employee group trying to buy the company.

headline: Soviet Aid: Short Reach
abstract: LEAD: Sometimes the very struggle for unity undermines the semblance of unity, and such was the case, it seemed tonight, in the search here for a formula that would unite the seven leading democracies on the question of aid to the Soviet Union.

headline: Buyer of Savings Units Misled State Officials
abstract: LEAD: James M. Fail, the Arizona insurance executive whose acquisition of 15 failed Texas savings and loan associations from the Federal Government is under Congressional scrutiny, has misled regulators in the past about his legal problems.

headline: Emigres in New York Trying To Reach Families in Trinidad
abstract: LEAD: New Yorkers with family and friends in Trinidad and Tobago said yesterday that they had spent the last three days hunched over telephones trying to make contact with loved ones in the island nation.

headline: Chile and U.S. to Begin Talks on Freeing Trade
abstract: LEAD: Chile, one of the lowest-tariff countries in Latin America, will open negotiations with Washington this week about establishing a free trade zone with the United States, Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley said Friday.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Soviets Leave Hungary, Dispute Arises Over the Bill
abstract: LEAD: As they pull out of Hungary, Soviet troops are leaving behind a legacy that to Hungarians somehow befits the 45-year occupation - rows of grubby, rundown barracks, shoddy apartment buildings, fields of unexploded artillery shells, oil and other waste dumped directly into the ground.

headline: Textile Bill Advances
abstract: LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a textile import quota bill today and sent it to the full House. The bill would establish United States import quotas for each category of textiles, textile products and nonrubber footwear beginning this year. Imports from Canada and Israel would be exempt because those countries have free-trade agreements with the United States.

headline: Arizona Utility Plans Job Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Following up on a midyear announcement that it hoped to cut capital expenditures and trim its budget, the Arizona Public Service Company said it would eliminate 675 full-time positions. Executives at Arizona Public Service, the state's largest utility, said the cuts were needed to keep rates at a reasonable level and match competition in the utility industry.

headline: NAZI COMMANDANT INDICTED BY BONN
abstract: LEAD: Josef Schwammberger, who spent nearly 40 years as a fugitive from prosecution for Nazi war crimes, was indicted today in the deaths of more than 3,400 people in Poland during World War II.

headline: Yields Post Modest Rise
abstract: LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly higher for the week ended Tuesday.

headline: At Gulag Cemetery, a Struggle Against Forgetting
abstract: LEAD: These morn-ings, as the all-night twilight of an Arctic summer brightens into real day, Stanislavas Grintsyavicius can be found tending anonymous graves in a gnat-infested field near the Yurshor Coal Mine.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Asians, Gulf Is Fickle Godmother
abstract: LEAD: The tens of thousands of people from South Asia who are fleeing the Persian Gulf crisis are leaving behind shattered dreams, empty homes and frozen assets.

headline: New York State Bond Offering
abstract: LEAD: The State of New York yesterday offered $225 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Fewer Badges of Faith
abstract: LEAD: The Defense Department is allowing Jewish soldiers to have their religious affiliation deleted from dogtags before traveling to Saudi Arabia as part of the American military buildup in that Muslim country, Pentagon officials said today.

headline: Kimberly-Times Sale Of Paper Mill Called Off
abstract: LEAD: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company said yesterday that negotiations to sell the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company to Kruger Inc. had been unsuccessful.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraqi's Belligerence Touches Pride and Old Wounds of Arabs
abstract: LEAD: Throughout the Middle East, the defiant stance of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is inspiring a surge of deep, conflicting emotions and reflection on the old, troubling question of Arab identity.

headline: Chrysler And Hyundai Venture Off
abstract: LEAD: With its domestic market share falling and doubts growing about its long-term viability as an independent car maker, the Chrysler Corporation canceled a small-car venture with Hyundai of South Korea today. The company also confirmed that it would build a low-priced version of its Dodge Shadow and Plymouth

headline: Saudis Criticized Over Mecca Tunnel Disaster
abstract: LEAD: The death of 1,426 Muslim pilgrims earlier this month in a tunnel stampede in Mecca has led to strong criticism of Saudi Arabia in several Muslim countries in connection with the disaster.

headline: Commodities Firm Closing
abstract: LEAD: A commodities brokerage firm headed by the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade is going out of business because the company is unable to pay its debts.

headline: Madison Avenue, Where Humor Can Get Some Respect
abstract: LEAD: Humor on Madison Avenue is no longer a laughing matter. It has evolved from whimsical fad into an established marketing tool that is now taken very seriously, something akin to product demonstration, celebrity endorsement, the sexual tease or the adorable child.

headline: Stocks Up on Belief in an Interest Rate Cut
abstract: LEAD: A growing belief that the Federal Reserve may take steps to lower interest rates to revitalize the economy pushed stock prices higher yesterday.

headline: Toyota and GKN Pact
abstract: LEAD: GKN P.L.C. said this week that it had an exclusive order to supply constant-velocity driveshafts to the Toyota Motor Corporation for Toyota's new passenger car to be built in Britain. The car will be built at Toyota's new plant in Derbyshire in central England. Initial output is expected to be 100,000 vehicles annually, rising to 200,000 at full capacity.

headline: Mastercard Plans to Offer Discounts
abstract: LEAD: IN an extension of its new pitch to Middle America, Mastercard International Inc. said yesterday that it was joining six national retailers to offer discounts of 10 percent to 50 percent on items like compact disks and furniture when consumers charge them on Mastercard.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraqi TV Shows a Smiling Leader With Grim-Faced British Captives
abstract: LEAD: In one of his few public appearances since the invasion of Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq held a strained meeting today with British hostages that was shown on Iraqi television and broadcast abroad.

headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   CRACKS APPEAR IN EMBARGO AS SEVERAL NATIONS DISCUSS RELIEF FOR IRAQ AND KUWAIT
abstract: LEAD: The first cracks in the international trade embargo against Iraq emerged today when several nations said they were considering sending emergency food and medical supplies to Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

headline: Evolution in Europe;   Mongolia Casts Votes in Multiparty Primary
abstract: LEAD: Mongolians began voting today in their Communist-ruled nation's first multiparty election, a primary for local, provincial and national legislators.

headline: PANAMA'S COURTS STALLED BY CHAOS
abstract: LEAD: The rugged island of Coiba, off the Pacific Coast here, is the kind of grim, isolated penal colony that nations have used throughout history to cage and punish their most hardened convicts.

headline: Underwriting Fees Decline Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The squeeze on Wall Street profits grew tighter in the last quarter, as fees for underwritings of securities fell by more than half, to their lowest levels in six years, and corporate America began to pull back from raising money in the capital markets.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Post a Gain; Others Mixed
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese stock market made up some of yesterday's losses today, as bargain-hunters pushed the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key Nikkei index up 3.10 percent. The world's other major stock markets rose or declined slightly.

headline: Dealer Incentives At Ford Reported
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company will offer sales incentives to dealers on some high-volume 1991 models and will increase advertising spending, according to a trade journal report. Automotive News said the incentives include a first-time-ever rebate of up to $500 on 1991 Ford Escorts. The incentives are in the form of a rebate to dealers, and the rebate amount will be based on the number of vehicles sold from July 10 to Aug.

headline: 0.9% Gain in Business Sales Limits Growth in Inventories
abstract: LEAD: A rebound in business sales in May helped keep inventories growing at a moderate rate and helped reduce the time it takes to exhaust the backlog of goods, the Government said today in a sign of continued economic expansion.

headline: New President in Line To Be Southeast Chief
abstract: LEAD: Douglas E. Ebert, who left the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in the spring after 22 years, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Miami-based Southeast Bank N.A. and is scheduled to become the bank's next chief executive.

abstract: LEAD: Because a service that provides The Associated Press with market data remained without power yesterday after a Monday fire at a Consolidated Edison plant in lower Manhattan, the commodity futures tables today contain only settlement prices and net changes, plus volume and open-interest figures where available.

headline: Church Prods Kenya to Issue Report on Death
abstract: LEAD: Stepping up its pressure for political change in Kenya, the Anglican Church called on the Government today to release a highly sensitive British investigative report on the slaying earlier this year of a former Foreign Minister.

headline: Seeks Joint Action
abstract: Declaring that Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait posed an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia, the United States today ordered thousands of paratroopers, an armored brigade and jet fighters to the Middle Eastern kingdom, officials said.
